description:
I came here for some lunch and definitely enjoyed the food. There mostly "to-go" counter was extremely busy but they were efficient with getting the orders out. We tried all the below items and enjoyed everything.

- Five spice chicken and vermicelli 
- Pork bun
- Meat sticky rice /banana leaf
-Ice Vietnamese coffee

Unfortunately, the make or break thing I think will come down to one thing: Price. You are paying waterfront pier prices, not small Vietnamese restaurant prices (which I totally get because their rent is probably not cheap ). For people who love Vietnamese food though, there will be a visceral, "You want me to pay how much?!" when they see the menu.
author: Doug P.

description:
After hearing rave reviews from friends about The Slanted Door, I had high expectations for their side-gig Out the Door while wandering around Ferry Building on an empty stomach (never a good idea!)

It's counter service, quick, and no-frills. I went around 4:30pm on a Monday and there was no line. I ordered a steamed chicken bun ($3.50) for a quick bite, although they have other options for actual meals, e.g. $16 lunch specials. 

I don't know what I was expecting from a $3.50 steamed chicken bun? Considering I could have probably gotten a much better one for $1 in Chinatown, probably the best chicken bun of my life. The filling was tasty and spicy but not enough - I ended up eating more dough than filling. 

Next time I'm in the Ferry Building, I'll definitely try to check out The Slanted Door, but Out the Door is a no from me.
author: Megha T.

description:
Exactly average, but high priced for what (which makes sense, since it's in the Ferry Building).

I tried the lemongrass chicken ($16 lunch special) and a black milk tea. The lemongrass chicken sauce mixed together with the rice was good, but nothing special. The milk tea was similarly good, but not great - the boba was a little squishier than I liked, but overall not badly priced for boba in the Ferry Building.

Overall, my feelings can be summed up by a simple 'meh'. I would probably not go here again, and take the extra walk to somewhere better!
author: Hannah H.

description: It was pricey but overall it was okay just can hear when ur number is being called.no one greeted me as I stood in line for had to walk up and figure If the cashier was ready to take my order
author: Jonisha W.

description: This is a delicious grab & go Vietnamese style restaurant! The chicken rice noodle soup was delicious! Homemade broth without any MSG flavors. The egg rolls were freshly made, and their steamed vegetarian buns are amazing! The portions may look small but carbs will expand!
author: Jamie C.

description:
I got the clay pot chicken and pork bun for lunch. When I first looked at my take out order, I wasn't super impressed. I asked myself why did I just get tourist trapped into spending $15+ for this chicken in runny brown sauce? The chicken looked like a shoyu or Asian style chicken dish that I could have gotten for half the price elsewhere. But when I took the first bite, it was so flavorful and tender. It complimented well with the aromatic broken rice that came with the dish. I couldn't stop eating it and slurped up the sauce after too!

Overall, I would come here again and try other dishes. I wasn't blown away by the pork bun but it wasn't bad. I would try the five spice chicken or a lemongrass dish next time!
author: Sandy L.

description: $2 worth of food for $14.  I could eat 3 of the chicken vermicelli bowl. It's mostly lettuce. Not worth the wait
author: Jay R.

description:
Even though I was still full from breakfast (and it wasn't lunch time yet), this little, unassuming stall in the Ferry Building immediately appealed to me.

I figured I could swing a snack, so I ordered a Steamed Pork Bun, which was incredibly savory and filled with rich pork in a light and steamy bun.

The service was quick, but friendly - sitting at the counter was a nice touch, too.
author: Herbie H.

description:
I've been to Slanted Door and thought it was fairly good.  Out the Door in Pac Heights was just so so.  So I was a little skeptical of Out The Door. But I wasn't satisfied with our lunch catering earlier that day at the office.  #IKnowFirstWorldTechProblems.  I attended a speaking session nearby at a conference at the Hyatt and was on the prowl for a snack. My dad loves traditional chinese chicken buns.  When he'd give them to me, I'd pretty much just eat the chicken and the bun part, while avoiding the black mushroom and the hard boiled egg part.  For the price of 1 at Out The Door you could get 2 or 3 in Chinatown or on Clement.  

But all I gots to say is, BEST OVERPRICED CHICKEN BUN!  The meat was so flavorful and moist.  The bun so fluffy and it all still tasted good 20 minutes later when I got back to the office to eat it.  It also didn't have a hard boiled egg or a nasty black mushroom which I so appreciate.  I can see why this bun made 7x7's list.  

Not sure if I'd get anything else here, and there's strong competition at the Ferry Building.  But if you want a bun or two OTD is the place!
author: Cat C.

description: Chicken salad with noodles is the best! I came here on the recommendation of a colleague and this salad was hands down one of the best salads I have had. The veg is crispy, the herbs are fresh, the balance of textures (rice noodles and peanuts and crispy noodles) is perfect. The dressing is perfectly balanced sweet/sour. A 5 for a salad may seem disproportionate - but honestly, it was just absolutely delicious. Also had a savory pork bun, and loved that as well!
author: Jennifer A.

description: I don't know why this place is so lowly rated. I came to Out the Door for lunch on my birthday on Friday and it was so delicious! I have never tried it before and I believe it is the quick take out restaurant of The Slanted Door which is the sit-down restaurant. I ordered the Five Spice Chicken Sandwich ($10 I believe) and it was so flavorful, not spicy and was so fresh with the cilantro, carrots, sweet mayo spread, and the freshest bread! Oh my gosh, so good! It is some of the most delicious, freshest Vietnamese food I have ever had! So delicious! :) They also have a variety of dishes like buns and curries. The only thing I don't like is that there is no seating. One thing I don't like about food markets is that there is no place to sit. So, I guess it's best to take it to go and sit down to eat somewhere else. Otherwise, the food was delicious and they had excellent service! I will definitely be back! So good! :)
author: Busayo O.

description:
I tried Out the Door for lunch a couple of days ago. This is located behind Slanted Door and seems to be its to-go Cafe. Like every other restaurant in the Ferry building at the peak lunch hour like there was a huge line to order. I dutifully got in line and after about 5 minutes was up. Due to a late breakfast I decided to get something light, so got two Steamed Chicken Buns ($3.50) to go.

After about 10 minutes of ordering someone came and told me that they were out of chicken buns and if I would like something else. On hearing a no, the person walked across to the small station that sells steamed buns and got me two from there. It seems that small station is also an extension of this place so I was getting the same product.

Let's come to the buns. They were piping hot, decent sized and two would be enough for a complete meal for a light eater. They were perfectly steamed and had a decent amount of filling. Overall they were pretty good. The question is, were they $3.50 a pop worth? I mean you can get steamed buns for $1.1 each in Chinatown and even cheaper in other places so a large part of what you are paying is for the location not the food. I mean these were much better but not 3x better. 

Other entree's too were all in the $15 range so this is definitely one of the more expensive to-go places to eat in FiDi. Looking at the overall package of quality, service, price and value I'd say this is A-Ok at best.
author: Ahmad J.

description: I ordered the veggie curry and it came with a side of rice. They asked me if I wanted a bag and they charged me 10 cents. When I got to my seat I noticed all the curry juice leaking all over the place. The lid fell off in a short walk to a bench. What mess. Overall, I thought it was bland and lacked any spice.
author: Stacey W.

description:
I come here for lunch around twice a month as it is very close to my office .
I love the shrimp Vietnamese spring rolls and the lemongrass pork. It's pricey but so is everything else in the ferry building.
author: Naina M.

description:
Make sure you remember to check their special menu on the chalkboard on the right side of the cashiers.. I've been here onat least five separate occasions now and have just recently noticed they offer more than what's on the main menu board up top.

Usually go with the chicken pho (it's around $14 if I remember correctly) but tried the sticky rice wrapped in banana leaves ($9 ish). It was good, would recommend anyone try it if you're getting bored of always getting pho there.

I decided to treat myself to a cup of Thai iced coffee this time. This is the size of a $3.75 cup of Thai iced coffee.. can you even call that a cup? And I have really small hands. I think I would've appreciated a heads up from the server that it was only going to be enough for two sips. Or that they serve it in a real person sized cup. I won't order the Thai coffee again.
author: Nat E.

description:
Because of other Yelp reviews, I made sure to order the pork bun....at $3.50 EACH. For a pork bun, there was a lot of filling, but at $3.50?

Additionally, I ordered the Lemongrass Chicken with rice which is only served from 11am - 2:30pm and I thought it was missing something. 

The people next to me were eating strong smelling soups which I bet tasted good, but the smell was too strong.
author: Monica S.

description: For tourists and Caucasions... had to pick up some chinese food for grandma since theres no other choices in this location, so... for conveniency
author: Jason C.

description:
We love getting food from here after strolling in the Ferry Building. The prices are high, but the taste of those pork buns are one of the best we had!

However, the tiny cup of ice vietnamese coffee is probably not worth it. It used to be normal size cup, this morning our jaw dropped when they handed us this kiddie cup of iced coffee.... Same price as ever, just downsized. What a disappointment, what a rip off. :(
author: YY M.

description:
I've been to the Slanted Door before and had nothing but the greatest experience there. I loved it so much that I bought their recipe book.
This was my first time trying Out the Door for lunch. I was excited to find out that they have this more "budget-friendly" option for lunch and since I work nearby I've decided to check it out. Everything seemed to be great, until I went back to my office and found a very sharp piece of a hard plastic in one of my wontons. Luckily I didn't hurt myself, but I cannot imagine how it got there (perhaps something plastic got ground together with the meat, in this case how many more people got it in their wontons?!) 
I took the soup back to them, they did return my money and offered me a free drink, but I sincerely didn't want anything at all from that place, who knows what's happening at their kitchen.
author: Lena G.

description:
I love their steamed pork buns and chicken buns : )
Always make me grin! Can't beat the price either
author: Sunny S.

description: Good vibe and a quick eat for me and my girlfriend. We got the pork and chicken bun. Check it out if you  come to the ferry building. Well priced as well.
author: Sumit S.

description:
This is a regular spot for me, I love the swift service but most of all the freshness and care with which they prepare the food. Vietnamese vegetarian imperial rolls this good are so hard to find! Their ponzu is a bit spicy which I love. 

Their fresh veggie spring rolls are delicious, I love how much mint they give you with each dish you order. The fresh roll comes with a spicy peanut dipping sauce which is addictive. I am so predictable with my order here, next time I'm sampling some new items, I'm sure they will be just as tasty. 

If you are at the Ferry Building this place is a must!
author: Kelly T.

description:
Walked "Out the Door" thinking "why on earth did I just pay over $12 for two spring rolls", but here I am licking the peanut sauce off my fingers because it was so darn delicious!

The dipping sauce is really what made my whole purchase worth while, but the spring rolls themselves were very delicious as well -- soft bite with a nice crunch from the lettuce wrapped inside.

Worth $12? For the sauce, yes. One day, I'll steal their secret recipe & make millions.
author: Monica H.

description:
Had a 5-spice chicken banh mi. Not very good. The bread was too tough, there was too much mayo, and the chicken didn't taste like chicken (tasted almost fishy?). I'm not a fan of cilantro to start with but there was way too much cilantro, not enough cucumber or carrot. A lot of chicken but wasn't even tasty chicken. I had hoped the '5-spice' would be unique and flavorful-but this 5-spice was probably used to mask the weird taste of the chicken which might have been kind of old.  :-(

Their baos are freshly steamed which looks delicious but I wasn't about to pay $3.50 for 1 bao when you can buy a pack of 10 from 99 ranch for like $5.
author: Lydia Z.

description: Service is prompt. Order is always delicious and correct. Wait time is minimal because they hustle. Price is right. We now frequent this place...
author: Jocelyn T.

description:
I USED to enjoy stopping by Out the Door but today will have to be my last visit. 

First - when did they start charging $12 for two spring rolls? And what happened to the size of the Vietnamese iced coffee? It came in a kiddie cup and when I asked if maybe I received the wrong drink they rudely asked if I had ever had it before (I'm part Vietnamese), and then explained that they "don't use water anymore" which I still don't understand. 

Second - sooo much attitude from the guy who rang me up. From the second I walked up to the counter he treated me like I was encroaching on something important, but he was more than friendly to the two women who ordered after me

I support local businesses but I draw the line at rude clerks talking badly about me in Vietnamese while charging me overpriced snacks.
author: Shaun L.

description:
For $12 your vermicelli bowl better be fresh and tasty and not that sad excuse for a roasted bork Bun that I got yesterday. The lettuce was yellowing and limp, totally not fresh, and looked like a Trader Joe's salad for which you forgot to look at the expiration date. There were no other fresh vegetables in there, and the pork was salty as all hell. AND the noodles were overcooked. 
Nope, not going back.
author: Natasha C.

description: Terrible value. 12 bucks for 6 teeny tiny pieces of fried spring rolls (2 rolls each cut in 3). Served with a disproportionately large amount of lettuce and some rice noodles. On top of which they were not delicious. I don't recommend.
author: chris d.

description:
Stopped by for a light lunch and ordered the vegetarian spring roll and steamed pork bun ($15 total).  Both were pretty good but not outstanding.  The spring roll was pretty well executed with a nice peanut dipping sauce but fairly standard.  And while the pork bun was also good I have had better (I am looking at you Yang Sing).

I will likely return to try something else.
author: Bob F.

description: Run by the same family who owns the Slanted Door. We love the spring rolls, pork buns and the roasted pork sandwich. Always fresh and tasty, and the price is reasonable considering where you are.
author: John C.

description:
Everyone seems to love this place as a lunch option, but it's honestly just okay for me. 

The pork buns here are good and the spring rolls are pretty hefty, but other than that, there's nothing here that amazes me. Okay, it doesn't have to amaze me, sure.. But there's nothing here that makes me want to come back. I end up only coming here if coworkers want to.

Maybe it's cause the standard is slanted door (given that this is the to-go version), but I'm consistently unimpressed by out the door, after repeated times coming here with coworkers for lunch.

Honestly think there are much better Asian options around fidi.
author: Nicole L.

description:
They have take out food here. The same food that they have at the Slanted Door.
Usually get the spring rolls with peanut sauce, Shakin beef ( you'll have to cook this),
green papaya salad. Very good. So easy to prepare.
author: Gayle G.

description:
Early dinner in the Embarcadero on a lovely Sunday afternoon at The Slanted Door.

Started with the Pork belly, which was cooked perfectly, tender and juicy with a nice BBQ sauce, which was a bit too sweet, but complimented nicely by Thai chilies.

I always get the grapefruit jicama and red cabbage salad. A wonderful mainstay that is my all time favorite salad in SF! The roasted pecans, covered w salty caramel balance this classic dish.

The Rib Eye steak was delicious and cooked medium. 
The steak was accompanied by glass and flat noodles and eggplant.  

Overall a great meal and reasonably priced, except for  the steak (13 oz.) which was $48...
author: John M.

description:
The chicken noodle soup is a life saver!  I wasn't feeling well today and I vaguely remembered the beef noodle soup being quite tasty here so I ventured out and not only was my soup on the counter within only a few minutes (this place gets crowded during the lunch rush)- but they had an unfiltered ginger ale in the refrigerated section to soothe my tummy.

I got back to my desk and opened the lid.  The warm and hearty parfum of chicken and ginger tantalized my senses.  The first sip of soup... was simply deliciousness all bundled in my bowl!  I could taste the chicken broth that only comes from simmering a whole chicken with ginger and garlic for hours.  There was a light layer of glistening unctuous fatty goodness on the top of my soup adding to the depth of the beautiful savory chicken noodle soup.

One of my new favorites! I will be back.
author: Alicia W.

description: Fast counter service with good food. Tried the lemon grass pork & vermicelli and would order again.
author: Maia M.

description: Stopped  in while on vacation after we had to cancel our reservation at the slanted door because the kids were sleepy and losing it. We took this back to our hotel and enjoyed with some trader Joe's wine. It was delicious. They were sold out of a lot when we got there at 6, but the buns were delicious as were the vermicelli and rice dishes. The pork was slightly dry, but flavors were spot on.
author: Clint L.

description:
I love out the door and have for a while because years ago their chicken mushroom buns really got me. The buns are consistently good and only available at out the door (not on slanted door menu).  The buns are well seasoned, filled with succulent dark meat and mushrooms. An awesome grab and go treat or if you get two, small lunch. 

Today I also had the clay pot chicken! It's a decent sized portion with delicate short grained rice. The chicken is in a sweet, scrumptious caramel-ly sauce that is topped with fresh cilantro that really contrasts with the sauce. All dark meat, score! It is a "special" but I have seen it on their menu a few times. 

Definitely a great place in the ferry building! Only 5 chairs and then two standing tables there but you can always head to the back to lunch or dine with a view. Yeah, there is more "authentic" Vietnamese in the city but not at the ferry building and overall the food is very well-executed.
author: Emily P.

description: I order the Lemongrass Pork with Rice for lunch one weekday since I work in the area. I expected a decent meal being they are affiliated with The Slanted Door, but man it was a letdown. I've had my share of Lemongrass + Meat dishes but this was the worst. The pork was cold and dry, I'm guessing they gave me leftovers from the night before and didn't bother to warm it up. And I noticed all the other photos on Yelp had peanuts, but none for me. I will never go back to this tourist trap.
author: D. T.

description: Yes it's a bit expensive, but you're paying for the view if you take your lunch outside and watch the ferry boats come and go. Good, solid Vietnamese take away. Very busy at lunch time. A good option at the Ferry Building if you don't want a sit down meal.
author: Prescott B.

description: I've eaten here several times (have also been to the other side, Slanted Door). This place is consistently excellent for lunch. One thing to watch out for is the lines, they start getting out of hand around noon. I guess that is the price of popularity! My favorite dish is the *crispy duck salad*, highly recommend! For out of towners, the price is typical for a SF lunch.. usually around $15/person.
author: Matthew H.

description:
Out the Door was an unassuming food shop stop while wandering through the Ferry Building looking for some light eats. I was unaware, at the time, of the affiliation between Out the Door and Slanted Door, so this review is with respect to its individual performance and without any expectations tied to its flagship shop.

Pork banh mi: a meat mountain inside a baguette. I only tried one piece of pork, which was on the dry side, but very flavorful and filling. My boyfriend seemingly enjoyed this sandwich. $8.50 is expected for SF + Ferry Building considered, but it still hurt a bit. 

Spring rolls: Rice paper was strong yet delicate and yielded easily to a bite. I know it's a simple aspect, but I've never really liked rice paper that much until these rolls. The filling could have used more protein, and what is this creamy mayonnaise-y spread? Inauthentic and unnecessary. Their peanut sauce is unique and creamier than most I've had, which would effectively eliminate the need for that mystery spread. Pretty damn delicious sauce, but could be even more delicious with the addition of crushed peanuts. Overall, would eat again, but $9 for two rolls is a bit much. 

Vietnamese coffee: Not strong enough. I appreciate the authentic Vietnamese coffee filters doing their thang in the corner, but the resultant product was much too weak, especially with the munificent amount of ice. Stronger coffee, less ice please. 

The workers were very friendly and quick with their service, which I appreciate. 

Overall, a good option when craving Vietnamese food when in the Ferry Building hood. Pros are for tasty food, cons are for steep prices, weak coffee, and weird mystery mayo. Out the Door, until we meet again.
author: Shirley V.

description: This restaurant is a slam dunk.  It is located in the Ferry Building. The food is so delicious.  The customer service is impeccable.  The ingredients are of the highest quality - and it is obvious based on how good the food tastes.  I got the chicken noodle soup and my boyfriend got the chicken clay pot - both were yummmmmmmy - light, fresh, nourishing. The only thing is that its expensive, but so is everything in San Francisco.  I also wish they had more seating.  Otherwise, I love this place.
author: Ghazal S.

description: It was s nice sunny day yesterday so, decided to walk to the ferry building with my caretaker.  We had an ice tea at Out the Door couple weeks back so this time we were ready to try out food...five spice chicken banh mi. A fruit tea boba and Vietnamese ice coffee. There is a bit of a wait in line but it's expected in this area. Luckily we had the bar seats to eat comfortably. The banh mi looks good and it's big enough to split/share. I got caffeine from the coffee so eating a hardy sandwich was great. Loaded with chicken, cilantro and veggies. It was her first time trying banh mi and she said she loved it. It's about $24 total. The drinks could be served in a bigger cup.
author: Vee V.

description:
Originally we did not plan to eat here, but looking back, it was a great decision to try this restaurant/to-go place(?).

Foods:
+ They have a variety of Chinese and Southeast Asian dishes. The salad and rice bowl were Vietnamese-style banh mi like. 
+ The chicken porridge is a tasty traditional Chinese rice porridge. Maybe not the most delicious porridge but it is authentic enough and I wouldn't mind to go back to eat here just for the porridge.

Area:
- There were not many tables to eat. There are many seats (no tables) outside, near the pier.
author: Rafael W.

description:
You ruined the Vietnamese iced coffee! It's half the size and it tastes weird.

Change it back you just lost a customer
author: Stephanie Joyce D.

description: They may have tourist-trap prices but the food is definitely up to snuff. I love their noodle soups, five spice chicken and Hong Kong style milk tea, but my absolute favorite is their chicken porridge, which in my opinion beats everywhere else in SF (yes, that includes Chinatown). Perfect for a quick lunch.
author: Carl W.

description:
Lunch review. 

Crispy imperial rolls - 4/5 - 7x7. $3 cheaper than inside.

Overall, "I'm a fan."
author: Mark O.

description: Got the lemongrass pork and it was not good at all. Its a little bit spicy which was fine but not expected. the meat was so chucky and tough to chew. so much meat and very little noodles. VERY disappointed. I took a few bite and threw it away.
author: R A.

description:
Had a quick breakfast/lunch before my trip back to New York and I would like something simple and relaxing, so out the door became our first choice. 

Ordered the veggie bun and chicken porridge. Tons of mushrooms inside the bun, yummy! Also liked the dried garlic on top of my porridge, making it flavorful and reminded me my time back at home eating mom's cooking. They also serve noodle soup/Vietnamese sandwich/bubble teas which I would like to try them all.
author: Elaine H.

description:
Staff: Not very friendly, not very rude. A smile and a thank you go a long way to pleasing customers.

Pricey: You can blame this on the Ferry Building surcharge. Everything in here seems to be 50% pricier than elsewhere. $12 for a banh mi? GTFOOH!!!

Food: Not bad, not great.

Conclusion: I would only order from here if I was already here, was starving, and in the mood for something on their menu.
author: J K.

description: I got an iced coffee from this place it was amazing!!! It was ice cold and very refreshing. I was thinking it would be a larger size than it was but I enjoyed it lots. I would come back for an iced coffee again but maybe order two instead of one for the amount of coffee you get
author: Jessica S.

description:
Let me just say up front: This place is pricey and it is a splurge.  There's no seating area and a meal will come to the same as a medium-ranged sit down.  However, they use quality ingredients that taste SO good.  I love the spring roll ($$$, but just better than other spring rolls I've had), the beef pho, the salads, and the chicken banh mi.  Everything is probably a 25-40% premium over other places, but it just has a clean and amazing taste I have not found elsewhere.

I decided to venture to Dragon Eats for their chicken Banh Mi today.  And, while it was $6.50 vs OTD's $11, it was not quite as good and OTD's has 1.5-2x the meat.  With the OTD sandwich, I can have over two meals.  So, it's definitely $$$$, but still my go to in this area when I'm craving spring roll, pho or banh mi.  

If prices were $1-2 less, it'd be a 5* place in my book!  but, I imagine Ferry Bldg rent ain't cheap.
author: Kathryn C.

description:
Update:
Still loving this spot in the Ferry Building.  Always a go to for their steamed pork buns.  I'd honestly pass on their drinks, but I was thirsty that day.  The drinks are decent, but overpriced.  They're also filled with a bit too much ice (literally half ice).  Maybe ask for less if you do need a drink.  

This place has some awesome food, a bit pricey, but I think its worth it.  Located in the Ferry Plaza, this place serves a good variety of food.  My friends and I came and tried a variety of things.  I had the rice porridge and a pork bun.  The rice porridge was bigger than I expected and very tasty.  The pork bun was my favorite though, it was so flavorful!  It sort of reminded me of a xiaolongbao but without the soupiness.  It was fantastic though, and I would definitely recommend stopping by for one if you're in the area.  Another couple random observations: it can get really busy here so your food may take a bit.  Also there isn't very much seating.  But overall, fantastic food!
author: Bryson L.

description: I wanted to try the grilled five spices chicken sandwich but it was not available. The server suggested I take chicken clay pot which was some and tasted good and served very hot. If you are hungry and in the area u should definitely try to catch a light meal
author: Jaynab Y.

description:
Usually my go-to place for a quick bite / pickup before boarding the ferry home. Food is decent but so overpriced. Not a deal breaker considering this is San Francisco and at the ferry building. 

Today paid $50-something for two bowls, a sandwich and spring rolls. Price is a given buuuut the service was tougher to swallow. Guy at the register was rude and unwelcoming!!! Normally when you approach a human being who works at a business / food establishment you're greeted with a simple hello. He said nothing, stared at me with an annoyed look. No hi. No how can I help you. I just ordered, waited and picked up food. I grabbed bag and no thank you or have a good day. Ummm this is a business food establishment. You want customers ? You want to keep them? At least greet them and say have a good day. Even if you have to fake it. Never going back. Fix your customer service issue.
author: Constantine C.

description: Yummy food but the seating is EXTREMELY limited (almost non existent). The line is long but moves really fast. The ferry building is an excellent touch and it makes the whole experience worth it.
author: Rita A.

description: Please clean the hairs off your pork dish before serving. It was pretty gross. Not one hair but a ton. You can see the hair on the meat. After realizing that its not human hair, I realized it just was not skinned or cleaned thoroughly before just tossing some sauce on it to cover it up ugh. For the price it should be a lot more effort into it. 3 stars for other dishes like the spring rolls and chicken pho
author: L M.

description:
Vietnamese take out in the ferry building that's decently fast. 

~$12 for a chicken salad with some noodles: not a large portion of chicken, but kept me full long enough.

Few seats available at their bar. 

TLDR: will do in a pinch, but kinda pricey for what you get
author: Kristie C.

description: The chicken noodle soup is my favorite but has been much less flavorful recently. Also, the bubble tea the bubble is not right - is not flavorful and the middle of bubble is not cooked. You guys don't know how to cook bubble.
author: Anya C.

description: Best pork vermecelli I have had in a while. Staff wasn't the most friendly, but food was bomb.
author: Sarah R.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Friday. I have had positive experiences with Charles Phan restaurants in the past, like Slanted Door when I turned 16 and also Out the Door when it used to be located at the SF Westfield Mall. I mean I knew I wouldn't get a beautiful dining experience and service of sitting in front of the Bay Bridge, but I expected a dish that would have the casual version of the same caliber! I wanted a rice dish, and when I saw the Lemongrass pork with vegetables I was sold. However I can't say my tastebuds were sold. 

I think I waited about 10-15 mins for my order. When it finally came, I had to hope to get a seat or standing room at one of their tables. It's first come first serve, which is frustrating since some people have finished their soup 20 mins ago but are still catching up with their friends and lounging around. 

Anyway, I took my first bite of my lemongrass pork. Cold. Took another bite. Cold. Took a look at my vegetables - it was actually just broccoli, no variation. Took a bite of broccoli - cold. Took a bite of the rice, which was short grain. WARM AND DELICIOUS!!! ....to think that my favorite part of the disk was the rice. Really now? 

My total was $13 for the whole thing. To be honest, I'm fine with paying that much for a fancier lunch that comes from Charles Phan, but not if my food comes out cold. Disappointing. And another tip for the restaurant, it's super frustrating to be given numbers that don't put the guests in numerical order. They should do something similar to in-n-out where you can anticipate where your order is in the line.
author: Jocelyn L.

description: When you order the meat sticky rice and get this. Is it a sausage?? So disappointed. #fail.
author: LL T.

description: Vegetarian steamed buns are made with egg yoke... from what I have read, traditional steamed buns do not included egg yoke. Wish they could have an option without. Vegan Unfriendly.
author: Steven T.

description:
3.5 stars is a bit too low for this place and is probably reflective more of the price than anything. If you go here, I highly recommend the chicken porridge. At $9, it is expensive considering it's mostly rice, but the broth that they cook the rice in is A+ - it is the most flavorful base I've ever had in my life! While the porridge only has sparing pieces of chicken (and none of the good stuff like the preserved eggs, etc) it's so flavorful and the addition of the fried donut pieces more than makes up for it. 

Note there's no nearby seating but you can eat standing near the big tables.
author: Amy G.

description:
Had time between our morning tour and afternoon tour to visit the Ferry Building.  Lots of eating options, so we chose the take-away Slanted Door spin off, Out the Door.  In short, it was decent.

It's a pretty much a takeaway spot with 5 or 6 stools in front of a small counter.  There are plenty of other spots in the Ferry Building to sit down including some outdoor options.  

I had a pork sandwich and Shari V had lemongrass tofu over vermicelli.  Both dishes were totally adequate.  My sandwich had fresh vegies and the pork was medium quality, around what one would expect for a $10 sandwich.  The shortcomings of both dishes were their lack of seasonings, sauces and mostly a lack of flavor.  It wasn't that anything tasted bad, but it just lacked taste in general.  

There are so many good options in the Ferry Building.  Next time, I'll try another.
author: Chris B.

description:
# 29 Out the Door *Rod Boba SF Rating * 3/3 *Rod's Yelp Rating *2 stars 

Review is simply for the boba which I tried here recently for the first time. It left a lot to be desired and I couldn't finish the whole thing. I will try the food dishes I'm sure in the future.
author: Rod M.

description:
Although there were mixed reviews, I checked out Out the Door at the Ferry Building in between Pokemon Go Hunting on the Embarcadero on my last visit to SF.  Compared to those below-4 star-reviewers, perhaps I just ordered well off the menu.  I opted for their Chicken Noodle Soup aka Pho Ga and split a Vegetarian Steamed Bun with my sister.  

The pho was portioned to my liking in that I thought it was a generous and healthy serving for takeaway.  I had ample noodles and the breast meat in the soup were tender and cooked well.  I was also provided with the usual dressings of lime, bean sprouts, basil, etc.  Before I added the dressings, I thought the broth was good, but not necessarily bringing the "pho" flavor I was expecting.  If you're looking for pho, you may be disappointed when it doesn't quite meet your expectations.  However, maybe that's the reason it's listed as Chicken Noodle Soup as opposed to Pho Ga.  After I added the lime & co, I got more of the "Vietnamese" flavor in pho, but it wasn't the same.  That being said, I still enjoyed the meal.

The real star of my takeout experience there was the Vegetarian Steamed Bun.  After splitting it with my sister, we immediately went back for more and then some more on top of that for the long road back down to San Diego.  The filling is of mixed mushroom, glass noodles, and spring onions.  The flavors it brought to the steamed bun were fantastic, especially for being vegetarian, and the steamed bun part was wonderfully warm and pillowy (I can use that as a word, right?).  *drool*  I appreciate a good vegetarian dish anywhere, but THIS was a fantastic find and alternative to traditionally meat-based Asian savory buns.

I'll definitely hit up Out the Door for more of dem buns next time I'm at the Ferry Building!
author: Halstene A.

description: My friend told me how awesome their taro boba drinks are and she did not lie. They are amazing. They use real taro and the overall taste of the drink is just perfect. It doesn't taste americanized and tastes very authentic. The boba is also surprisingly pretty good. It costs about $4-$5. They do validate if you park in the outdoor parking lot across the street. I went here twice in one week....
author: Tommy L.

description: I've literally missed this every time I walk by.  Hidden place to get good boba - very fresh similar to Ten Ren! Also the taro boba is clearly made from real taro (and not powdered) giving much more distinct and thicker taro drink.
author: Dion L.

description:
So I came here for lunch while trying to kill time waiting for the ferry on a Tuesday afternoon. I decided to try the lemongrass pork with vermicelli and was hoping that for $12 that it would fill me up. 

Let me just say that I am glad I aso have a banana and halo in my backpack because this is not enough for a lunch. Maybe a snack or lunch for a small child...but not an adult. The pork was not even that warm and honestly the whole meal was mediocre at best. I have definately had better Vietnamese food.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
I am so happy this little pop-up version of Slanted Door exists. It has redeemed the whole of SOMA for me with regards to Asian food. 

Its a good place to stop by for lunch during work or while sightseeing because the lines don't seem to be too long and service is quick. 

Admittedly it is overpriced for Asian food, but given that all other Asian food in SOMA is overpriced, I think it gets a pass... especially because it outshines most other places in taste. 

First time there, I got the chicken rice porridge and a steamed pork bun. Both were on point. The porridge comes out pipping hot with a side bag of youtiao (Chinese oil sticks) to eat it with. Just know that with the porridge, the chunks of chicken are buried at the bottom of the container. I didn't realize this and didn't come upon the chicken until I had almost reached the bottom of the bowl. I hear that the lemongrass chicken is also very good although it takes them longer to prepare.

I'll be back to try more of their dishes!
author: Rica Z.

description: Conveniently located and the food is decent. Not the best Asian cuisine in town; however, it's quick and will leave satisfied. The buns are great; the porridge and the soup are decent.
author: David C.

description: This was very good for a little establishment with little room! There is not a lot of seating and the line gets long fast, but in my opinion it's well worth the wait and eating outside with the ocean view is way better anyways. I ordered the chicken porridge which normally when I get from any where else I have to add sauces for taste but this was tasty on its own! Also got the lemongrass pork and vegetables. The pork wasn't over done and had just the right amount of fast. FYI the vegetables is only broccoli which didn't bother me much. Service was nice and fast highly recommend but come early before the lunch rush!
author: Tianna C.

description: Out the Door is a take-out/counter-service spot in the Ferry Building that's connected to the famous Slanted Door restaurant. The options here are much more limited than the full restaurant--there are rice/vermicelli bowls, noodle soups, as well as salads and a few snack options. I stopped by here for lunch and ordered the lemongrass pork vermicelli bowl. The pork itself was very tasty--there was plenty of meat, and the slices were glazed in a sweet dressing that almost gave it a flavor (and texture) of pork jerky. The noodles and salad were pretty standard, and there was a container of sweet fish sauce that doused the whole dish. While the food definitely wasn't bad, it wasn't nearly worth the $12 price tag, as the portion was tiny, and there's almost no place to sit at the counter. I would be interested in trying out the full Slanted Door restaurant, but probably wouldn't return to get take-out here for lunch.
author: David K.

description:
I finally had the chance to try the curry chicken rice plate. The food was good, the chicken was moist and the rice was cooked perfectly. In short, the food was excellent. However, $13.75 for two drum sticks and white rice is highway robbery plain and simple.

I won't take a start off, but the food was way over priced.
author: Corey H.

description: Out the Door needs to stop doing boba drinks. I work in the Ferry Building so I've tried many of their boba options many times, and I've sadly reached the conclusion that it just isn't good no matter what you order. The boba is stale and clumped up, the tea is lukewarm, and the wait is long. Go elsewhere for boba!
author: Kayla T.

description:
Just had the veggie sandwich and it was pretty amazing. I am a harsh critic on the veggie patties if it is done wrong- but I must admit, they nailed it! I was pleased with my sandwich :) 

Only 3 stars because the service could be improved. The organization is awkward. I was told to move by the staff while I was ordering food because apparently I was in the way...it was incredibly rude and I was rather surprised.... But other than that, excellent veggie sandwich.
author: Kimberly N.

description:
Story time: Called in to place a phone order. Waited over 7 minutes before someone picked up. When I told her I wanted to place an order, she said, "Normally, we don't do phone orders unless it's over $100." So I told her, I'm pretty sure I have an order over $100. Then she proceeds to saying, "Normally, we don't take phone orders from 11-2 but since we're not busy, we'll do it." Ok woman, if you don't want my business, JUST SAY SO.

ANYWAYS. I had the lemongrass pork vermicelli and I really like the meat here. There's just something about the marinade that is yummy. The sauce is spicy and more sour than other places. Other than that, everything else is just EH. For $11, the portion is small. You could probably find a cheaper place with a larger portion that tastes just as good.
author: Benita M.

description:
Out the Door is the little brother of the famed Charles Phan Slanted Door restaurant. It would be more appropriate to call them siamense twins as they are joined at the butt at the Ferry Building. Unlike the dine in Slanted Door, Out the Door features a take out menu of various Vietnamese dishes ranging from noddle soups, Noodle bowls and rice plates. 

I came here with Christine S. in hopes to find Slanted Door quality in a quick take out format. We ordered the Hanoi Beef Noodle Soup and Clay pot Chicken and Broken rice. The Hanoi Beef Noodle Soup is essentially your boilerplate Beef Pho bowl with rare cuts of beef. The soup was nothing to rave about and the noodles were limp from being over cooked. The meat was the star of this dish, but the cooled down the soup faster than I wanted.

The clay pot Chicken was flavorful with a caramelized fish sauce exterior. The chicken tasted as if it was stewed for a while and lost its tender texture. I never heard of broken rice before but I imagined something crisp and Broken after being cooked. The rice grains were actually broken before it was cooked and gave a softer moist texture. Not what I expected but it came out as described.

The food overall did not stand out in any aspect. The flavor reminded me of dishes that my mom would cook or of places that provide larger portions pack with more flavor for cheaper.
author: David C.

description:
Decent fast-food counter in the SF Ferry Building

For a little shop tucked at the back, the food is actually decent. The congee was flavorful, with large chunks of real chicken, and colorful seasoning. The vietnamese iced coffee was also very strong (probably brewed for quite some time).

The only downside is the price--it costs $9 for a small bowl of congee, which is probably expected given the location. There is no dedicated seating, so you'll need to find seats outside next to the Pier most likely.
author: Henry L.

description:
I like how they serve up boba in the Ferry building and small delicious bites, such as their Chicken Turnovers, Papaya Salads, Wonton Egg Noodle Soups, Steamed Buns and Vietnamese Sandwiches!

It's more or less $10 for a meal here!  It is of the norm around here!

Their service is quick and you will be surely Out The Door in a jiffy!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
I've been to Out the Door twice and neither experience was very impressive. My first experience was years ago and I got a chicken vermicelli soup of some kind with a bland broth.  This time, I needed a snack while I waited for a late dinner.  I will say I liked Slanted Door much better but I guess Out the Door fills a niche for quick and snack foods. 

I ordered a $3 steamed pork bun.  It was ready to go in a steamer tray.  The steamed bun most resembled a steamed char siu bao from dim sum.  I really disliked the filling - the sauce was goopy which impacted my perspective of the pork and a little too gingery. I also ordered a HK milk tea which took about 5 min to make.  This was fine - a nice combination of sweetened hot milk and strong tea that they brew fresh per cup.
author: Les L.

description:
I love Vietnamese food and want to like this place, but...eh. I've been twice and wasn't blown away either time.

Yesterday I had the lemongrass tofu dish. The chunks of tofu had a nice flavor profile but needed a boost from Sriracha and soy sauce, which are conveniently provided in to-go portions. It came with a pile of white rice and steamed broccoli, which was too crunchy and also a bit discolored. The broccoli and rice were really plain--I wish there had been more sauce coverage. And it took a long time to slop this portion together. Not a worthwhile lunch, and it was over $12 with tax.

Maybe I'll return to try some other dishes, like sandwiches or spring rolls or boba...but I'm not in a big hurry. As other reviewers say, there are better options in the Ferry Building.
author: Elinor A.

description: Love this place! Food is great. I love the pork buns, spring rolls, and the grilled five spice chicken sandwich. Whenever I'm visiting San Francisco I love to go to this place!
author: Roxanna Gisell R.

description:
Their chicken pho is delicious! The chicken is a little greasy, which makes the soup a little greasy, but still perfect for a cloudy day.

There are some sitting and standing tables right next to it! Grab a bowl of soup and get slurping!
author: Michelle L.

description:
I actually was a fan of Slanted Door back in the day.  Nowadays, many people say it's gotten a bit long in the tooth and that Asian fusion isn't quite as popular as it once was about a decade ago.

Still, I was very glad that there's an Out the Door branch at the Ferry Building.  It's well executed and serves a lot of the same type and style of food as the sit-down restaurant, but perfect for a walk around place like the Ferry Building. 

I stopped by today as I heard that the chicken porridge served earlier in the day was a listee on 7x7 Magazine's annual Big Eat list for San Francisco.  It supposedly had sold out the week before when a friend tried to go, so I beelined my way over early.

For $8, you get a decent size bowl of chicken porridge.  It's ready quickly and topped with a nice assortment of scallions and I believe deep fried onions and garlic.  A brown paper bag contains a few pieces of sliced Chinese donut.

I eat a lot of Chinese porridge and congee and Out the Door's version is a bit more mainstream.  It's very flavorful, has large pieces of tender white and dark chicken meat and isn't as thick as some of the Chinese versions I've had that have been boiling over for hours to concentrate the flavor.  

Overall, I liked the bowl, though it's admittedly pricey compared to more authentic versions.  None the less, it was very tasty, had great quality ingredients and I often love an Asian fix among all the other restaurants in the Ferry Building (and I don't mean those crazily priced steamed pork buns at Imperial Tea!)

Solid.  

Out the Door accepts all credit cards including American Express.
author: Randy F.

description:
Dee-lee-see-us.

Got the fresh spring rolls, a steamed pork bun, and the Niman Ranch beef salad with orange. (Yes, I am a fatty.)

The pork bun came out warm, and its contents were piping hot! Pretty sure I got a burn on my tongue, but it was a price I gladly paid. Yum. The beef salad was probably one of the best salads I've ever had in my whole 21 years of living. The meat was seasoned beautifully and the crispy taro strips gave the salad great texture. I thought the spring rolls were just alright - not worth $8.

Grab your order and enjoy your meal (and the view) outside!
author: Jennifer K.

description: The crispy roasted duck lunch item was overcooked and came out dry/stale vs crispy. I was also very sad that I paid about  $10 for 4 tiny vegetarian dumplings that had a bean filling inside that tasted funny. Everything is overpriced and execution is disappointing.
author: Briget P.

description:
Really not impressed. I came to the Ferry Building with the intention of finding and trying Gott's for the first time, but somehow got swayed into trying Out the Door (which is right across from Gott's) instead. 

Like most of what's in the Ferry Building, Out the Door is a stall with limited seating - in this case, a few seats at a small counter - but Out the Door charges for their food what you'd expect at a sit-down, full-service restaurant. For a bowl of lemongrass pork vermicelli, an iced coffee and milk boba, and a bottle of water, my total was $19.98. I'm used to averaging about $10 a day for lunch around my building in the Financial District but this was ridiculous, and I felt stupid saying "no thanks" and canceling my order when the guy at the counter gave me my total, so I just swallowed my pride and paid. 

I found it hilarious when the guy openly looked at my receipt after I signed for my purchase to see how much, if anything, I paid in a tip (and I don't feel bad in admitting I tipped zero), and looked mildly annoyed when he looked away. The food came instantaneously, and as I was drinking my boba walking away I realized it was my first mistake. The pearls were flavored, it tasted almost floral like something like Jasmine, which were actually very delicious, but tasted awful with the extremely strong iced coffee with milk. Two very distinct flavors clashed in the cup and for the first time ever, I didn't finish my boba. Really haphazard, poorly executed attempt at a coffee boba drink - please don't just dump boba in iced coffee and think it's going to work.

The vermicelli bowl seemed like it had more food in it than there really was, as about a third of the bowl was a mint salad and there was a stingy amount of noodles at the bottom. The meat had great flavors and wasn't exactly tough, but tasted like and had the consistency of softened jerky. 

Not returning, not impressed with the food and the small amount of it that you get for what you pay, overpriced boba, all topped with a cold cashier that had the nerve to check what he was getting tipped right in front of me. Should've just stuck with trying Gott's.
author: Angela M.

description:
I ordered the pork banh mi sandwich. It was mediocre. So much pork inside the sandwich I had to take some out because it was grossing me out. Perhaps this wouldnt be a problem for heavy meat eaters.
Inside with the pork mountain was some shredded carrots,  cilantro and what seems to be straight up mayonnaise. Meh. Disappointing for $12.50+ tax.
No daikon, jalapenos, or flavorful sauce.

If you're craving a banh mi, go to Saigon Deli Express. Theirs are more authentic and around $7. Can't be that!

Sorry out the door, try again!
author: Marie B.

description: Snobbery! Overrated! Forgot to give me  utensils?!? And to think I even tipped them? Most expensive lunch ever. Never again
author: Neo23 T.

description:
I've probably come to Out the Door many many times since I've started working in the financial district. I tend to only order 1 thing when I go to out the door - chicken porridge. The chicken porridge has thick slices of ginger and all the chicken at the bottom so be sure to mix it up before eating it. 

The 7x7 list suggested to get the crispy imperial rolls from Slanted Door and as much as I love a good restaurant, I love a good deal. The food at Slanted Door, I'm pretty sure, is made in the same kitchen as Out the Door. 

Overall, pretty good food. Decently priced (for the ferry building). 

Protip: get there early to be able to try all the food, the lines at noon are ridiculous.
author: Nina Y.

description:
The food is good but I hate that the restaurant is labeled as Vietnamese when the food actually comes from all  over East Asia -- a lot of them Chinese. Slanted Door is the same -- Japanese, Chinese, Vietnamese, etc, etc...

Just call it what it is -- Asian fusion. But don't plagiarize.
author: Jay Y.

description:
The to go place of slanted door....aka heaven on a plate. Slanted door is a god send but the lines and necessary reservations even for lunch...not so much. So hello Out the Door. This is the go to place. 

I got the chicken salad and noodle. First of all HUGE portion, couldn't finish it so A+ because it's leftover for tomorrow. Second of all food was super duper fast! My coworkers all seemed super pleased with their food too! It's the best of both worlds! 

Tips:
-Yes, the line looks dauntingly long, do not let that dissuade you. It goes super duper fast! 
-the pork buns are amazing and already ready if you're really short on time
author: Sami F.

description: I love Slanted Door and really wanted to like this place. I went with a group of friends, and we all ordered different things. I had a duck/rice plate (which I don't see on their current menu). The duck was overcooked, the fried rice was bland, and everyone who ordered the iced boba threw it out. They have good, but very slow service for a to-go lunch spot. There are a few bar height tables you can eat around, but usually, these are take. Long wait for a bland $20 lunch and nowhere to eat it. No thanks.
author: Nelya T.

description: My usual here is a black tea boba here which is really great in the middle of the workday. The flavor of the tea is very nice and I highly recommend giving it a try. I've also had a pork sandwich here which is ridiculously good and packed to the brim.
author: Steven P.

description: I've been to Out the Door a number of times for lunch and usually always order the Hanoi beef noodle soup. On a cold day, it'll usually hit the spot, but for a whopping 14 bucks.  You'd think a to-go restaurant wouldn't charge that much, but that's the Ferry Building for you.  I've also had the roast pork banh mi which I was a bit hesitant to get since its priced at $12, but it is a big sandwich and they definitely don't skimp on the meat.  Overall, the food is pretty good and it's very close to my work, so I'll most likely come back.  It'll just hurt my wallet a little every time.  One more thing, I wouldn't recommend the tropical fruit drink with boba.  They're way too sweet.  Save yourself the $4 since you'll already be splurging on the rest of your meal.
author: Elise O.

description: Slow service. Staff handling food and money. Sandwich maker not wearing a hair net. All that for bland pricey for what you get food. Out the door and off my list. Other better choices around. Go elsewhere.
author: bongo c.

description: Incredible jook (chicken rice porridge) so delicious and big portion for a great price! Only complaint was when I get the Vietnamese coffee they only fill the cup half way:(
author: Natalia G.

description:
This place is in the ferry building in the last corner.

Got coffee and milk with boba. I think it was about 3.50$.

The boba is good, a little harder than the usual one I think.

It was good but nothing really special about the boba here.

The good thing about this place was that it was not really sweet. I had so many boba, and this it the first one that it wasn't really too sweet. 

Also, close from the ocean and ferry. So you can drink your boba with a great view! 

Over all ok.
author: R R.

description:
Yes, it's overpriced. Yes, it's pretentious. And yes, the people who work there have major attitude. However, the Hong Kong Milk Tea will change your life - for the better.

Yum.
author: Sarah A.

description:
Expensive for the quality you're getting. The lemongrass pork with rice came out dry. It was tasty but the texture was definitely off. The claypot chicken rice was quite strong in its chili taste and didn't have much to balance against it unlike the lemongrass pork which came with broccoli. 

I think it all tasted okay but $27 for those two dishes to go is a bit much. I like the concept but the execution left more to be desired.
author: Victor W.

description:
My friend had taken me to get boba on a side of the Ferry building I never really ventured too far into. 

Boba!? In the Ferry building!?

Apparently Out the Door has been here all this time serving Asian food and boba, and I didn't even know it existed.

I tried my friend's boba milk tea. The boba was too chewy; almost hard. The milk tea itself wasn't bad, but it wasn't anything to rave about either. 

Intrigued by their actual food offerings, I came back again to try their five-spice chicken sandwich for lunch; which is basically their version of banh mi. The chicken was flavorful and they gave a fair amount of picked carrots and veggies as fillings, but it's still not worth the $10 I paid for it (and it was one of the cheapest things on the menu). 

I know it's the Ferry building and everything's pricier in there (yay tourist destination!), but it's still hard to justify spending that much money on Vietnamese food I can get for a fraction of the cost down the street that also tastes even better.
author: Derick N.

description:
The pork and lemongrass vermicelli was one of the best I've ever had. Considering this is the "food stand" representation of Slanted Door cuisine, I was impressed. The pork didn't have that chargrilled flavor that you usually get, but it was delicious, tender and juicy.
We also tried the pork buns which were really good and very filling. Different from char siu bao in that the bun wasn't as thick and bready, and the pork was less sweet and had bits of maybe scallions in it. The portion of meat inside the bun is quite generous. 

The food comes out within minutes, and service is friendly.  It's right around the corner from the Slanted Door, and across the way is a small kiosk which sells dry goods like noodles, books from the chef, and refrigerated goods like "Mother in laws kimchi"
author: Ed L.

description: Love their chicken buns and everything else is okay. Wouldn't really recommend their boba (doesn't taste like milk tea..maybe not creamy enough?) or soup (not super flavorful).
author: Taryn Q.

description: Still impressed with the service and the quality of food at Out the Door. They have generous servings and their Tofu Dish really delivers!  Love their iced coffee and fresh spring rolls as well.  I like that they have a take away counter as well where you can get the spring roll, veggie bun, peanut sauce, and salads. You can definitely take home their hot dishes and they still taste very good when you get home. Knowledgeable staff. Fast and efficient service. Quick line.
author: Kitty D.

description: I ordered the meatball sandwich. Threw it away after 1 bite. It was raw! You can see the pink in the meat. It almost looks like when you first roll a meatball, that texture. Slimey and not cooked. They may have thrown it in the pan for a quick second but definitely not cooked. Too bad because I love the imperial rolls. Never again. Now my stomach is hurting from eating that. How could you serve meat not cooked. It would be a different story if it was a steak. This is indeed not a steak.
author: Sheena C.

description:
A lot of good vegetarian choices.
We had the vegetarian Curry, the vegetarian Dumplings and the fresh vegetarian spring rolls.
Especially the fresh vegetarian spring rolls are sooooo yummy.
Only bad thing: It's quite expensive.
author: Leonard S.

description:
I had the spring rolls and it has mayonnaise in them. It tasted weird, this is soo odd! Vietnamese spring rolls never comes with mayo. This is why there's a peanut dipping sauce. 

The chicken pho was no where authentic. It tasted more like Chinese style chicken noodles with fried onions in them.
author: Jana N.

description:
We tried two items that were the top 100 things before you die.

Chicken porridge and steamed pork bun. Good, not great. Service wasn't good. They were just behind the counter, not interactive. Inside Ferry Building.
author: Tina N.

description:
Walking through the Ferry Building, we passed by Out the Door. Then I remembered that I had to check out their pork bun.  I ordered a steamed pork bun and it was promptly served up from the bamboo steamer tray to me on a paper take-out tray.

This Vietnamese version of the traditional bbq pork bun was different in that the pork pieces were smaller with a lemongrass flavoring and without the reddish Chinese bbq sauce.  The bun was average in size and filling.  Overall, at $3 ($3.36 with tax), the bun is good, but on the expensive side when you compare it to the traditional bbq pork bun.  (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/out-the-door-san-francisco?select=D6xc0Gq-fbrwlO-gEnLpIw#D6xc0Gq-fbrwlO-gEnLpIw) (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/out-the-door-san-francisco?select=D6xc0Gq-fbrwlO-gEnLpIw#c5oS4ANpRgfXv065VhsHRw)
author: Al L.

description: If you're headed on the ferry and you're hungry, stop here! I love the fresh veggie rolls with peanut sauce. They are so quick to get + very yummy. The mushroom veggie bun is also so good! And the lemon tofu. It is always really quick to get my food and it is a treat. The staff is very friendly, too.
author: Sherry B.

description:
This is a great place within the Ferry Building to grab a bite of food to eat to take outside and sit by the water.  Basically OTD is just a counter where you can order (they accept credit cards) and they will give you a number.  When your order is ready they will call out your number and give you your food to go.  I have only tried the sandwiches.  My favorite is the five spice chicken sandwich.  It has a generous portion of tender chicken, carrots, cucumber, seasoned mayo, and cilantro.  This is mounded into a perfect baguette.  Add a bit of sriracha and you are in business.  

This place is a bit on the pricey side, however it is in prime tourist location and the ingredients are a bit better than your average banh mi place.  

Make sure to grab lots of napkins and grab some packets of sriracha to take with you.  Then go outside and grab a picnic bench and dig in.
author: Paul W.

description:
Though this is slanted door's take away stand, it's still pricey for Vietnamese food.

I tried the chicken bun (because the pork bun was going to take another 10min, even though it was lunch rush hour, so you would think it'd be ready). The bun itself was decent, not bad, but not great.

I really enjoyed the vermicelli bowl with lemongrass pork! I had a bit of my friend's, and it was delicious! This is probably what I'll order next time.

Also, I was pleasantly surprised that this place serves up milk teas and boba in addition to vietnamese iced coffee!
author: Cynthia X.

description: My question is "Why would you go to the Ferry Building to eat Asian food?" I had walked around the Ferry Building and was meeting someone at Blue Bottle. I found this spot next to Blue Bottle and felt like having a meal here. I got the lemongrass pork with rice. The meat was edible and okay. It went well with rice. Came with some broccoli...However, most items on the menu are overpriced by $3. Something that costs $11 should be like 7-8 dollars. The serving was not big. I had an iced coffee with milk and the drink was too full of ice and not enough of the coffee. It was a decent meal but overpriced just because it's at the Ferry Building.
author: Denise C.

description:
I had a lot of Vietnamese friends growing up (hold up--they're all still my friends), and because of them, I've had my fair share of delicious Vietnamese food at rock bottom prices. I get that this is the fast casual version of The Slanted Door, but it was standard Viet food for rather expensive prices.

Don't get me wrong--the food is delicious. The portions aren't as large as what you may be getting at a small mom-and-pop's Vietnamese restaurant. But for its location in a rather touristy area, I understand why the prices are a little high. And I think it's a great gateway for those who have never had Vietnamese food. :)

Oh, but if I could give 5 stars for the iced boba milk tea, I would. Honestly, it's the best milk tea I've ever had. If you like your boba milk teas to taste more like tea and less like milk--this is your place.

TL;DR: Pricey but decent Vietnamese food if you end up in this tourist area. If you've never had Vietnamese food, start here. GET THE ICED BOBA MILK TEA THO.
author: Bettina L.

description: The sandwiches are good, I personally love the grilled five spice chicken w/ jalapeños. I have tried the green tea and milk boba, and the imperial rolls and those are also very good. The food is pretty pricey but what do you expect, at the ferry building especially since it's downtown.
author: Vanessa D.

description: I'm a big fan of Slanted Door and naturally a fan of their fast casual Out the Door connect in the Ferry Building.  Note there is another "Out the Door" on Bush St. which is a sit down restaurant.  I work across the street at 3 Embarcadero Center and like going here if I'm in the mood for Vietnamese (which is always).  The food is great, however it's pricey, but that's given when you're getting food in the Ferry Building.  The best bang for your buck is going to be the chicken noodle soup (chicken pho), which is delicious.  I also recommend the banh mi sandwiches, vermicelli bowls and spring rolls (priciest in SF, but really good).
author: Kevin N.

description:
Been to grab quick Friday afternoon lunch, ordered 5-spice chicken with vermicelli. 
Though there were very few customers, they took looooog time to get our orders. 
Not quite sure why they are soo expensive when the same food with more taste & more quantity can be served by many other Vietnamese places in the financial district area for the cheaper price.
author: Venkat K.

description: Got the special - vegetable curry with jasmine rice, and it tasted meh. Maybe other items on the menu that I didn't try are better, but this place is expensive for a take-out.
author: Maneesh S.

description:
Small sized portions
Quick service
Concise menu

Pork buns over chicken buns
The shrimp vermicelli was fresh and bombbb

Grab to go and eat outside!
author: Riana C.

description:
This is decidedly one of my favorite stops for a snack. I like to think of the Ferry Building as a self-directed food tour and this is an important stop. Get yourself a $3 steamed pork bun and enjoy what a small cost upgrade can get you when it comes to steamed pork bun. This one is light, warm, an bursting with flavor. 

For the vegetarians out there I've heard the veggie buns are good too, but you won't find me trying them when there's access to that succulent meat right alongside!
author: Stephanie T.

description:
Yum!!! This is a delish spot totally a must try if you're in the Ferry Bldg. It's a spin-off of The Slanted Door. It's got a minimal menu but it's got just the right stuff and there are a few gems.

The Thai ices tea is fantastic and I highly recommend trying it as a treat. It's so heavy! But so good. I really like the chicken salad it's refreshing and not too heavy it's a lot of food too! It's deceiving when you think salad. The bun mee is so tasty! I have tried it before and it's definitely filling on it's own. My gf really enjoys the won ton soup. 

It's a place where you pick up and enjoy eating outside somewhere. The price point isn't low and it's what's expected for the Ferry Bldg around $10-12 not cheap! However, I think it's one of your healthier choices in the area. It's a must try at the minimum.
author: Priya S.

description: I ordered the crispy imperial rolls, and they were crispy indeed!  The sauce wasn't as sweet as I usually like, and the flavor of the rolls was decent, but not outstanding.  Didn't think it was worth the price, $10 for only two rolls.
author: Emmeline C.

description:
$6 miso soup cups and $15 spicy tuna rolls at Seaglass Restaurant were giving me headache$ after leaving Exploratorium.

So a fix was in order. Time to strut over to the Ferry Building for some pricier gourmet snack and drink. The drink was what's needed!

No, not Blue Bottle Coffee. The lines looked like the Lord of the Food Trucks or something.

Back to Out The Door, where this was first mentioned. Luckily they were open on a Monday afternoon.

No bao$, no pho, no congee, and no confusion...and no thanks didn't want BOE-BA.

The object of my affection: Hong Kong Milk Tea....$3 a cup.

Brewed to order, so be patient! Felt like 8 minutes or more.

Some say this is a secret blend of 7 types of tea leaves. So what makes it "Hong Kong"? Perhaps the condensed milk, to add a layer of smoothness, plus whatever mystery goodness that goes into it.

So finally with a trip to Hong Kong from earlier this year, I can finally make a comparison.

Out The Door's Hong Kong Milk Tea tastes very different than the run of the mill HK milk tea, even in Hong Kong, or China town.

I've even visited Lan Fong Yuen, the so called birthplace of Hong Kong milk tea, located on 2 Gage Street in Central. Sadly it has become a tourist shrine and the poor service by one waitstaff left a bitter taste with me. 

My photos here: 

https://picasaweb.google.com/101746284683952454145/LanFongYuen#

The milk tea was ok, but strangely I am going to say I'd rather have Out The Door's.

Fast forward 6 years later, now I detect something that tastes like...Jasmine? This is in contrast with the Ceylon, Assam type leaves (and others from Sri Lankan) used in the 3 to 5 leaf blends at the Hong Kong cafes. Different, but still quite wonderful. The heavily slanted Jasmine accent added a great fragrance, not just to the smell, but the taste. Mildly more on the sweeter end, and the whole thing went down real smooth. Plus it was 4 pm. Whether you are on vacation, or slacking, a cup like this is a must.
author: Ken K.

description:
I liked Slanted Door and wasn't sure what to expect from the takeout place, but in the end it's just like any other Vietnamese take out except much more expensive. They're often sold out of things later in the day. 

- Chicken pho (they call it chicken noodle soup) is light and fragrant but not a huge portion. They do give you all the herbs, sprouts, and accompaniments on the side
- Lemongrass pork vermicelli: I initially wanted the five spice chicken one, but of the 5 people behind the counter could tell me if it was chicken breast or thigh.  The vermicelli was the typical vermicelli bowl with fish sauce, sprouts, etc. The pork was good but way too sweet.

Our friends had the Hanoi meatball, which looked good on broken rice.  I knew to expect expensive Vietnamese take out, but I was hoping it would have more of a Slanted Door touch; however, the stuff was got was pretty underwhelming for the price. 

There's a small amount of counter space that you can sit at; I actually prefer the taller tables they have where you can stand and eat.
author: Marilyn T.

description:
I stood in line to try Out the Door's chicken-based porridge, which attracted me because of my pleasant memories of jook (congee) in Hong Kong and elsewhere.  The cashier recommended that I complement my purchase by adding a bun of some kind to my order.  I walked away with a pork bun and a container of porridge, which was quite large by the way.  The tab for the order was $12.xx; I rounded up to $13, thereby leaving a tiny tip at the cash register.

Both items were A-OK.  I didn't think that I was eating the best pork bun of my life or the best porridge of my life.  The porridge, in particular, struck me as a tad more watery than those of my memory.  On the other hand, it was plenty tasty -- I felt that I had eaten a very good lunch.
author: Kenneth R.

description: Anyone rating this restaurant below a 4 probably regulars at Panda Express and thinks that is authentic Asian food. This food stand in the ferry building is outstanding!!! I just came back from Vietnam and the food here was even better. I highly recommend the pork sandwich and the steamed buns.  The papaya salad is a nice add on for some veggies.
author: Dana O.

description:
I was feeling pretty sick and sought out pho but I ended up grabbing lunch here. I was curious about their chicken rice porridge and it's close enough to comforting soup so I got it.

I don't regret buying it. It was really good. They put the right amount of spices and toppings and they give you pieces of bread if you want to put that on top too. The chicken sinks to the bottom so you have to dig it back up. There are bones and huge ginger pieces so watch out for those!

Kind of expensive ($8 something) but it was very comforting and tasty.
author: Sofia R.

description:
When you're at the Ferry Bldg at lunchtime, you should be prepared to splurge and Out the Door is worth it.

The Clay Pot entrees were the best part of my Saigon visit so I opted for that with caramel sauce and it was super tasty.  Bit of a wait, about 5  to 7 minutes, but there is plenty of eye candy to keep you distracted.  Served up piping hot as it should be with decent lunchtime portion size.

My absolute favorite, Golden Star, is about $11 all inclusive for an entree so its only slightly more expensive and lives up to the gourmet stake in the Ferry Bldg.
author: Amy Z.

description:
Nice place for somewhat mild Vietnamese street food.  The steamed buns (chicken and pork) are really excellent.  The roasted meats in the sandwich and the noodle bowls are a bit sweet for my taste, and could have a bit more heat/spice.

Everything is pretty well made and high quality, but maybe it's a bit too fancy to do justice to the food.  The sandwiches are huge, but oddly the noodle bowl is tiny with a huge over abundance of meat and almost no noodles.

Maybe the real point I want to make is that this place lacks a certain elegance.  A really great Vietnamese sandwich place, to me, is able to find a wonderful balance between ingredients, meat, veggies, pate, bread.

Maybe they throw the meat at you in part to help justify the steep prices, not sure, but I suggest giving it a try.
author: Patrick S.

description:
The one weird thing about Out the Door is that they call their pho, Noodle Soup. Maybe it's because for meat options you only have the options of Chicken or Beef (instead of the usual flank steak, brisket, tripe, etc), but let me tell you; their faux pho is pretty dang great.
First of all, ALL of their ingredients are delivered morning of. Which means, that steak you're eating? Yeah it was at a local farm the day before. Same for the chicken. Same for the veggies. You get the idea. 
Secondly, I don't know where their noodles come from, but they're some of the best gluten free noodles i've ever had. And they are gluten free which is neat for all the trendy eaters and allergic s.o.bs.
Thirdly, back to the whole chicken or beef only thing; the chicken and steak taste *great*. Chicken is flavorful and well cooked; tender but not falling apart. Steak is served rare and finishes cooking while you eat. Oh and they don't skimp on the meat!
All in all, its not a bad deal for "noodle soup" that's decidedly less greasy and probably healthier than the usual cash only hole in the wall you (and I) go to. 

tl;dr Noodle soup = pho. Chicken is well cooked and steak is rare (and delicious)..
author: Boris K.

description:
When I visit SF, whcih is my "home away from home", I make sure to drop by Out the Door located at the Ferry Building on Embarcadero.  It's definitely a touristy spot that has a lot of great eateries like Out the Door.  Out the Door is owned by the people of The Slanted Door, but it's more of a casual place to order noodles, porridge, boba, and buns.

I really like the taste of their milk teas.  You can smell and taste the condensed milk they use to create the rich and addicting flavors of the drinks.  The last time I visited, I tried their chicken porridge, which really hit the spot when I was sick and tired of greasy, Western food.  

The people working behind the counter are always polite and work stealthily.  The food isn't the cheapest, especially the steamed buns, but I think for the portion you get, it's not a bad deal.  I'm definitely a fan of Out the Door, especially when I need some comfort food!
author: May W.

description:
Had Lemongrass Pork with rice $11 and Taro Milk Boba $3.5. Total waste of money, time, appetite and calorie count. If it's a litmus test for Slanted Doors, I won't be there to splurge $40 for an entree.

They managed to make the pork dry and tough, as the meat was heavily marinated and (I suppose) stirred fried in bulk, ended up more like steaming or boiling. The rice was obviously overcooked as well. Nothing much to say about the blanched broccoli. Tin in SOMA is far superior in price, portion, quality, environment (being a seat down restaurant); OTD can only win on location.

Taro Milk Boba was pre-made and so watered down with ice. I guess I would get better ones in any random restaurant in Chinatown.
author: Roy C.

description: Decent but not the best I've had.  I felt they lacked a bit of flavor in their food.  And the pricing is a bit ridiculous.  I didn't try their turnip cake but my sister swears by it!  It better be good for how expensive it is!  And customer service.... wait, what customer service?
author: Judy S.

description: We were anticipating an awesome lunch based upon yelp reviews and the constant lines we had seen at the out the door counter. Unfortunately, we were severely disappointed. I had the chicken in a clay pot and my boyfriend had the chicken sandwich. Both would have been amazing,  except that the chicken pieces were gross and disgusting.  If you are picky at all about the pieces of chicken, avoid any dish from there that has the meat. The roll and veggies from the sandwich were fresh and delicious. The rice and flavors of the clay pot sauce were spectacular. We just couldn't bear to pick through and trim the chicken.
