We did recycle and give the meals to a homeless person who I hope enjoyed it...but I'm not sure. Sorry for the bad review, but we didn't want anyone else to have the same experience.
author: Sheila R.

description: First time to the Ferry Building and saw a long line here so had to try it.  I loved my crispy duck but my wife's pork belly sandwich was just ok.  Maybe next time we should try their sit down place Slanted Door which was actually one of my chef brother's go to places while in SF...we're all from Hawaii.
author: Kahai D.

description:
The Chicken Rice Porridge here caught my eye. To be honest, I've never seen this dish offered anywhere else, considering it is normally more of a home-cooked meal. Buying it could be a bit risky, in the case that it wasn't going to be anything amazing. I'm glad they didn't disappoint. :)

They gave a pretty good helping of chicken rice porridge. The special touch in this dish was the slices of ginger (edible and not overly powering), caramelized onions, green onions and other herbs sprinkled on top or throughout the porridge that made it delicious.

Very much worth the price of only $8 and it hit the spot perfectly! Food coma commenced in happiness shortly after ;)
author: Ann V.

description:
One of the reasons why I go to the ferry building is to come here. I absolutely LOVE their Niman Ranch Beef Salad w/orange. Never get anything else because it's so good! The meat's so tender, the fresh greens, the citrus, and jicama sticks for crunch.  A must try!

Their drinks are only ok. The Vietnamese coffee isn't very strong and the Hong Kong Milk Tea is a bit watered down.
author: Kitty K.

description:
Not bad not bad.. I was so tempted to get the meatball bahn-mi or the vietnamese crepe but I saw someone with the sea bass and they really sold me on this b/c it was brand new on the menu and did look delish..

* Steamed Chicken Bun 3.00 - Actually has hearty pieces of meat (rather than a blended ground meat texture), and has a nice savory flavor! Enjoyed it. Chicken could be more tender but still liked it.

* California Sea Bass Vermicelli $11 (w/ fres htumeric, mixed greens, pineapple anchovy sauce, topped w/ crushed, roasted peanuts) - Loved the taste of the sea bass, which must've been sprinkled with lemon juice because it had a really great tart flavor. It also had a slight crisp yet each piece was tender. But there just could have been more of this flavor throughout the dish. There was a tiny isolated pile of crushed peanuts which would have been great had there been more spread out throughout the vermicelli. And speaking of the vermicelli - it was flavorless and got cold and stale pretty quickly.
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I used to come here all the time for weekend breakfast. Duck porridge was a favorite. Coming back after a few years however, I'm quite disappointed by how standards have dropped. Duck porridge is no longer on the menu, and the chicken porridge while acceptable is not as flavorful. There was no white pepper, and the yu tiao (Chinese donuts) that normally.accompany the dish were not available at 1030am. 

We also tried the Hanoi beef noodle soup and found it to be lacking in depth. Fresh roll does a better job on soup with chicken alone!
author: Aman H.

description: Decent place for a nice quick lunch when you are visiting SF and happen to be in the Ferry building during lunch hours. I would't go searching for this place otherwise. Food is worth the money and by money I mean SF money. Of course, you'd get much better food for the same $ elsewhere. Even though they were quite busy, they were flexible with my order and readily substituted rice noodles for rice in one of their menu items. Their mango pudding in the small glass bottle was amazing!
author: Sharanya A.

description:
I love coming here just to get some boba during my breaks at work. We just recently discovered the coffee + boba. It's AMAZING. I feel like I must come here JUST for that from now on.

In terms of food, I had the Vietnamese spring roll. It was okay - but totally not worth it for the price. The food is okay too - I had a banh mi with meatballs, and it wasn't the best.
author: Joanne W.

description: Yikes. If you want to put your entire paycheck towards 3 bites of meat, this place is for you! Let me start by saying, the food is alright, but the price points are absurd.
author: Bradley C.

description: Have tried the pork, chicken, and meatball sandwiches here.  Unfortunately the meat has been really bland each time.  The pickled carrots and bread are decent though.
author: Simon L.

description:
No complaints on their snacky, cherubic pork bun* - although for $3 bucks, couldn't they make it the size of my head?  I, for one, would be down for a gigantic pork bun. 


*liked the fact that the bread-like bun part was not overly dense and there was a good proportion of tasty pork, without the bright pink of cha siu, on the inside.
author: Peg S.

description: Super long lines and the food was well prepared but I wasn't blown away.. it was inline with the price though so if you're in the area for some vietnamese I don't see why not. But it's not a destination. I'd like to try the restaurant.
author: Will D.

description:
Went here for lunch recently and got the chicken rice porridge, steamed pork bun, and coffee milk boba. The porridge was great, lots of flavor and was very filling. The pork bun was small, and also cost $3 which is pretty expensive considering you can get 1 for $0.75 in Chinatown. The coffee milk boba was awesome!

Overall, I'll be back. However, it would be nice if you could order via phone for Pickup. The Yelp listing states that you can call in an order, but when I called today they told me they don't take orders via phone.
author: Anna D.

description:
We stopped here before catching the ferry out of SF a few weeks ago. Becca needed a snack to hold her over, so she got a steamed pork bun and a black tea iced boba. She made me try the bun even though I wasn't hungry,...and I see why,...it was probably one of the best tasting pork buns ever!
The staff were fast, very friendly and helpful. The food was very good. And the prices were very reasonable for the area.
author: Michael H.

description: Went to this take-out in lieu of the Slanted Door...just to see what all the fuss is about. All in all a good experience...the chicken bun was amazing, the lemongrass pork and vermicelli was amazing...but my husband's chicken salad w/ rice noodles was a big ole disappointing heap of bland. The two people next to us had ordered it as well and kept talking about how they would never get it again. You don't go to a Vietnamese restaurant for bland...just saying...
author: Mary Beth L.

description:
MY MOUTH HAS BEEN BLESSED BY THE BASED PORK GODS. 

Gott's line was out the door (no pun intended) so I came here, conveniently across the way. 

I was in the mood for something hearty and warm. The meatball sandwich was on their special's menu so I went for it. 

HOLY.SHIT. 

The pork meatballs were seasoned and cooked to perfection. Juicy, tender and warm pieces of pork with every bite. You can feel the spices moving across your tongue along with the fresh cucumber, pickled carrots and cilantro. Mmmmm, all the elements nuzzled in a toasted French roll will really get your gears going. 

Simply put together yet epiclly rich in flavor. Not heavy or greasy and totally filling....even for a hungry fat girl like myself. 

Total cost: $9.50.
Mouthgasm: Priceless.
author: Lydia L.

description:
Oi troi oi, qua dat! (Good lord, thats a lotta money). I ordered the bun thit nuong (grilled pork in vermicelli noodles) and it came out to be more than I was comfortable with. I just can't help comparing it to every other vietnamese place I've eaten where I would pay less and get more.  

Now sure, this is a classy joint here. They use fresh ingredients. Everything is expensive in the area generally. Its tricky because it's suppose to be higher end but at the same time, authentic and traditional. I'll give it 3.5 stars. Its good food but pricey and wait times can get long for take out.
author: Huy V.

description:
Out the Door at the Ferry Building is pricey, but I do go there sometimes to get food.

I went Sat 3/2/13 and there's a short line.  I ordered a Steamed chicken bun $3 & Hot HK Milk Tea $3.  

The steamed chicken bun is really good & big.  Is pretty filling.  I recommend it.

HK Milk Tea $3 - he said it's hot & I said ok.  Next time I'll ask if they can pour it over some ice because the lid they give u with that cup is Crap, scalded myself on my left hand, wrist got burned & sleeve of my shirt wet.  

Charge it because it's Pricey!
author: Ann L.

description: I really liked this place for a late breakfast early lunch (opens at 10am). All the vegetarian options ranging from the dumplings to the curry were tasty and well cooked. My favorite was the vegetable bun. The bread was perfectly baked and the filling was absolutely tasty.
author: Ato B.

description: I suppose I had super high expectations given its ties to The Slanted Door & its much-touted, elevated Vietnamese fare. I ordered the green papaya salad (served with fish sauce & chopped peanuts) and a daily special of sticky rice with pork, shiitake mushroom, and Chinese sausage wrapped in a banana leaf (also with egg yolk & dried shrimp). While both dishes had some elements of satisfaction (e.g. the texture of the sticky rice was perfect), neither stood out in the way that I was expecting and for $8-$9 each, I was certainly hoping for a bit more differentiation from other similar Vietnamese/Asian fusion options nearby. It also didn't help that I felt sick the rest of the day after eating the pork/sausage in the sticky rice. I will be back to give it another try, but after my first less-than-impressed foray, I will go in with decreased expectations and hopefully will be pleasantly surprised the next go around.
author: Andy L.

description:
Stopped into this outpost of The Slanted Door while in San Francisco this past weekend.  Like some of the other folks who've reviewed this place, my expectation was for small portions, lax service, and high prices.  I ended up batting 1 for 3; the place isn't cheap.  The Vietnamese sandwich, fresh roll, soda, and sparkling water I got came to almost $28.00, but, once I tucked into the spring roll, I really didn't care about the price...I probably would have paid more because, man, it was soooo good.  Granted I had run Bay to Breakers earlier in the day and was hungry enough to consider chewing on my own forearm, so maybe I was a little biased by this point, but, it really was good food.  The portions were big, too...even bordering on enormous.  Service was fast, attentive, and friendly, too....everything I didn't expect.  

It's a pretty big statement to say that, as a foodie visiting a foodie town, one of my best meals during the visit was from a takeaway stand, but it really was the case.  It was great.  So happy I figured out this outpost was there.
author: Matt M.

description: I ordered a meatball sandwich, vegetarian curry and chicken rice soup to go today around 130pm. I received a chicken sandwich, chicken curry and chicken rice soup. The flavors were good, but it would have been nice to receive what I ordered.
author: Natalie S.

description:
SOOOOO disappointed in Out the Door. I had heard so many good things about them that I was eager to try out their food. I had their bahn mi style 5 spice chicken sandwich, which was okay, but nothing special for the $10+ price tag. The wife had a chicken dish described as chicken with potato and carrots in a stew type sauce. That was nearly $14. You automatically know that when you go to a restaurant or any shop in the Ferry Building that you are going to be paying top dollar, so that part did not bother me.

The reason that I can only give them two stars is that my wife's dish was TERRIBLE. First the chicken that was included was two drumsticks, the cheapest and most difficult part of the chicken to eat. The chicken was almost undercooked and did not look appetizing at all. It did not have a lot of flavor either. Then to top it off there was not a single potato in her dish. She didn't even want to eat it, so we ended up sharing my sandwich.

I don't know how they had such a long line when we were there on a Sunday afternoon. In the end it took nearly 20 minutes to order. There are easily dozens of other restaurants in San Francisco that serve better Vietnamese style food - better execution, better value and better flavors. I certainly will not be going back here.
author: Ben B.

description: My favorite lunch place on both weekdays and weekend. Food quality is high and stable, so I won't worry too much if I ever wanted to try something new on their menu - never disappointed. My must-have are lemongrass chicken, chicken porridge,  chicken curry. If you're not hungry, a meat bun with a cup of decent boba milk tea is also a good afternoon treat. Price is relatively high but with this quality, it's worthwhile.
author: Kai-wing B.

description:
Five stars for the congee! 
The rice porridge was the perfect consistency, with plenty of cilantro, green onions, and fried onions to top it off. The pieces of chicken in the porridge were also relatively tender. This lasted me three small breakfast meals. 

Four stars for the fresh shrimp spring roll. I came at the end of the day around 6pm, so it's likely the roll had been sitting out for a while. The rice paper was a bit dry and a few of the pieces fell apart. 

Three stars for the price, but it's to be expected since it is in the Ferry building.
author: Emmalyn C.

description:
This fast casual restaurant is great for having a mid-day meal while visiting the city. You can grab your food and sit outside by the water on the tables or benches.

I ordered the lemongrass pork with rice and vegetables, and it was SCRUMPTIOUS. The pork was not exactly premium quality, but it was so tender and flavorful - sweet and spicy. But the only "veggies" it comes with is broccoli! My friends ordered the noodle soup (which was basically Pho), and although theirs was good, they pretty much attacked my lemongrass pork since it looked so tantalizing.

Out the Door is a bit pricey for the quantity, but it does fill you up. The food is solid and I look forward to coming back for more.
author: Nimish S.

description:
Most frequent complaint you'll read about on "Out the Door": 

- Food is overpriced
- Portion is a bit on the smaller side 
- You can get the same quality in the TL for a cheaper price

You can say all you want but you can't deny the quality and how good the food is!!  Plus it's a fancy Vietnamese restaurant (Slanted Door owned) in the Financial district, so expect to shell out little more money than usual.  

I've had their Lemon Grass Chicken and the 5 Spice Chicken Bowl.  The flavor of the food is indeed as good as what everyone else has advertised.  The real highlight for me though is the Chicken Porridge.  It's probably one of the tastier Chicken Porridge I've had in the San Francisco!! 

Again the price is little bit on the steeper side but it's one of those things you'd have to expect, when dining near the Ferry Building premises or in the financial district.
author: yusai g.

description:
Out the Door is a Vietnamese fusion cafe, branched off of Slanted Door presumably. I only buy two things here, the pork bun and the taro milk tea. Neither is incredible, but it's a cute meal to have when I'm just visiting the Ferry Building. 

The milk tea tastes very fresh with real mashed taro, but they do put a lot of ice which means less milk tea and also freezes the boba, making it harder to chew. The pork bun is huge and not like the traditional ones I have in every other Asian restaurant. The meat is not marinated in the typical char siu style, it is not as overpowering, which I actually like better!
author: Kathy Z.

description:
I am a Deadbeat Girlfriend.
 
Well according to Huffington Post blogger Dr. Alex Benzer anyway.**
 
"Here are the 4 questions of the quick-and-dirty Deadbeat Boyfriend Test, scored on a scale of 0-10, ten being the highest rating:
 
1. How often does he give you backrubs? Rate on frequency and quality.
Backrub is a general idea of liking to serve you and make you feel great.
 
2. How often does he cook for you? Rate on frequency and quality.
Taking you out to dinner is an acceptable substitute -- he can get a maximum score of 7 on that.
 
3. How satisfied are you with the sex?
 
4. How often does he tell you he loves you or otherwise lavish you with praise?"
 
My guy scored in the top range of 34-40 points.  He's a "keeper."
 
But when I gave the quiz to myself, I only got a score of 29-33.  "[H]as potential but needs some brushing up."  OUCH.  I lost major points on #2.  (Actually, I should be given points for NOT cooking.  Seriously.)  
 
But picking up take out should TOTALLY count so I stopped off at Out the Door.
 
I "cooked":
1)  Green Papaya Salad with Slivered Tofu, Pickled Carrots, Rau Ram (Vietnamese herb) and Roasted Peanuts 
2)  Duck Rice Porridge with Fresh Ginger and Chinese Donut  
3)  Shrimp and Pork Wonton Soup with Egg Noodles  
 
The ingredients in all these dishes were extremely fresh, portions were a good size, and prices were in the $8-$10 range.  All good but the Porridge Rice was probably my favorite because I am a fool for duck.  And for donuts.  Also kudos OTD, for packing everything in compostable plastic containers.  
 
Unfortunately, I also "cooked':
4)  Spring Rolls with Shrimp, Sliced Pork, Mint and Peanut Sauce 
 
They looked fine on the outside and the peanut sauce was delicious.  But then I saw that they had MAYONNAISE inside.  WTF?!  It's like lettuce in my pho or deep fried butter.***
 
NOT RIGHT.
 
But at least, I am no longer a Deadbeat Girlfriend.  :)
 
**  Full article here:  http://bit.ly/v3P32
***  I am not making this up!  http://bit.ly/9474S
author: Amy C.

description:
The casual side operation of The Slanted Door.  Great when you don't have a reservation to the more expensive big sister restaurant.

Pretty cheap, and great for a snack.  The steamed buns are just three bucks, and the boba teas are great as well.  

Also had the Vietnamese meatball sandwich.
author: Hieu H.

description: Having grown up in Orange County, I have tried many different milk tea and boba places. However, none have been as much of a waste of time and money as this place. We had a Cà Phê Sa Đá (Vietnamese Iced Coffee) and Green Milk Tea, both of which were extremely underwhelming considering their ~ $4 price tag. The coffee lacked a strong coffee flavor in general, and was ridiculously bitter, whereas the milk tea tasted like a mix of tap water and condensed milk, furthermore their boba had the texture of a soggy crouton. I sincerely hope that their food is better than their drinks.
author: Matt P.

description: We ordered lemongrass pork with rice and chicken with vermicelli thinking the food will be decent since Out The Door is same ownership as Slanted Door. Wrong. The pork is hardened and not fresh, same for the vegetable. Food is barely edible. Very disappointed and will not be back.
author: Maggie Y.

description: Just thought I would try this place since it seemed unique.. what a mistake! The service was terrible. The person taking my order rolled his eyes when I asked what came in the vegetarian sandwich. Once getting my sandwich, it did not taste well at all! I would skip this place. so many better places in the Ferry Building
author: Nikita D.

description:
Holy Noodle Bowls Batman!!! I had no idea this was in the Ferry building and then learning it's a sister restaurant to Slated Door I was so ready to try it! I ordered the lemongrass pork with vermicelli and spring rolls (meat and not fried) and let me tell you I would eat that everyday for as long as I could! It was the perfect balance of flavors and the portions weren't small or large, but a perfect lunch portion. They cut the spring rolls into 3 pieces and you get 2 rolls, so 6 pieces, which is super easy for sharing! The food took a little bit to come out of the kitchen (I work on the 500 block of Market and ran over here to pick lunch up) but not too long where you'd wonder what they could possibly be doing to your food. Just writing this review makes me want to go here tomorrow for lunch!!!

Go, try, get the spring rolls, and don't forget the pork bun (it's looked amazing!)!

You will not regret it.
author: Constance D.

description: Ordered the Chicken Porridge and didn't really want to finish it until i got home and added more Patis (fish sauce).  I've had it before and it was good, but this time, it just didn't go for me.  Maybe it was a bad day?  For some reason, they did seem messier.  I went in around 1:45 pm on a Wednesday so I was thinking it wasn't going to be that busy, but it looked super messy in the front  The cashiers, cooks and Owner? (i'm guessing because he was in casual clothes, no aprons, doing something with the cashier then making food for himself) were ALL over the place, there were just so many people behind the counters.  I wasn't even greeted, no "Hi, what can I get for you" or you know what i'm saying, just a blank stare, but yeah.
author: Joane B.

description: The sandwiches, the rice dishes, the noodle soups, the desserts, the Green tea + milk tea, the scones, the appetizers (especially the rolls) and the hard working folks behind the counter dealing with the crowds everyday in a cheerful manner. I heart them.
author: Joanna T.

description:
The line was pretty long during lunch, I'll definitely try to go early or late next time! I ordered the 5 spice chicken and vermicelli which was tasty but small for $11. My coworker ordered the meatball sandwich and said it was very good, but agreed portions are somewhat small for the price. 

I've had their grapefruit salad from the old location in the mall and that might be my favorite thing on the menu!
author: Rachel E.

description:
My family has a mini-debate going on regarding the validity of expensive fusion Vietnamese food such as Slanted Door, Out the Door, etc. (and btw we are Vietnamese).  My uncle and grandparents are not convinced that expensive Vietnamese food made with fresher ingredients could be much better, whereas my sister absolutely loves Slanted Door for their shaking beef.  I am somewhere in the middle, because I agree that some dishes such as bo luc lac could stand to benefit from better quality ingredients; however, I also would never pay more than $8 for pho.

I was interested in trying Out the Door as a representative of the middle road between cheap Viet restaurants and Slanted Door.  It was okay.  I got the Vietnamese crepe (banh xeo) on the special menu.  The crepe had much more meat and shrimp in it than the banh xeo I am used to eating (both in restaurants and made at home by my family members).  I always remembered banh xeo as being more on the bland side (and that is why we add the fish sauce), but Out the Door's version had much thicker cuts of beef and was saltier.

The main detractor for me was the fact that the crepe was extreeeeemely greasy.  I got it to-go, and the bottom of my to-go box was soaked in grease (see http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/CALxYrt__KaPU-4JA3MvsQ?select=BxRr5DAQ4Cf-UIlGI49_JQ).  The first half of the crepe tasted good, but by the end - with the fish sauce and all the grease - I didn't feel all that great.

The menu is expensive for what you are getting, to be sure.  I also ordered iced chrysanthemum tea, but they gave me lychee tea by accident.  For the wait time and price, I definitely wouldn't recommend going out of your way to eat at Out the Door.  However, if you're already at Ferry Building and just browsing your food options there, Out the Door is a decent option, especially if there isn't a long wait.  If I do come back, I'll probably try something different on the menu though.
author: Amanda N.

description: We ordered from here for a work lunch. We got everything family style. Since we didn't finish it we packed the rest but no one ate any. They were probably too good for left overs. Not me! No way! I was all over the left overs the next day. Breakfast. Snack. Lunch. Delicious!! #noshame
author: Julianna I.

description:
I like Out the Door, but it's a far cry from it's classy big brother, The Slanted Door, and to be honest, doesn't even compare to the discount sandwich shops in Little Saigon.  

 I come here a lot, so it's certainly all 'not bad,' but every time I'm left wanting more.  
-- The steamed buns are a bit dry, and often the filling is cool (not hot)
-- The five-spice chicken sandwich is good, but doesn't compare to Saigon Sandwich or even Lee's in little Saigon (tenderloin).  It's also not spicy or spiced at all, so I had to add flavor by adding hoisin sauce, Siracha, and jalapenos.  
-- The lemongrass chicken / pork is incredibly dry, and doesn't come with any side dishes
-- The spring rolls are probably the best thing, but for $8, it's a pricey starter and too small for a meal
-- The Vietnamese Iced Coffee has far too much condensed milk, and because they pre-make it, it's not possible to special order it to have less.  

What I do like about Out the Door is that the line is short and they provide a buzzer that vibrates when your food is ready, so you don't have to stand around waiting; you can shop or explore while they make your food. 

There is limited seating nearby, but the best thing to do is bring your food out back to eat in the sun outdoors.
author: Greg B.

description:
I've been meaning to try Slanted Door for a while, but haven't found the courage to drop the $$$, so I did a sampling at Out the Door (to-go version) instead. The Ferry Building booth is not as adorably decked out as most other stands, but there is usually a small crowd during lunch hour. There is limited bar seating and a few standing tables. Service is very efficient and everything comes in a to-go container.

I got the Crispy Duck and Green Salad with rice ($12). The cashier warned me that it would take 7-10 min to make, but it probably took closer to 5-7 min. I was pleasantly surprised by the attention to detail in my little to-go box. The green salad comes with a light balsamic vinaigrette dressing and grapes (for your daily fruit intake). The duck wasn't as crispy as I hoped, but it was restaurant-quality meat and not too dry. The rice was topped with green onions, which added an unexpectedly fitting kick of flavor; I'm going to have to try this at home.

Out the Door is slightly pricey, but nothing unheard of for the high quality and thoughtful menu options. The flavors are more Vietnamese than Western, which makes this an fusion-yet-authentic lunch stop.
author: Jessica F.

description: Best spring rolls in the city!!! If you go at lunchtime, be willing to stand or find a table outside.
author: Leah B.

description: They now have a chicken rice porridge with chinese donut, also known as COMFORT FOOD TO THE MAX.  I'm now a fan.
author: Esther S.

description: I feel bad rating them low, because I love the adjacent Slanted Door. I had the vegetarian sandwich twice there, and both times it was bland and greasy, and the fresh spring rolls that I had were also nothing to write home about. I don't think it was too pricey (well, everything in the Ferry building is pricey, but this place is certainly not more so), but it just did not meet (at all) the expectations that I had formed based on my experience with its associated restaurant.
author: H. W.

description:
Quick and great service. The $10 pork sandwich wasn't nearly as good as $5 pork Banh Mi 's that can be found in many other places in the City. 

Great place for tourists.
author: Alvin L.

description: The pork bun was great. But the duck was awful. Tough, dry and rubbery. I have had the lemongrass pork in the past and really enjoyed it, but I was sorry that I ate there this time.
author: Phil S.

description: Lemongrass Pork Bun: Expensive, portions a bit small, and meat was glazed with way too much sugar. Overall I liked the fish sauce over the noodles but I wouldn't return for this item since it's expensive, small, and too sweet.
author: Jess C.

description:
I usually don't have high expectations for tourist traps like the Ferry Building, but the quality of the food at Out the Door surprised me. Not having had anything for lunch except an egg cream at Cowgirl Creamery several hours prior, I dropped by to pick up a pork bun and vegetarian sticky rice for $3 and $5 a piece.

The pork bun was tasty, differing from the usual Chinese BBQ pork bun in that it contained a variety of unique veggies, including what I made out to be water chestnut. The sticky rice was just as delicious, served with the soft sticky white (rather than seasoned brown) rice that I generally associate with dessert sticky rice, not savory ones such as theirs.

Well worth a visit if you're in the area and in need of a quick, filling snack.
author: Johnny W.

description:
I had the Lemon Grass pork with Vermicelli and it was absolutely fantastic. I'm looking forward to trying other stuff. 

It's a food stand, a few counter tops to eat at, but mostly take out.
author: Gabriel B.

description: awesome vegetarian curry and vegetarian fresh spring rolls. The curry sauce is tasty. It was all served up quickly.
author: Richard J.

description: I've only had their fresh spring rolls and Vietnamese iced coffee.  It's overpriced, but delicious! I'm a fan!
author: Tammy T.

description:
It's been awhile since I've been to the far northern end of the Ferry Building.  I walked by Out the Door last Friday on my way to dinner at Slanted Door, where I enjoyed everything that was ordered.

If you're really desperate to grab some Vietnamese in FiDi, I guess Out the Door will do the trick.  However, the wait, portion, price, and overall quality wasn't worth it.  This is definitely not a place I will be adding to my weekly lunch rotation.  I'd rather just go to a hole in the wall in the TL at another time.

I ordered the 5-Spice Chicken w/Vermicelli (dry, over cooked).
author: Marleen C.

description:
I ordered the vegetarian Bahn Mi, and it was ok. 

The french bread was good, but other than that, they were trying too hard. The sandwich had the pickled veggies in it, but they didn't have the normal sweet and sour taste I love. Tt was way too salty and was flavored with something, I don't know what, but it overpowered the whole sandwich. I'm sure they added that flavor to make it gourmet, but it was simply too much and took over the whole sandwich. I much prefer the veggie bahn mi from Fresh Brew Coffee, which is also half the price.

On the other hand, the spring rolls were delicious! Overpriced as you can get the same thing for much cheaper, but I can't deny that they were good. My friend ordered the lemongrass chicken, which she liked.

I personally wouldn't go back; especially for a $9 sandwich that was ok. I didn't hate it, but I can't say I'd order it again.
author: Maleenee B.

description: This place is the lunch takeout version of The Slanted Door and it is right around the corner. Overall I was fairly disappointed; the dishes I got weren't very good and considering the price I wouldn't recommend this place. The daikon rice cake should be crispy on the outside but it was just overly mushy throughout. The duck salad wasn't great either. The duck was alright but the vegetables that came with it were bitter and unappetizing.
author: Kevin T.

description: Warning to vegetarians!:  the vegetarian curry I ordered tasted like it was cooked in chicken broth. Check before ordering.
author: Frank R.

description: Had a 5 spice chicken noodle bowl, when i first got it as a togo order, i was a bit suspect, i looked a bit small and questionable. But when i started to eat it it was really good, the chicken and the noodles were great and the fish sauce just took it over the top.  will defnately try there other stuff during lunch.
author: Anuj C.

description: I'm just more and more disappointed with this place... which is sad, because it's been a regular go-to for me. Their filling has changed... the pork is not as super-awesome as it used to be. The wait can just be so ridiculously long. And last week, my banh mi sandwich tallied up to $11.20 for takeout. FOR JUST A SANDWICH. sigh. Very disappointed.
author: Zoe H.

description:
If you are tired of the same-old lunch food, just come to the ferry building.

If you don't have time to sit down at Slanted Door, you're set.

And honestly, everything from the chicken to the spring rolls are top notch.

five stars for price, convenience and quality. yes, there is cheaper in the embarcadero, but for this price? there is none better.
author: Mike V.

description: I love the steamed chicken buns and green papaya salad here! The chicken is so flavorful and the green papaya salad is so light and refreshing! I just love the crushed peanuts and the crispy delicious shallots! The lines are always so long so try and get here early before the weekday lunch crowds roll in. The food is pricey, but hey, you are in the Ferry Building! On a beautiful day in SF I like to grab my food and sit out by the water.
author: Michelle T.

description: 3.5 stars. Pork bun was amazing, veggie curry just so so. Prices are a little too high, but it IS the Ferry building after all.
author: Stacy G.

description: I stop here every time I'm at the Ferry Building for a hot Hong Kong milk tea with boba. Delicious!
author: Dara M.

description:
My boss brought me here for a celebratory lunch after we saw the insane line at The Slanted Door, as this was the next best thing -- a to-go version of the restaurant.

After overcoming my indecisiveness, I settled on the vegetarian fresh spring rolls and a steamed veggie bun (char siu bao). They make the rolls ahead of time, so they whipped those out from their fridge immediately. The peanut sauce is to die for, but $10 is a little pricey for just 2 rolls. However, if you give it some time, they can be quite filling without another side dish.

I got my steamed bun in a few minutes, and it was nice & hot. I walked off happily, and when I sat down to eat my bun, I bit into it and realized that it WAS NOT VEGETARIAN. I had been given MEAT when I had clarified with them twice that I ordered it as vegetarian. (Minus 1 star here.)

Vegetarians, beware -- make sure to check your food before you leave. Otherwise, the food is of great quality. I might be back to give it another try, just because the rolls were so great.
author: Nidhi K.

description: Soooo freaking good! Perfect menu for the best dishes that The Slanted Door provides. Friendly staff too. I tried the vegetarian spring rolls--which were unreal--and the vegetarian bun (mushroom based). Highly recommend!
author: Ashley C.

description:
Ate fast forgot to take pictures!
Pork buns - amazing flavour
Chicken buns - ditto
Justin scones (only available on the weekend)  ~ pipping hot and lot of stuff inside
Chicken turnover also pipping hot and great flavour 
Beef noodle soup - good quality lean beef
Chick porridge - well seasoned. A little too much cilantro for my taste. 
Black milk tea
Green milk tea

Stuffed to the gills and already thinking about coming back to try the chicken clay pot and daikon cake.
author: Anne L.

description:
During the lunch hour, the Ferry Building gets so congested that you're lucky if you don't get elbowed by indifferent tourists grabbing for the free samples at Recchiuti Chocolates. And I really detest the Euro-trash families in mismatched outfits who stand in the middle of the hall oblivious to the people who need to walk around them. Hello? You're not the center of the universe, comrades.

Tourist density does not improve much at Out the Door, although it is the influx of office drones the dominate the scene here. You can tell because all the Blackberries are all out in force. Invariably you wait in a line here, and the staff becomes surly as a result. Faced with a case of tight-lipped small-mouth, I ordered the $9.50 Crispy Duck special, which came in a little plastic bento box with a bed of rice and some greens underneath.

I bolted from the building the moment I got the food and searched for a place to park my derriere at Justin Herman Plaza behind the ice rink. As it turns out, the duck was a bit lukewarm and the rice rather greasy from sitting in the tray. And is it me or have seagulls become larger lately? Does it reflect an evolutionary process expedited by leftovers from the Ferry Building? I don't know, but I was holding that try so close to my face that I don't know why I bothered getting a fork.

FOOD - 3 stars...lukewarm duck, somewhat overpriced for the tourists...it really ain't the Slanted Door, y'know
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...gee, it's the Ferry Building...ambiance consists of avoiding being trampled
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...surly and robotic...but they gave me a bag
TOTAL - 3 stars...might as well sit down in Slanted Door if you want a decent meal
author: Ed U.

description:
My boyfriend I used to eat at Slanted Door twice a month, then we discovered Out the Door--a good, slightly cheaper alternative.  The food is fresh, light and so delicious!  Our favorites include:

1. Spring rolls - We never get tired of this. Sometimes we walk to the Ferry Building just to get the spring rolls. The peanut dipping sauce has the perfect amount of garlic and spices. I'm salivating just thinking about it. 

2. Lemon grass pork with vermicelli noodles - The pork (marinated in sweet sauce) compliments the pickled vegetables.  I always order this with extra noodles, because they give you so much of the meat.  It's a good problem to have. :)

3. Grilled 5-spice chicken bahn mi (sandwich) - This is my boyfriend's favorite.  He said the chicken is very flavorful and never dry. 

4. Pork bun - In taste and flavor, Out the Door's pork buns are comparable to the ones you can find in Chinatown.   In quality of meat, Out the Door blows its competition out of the water!  They use lean pork pork for the filling, and it doesn't have fatty chunks or chewy ligaments. 

5. Wonton noodle soup - Good broth, decent wontons, but it won't knock your pants off. It's a good rainy day dish. 

The service is not always the best, but you can't expect too much from a place that serves food to-go.  I wouldn't let this deter you from trying the food.  On more than one occasion, we've experienced crappy service (from the same guy), but we keep going back. It's that good!
author: Khristine A.

description:
ROB - for those of you who know the acronym.
$9 for a bahn mi that was a distant third place to saigon sandwich and banhwich.  not a wise use of money.
also $9 for an order of wonton noodles that i saw my neighbor order at the take out counter.
yes, the rent here at the ferry building is high but Puhleaze!
you are better off controlling your urge for vietnamese food for a trip to the tenderloin. 
really not worth it.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Sometimes the simplest things are the most enjoyable.

That simple thing was the most piping hot cup of Oolong I bought at Out the Door.

I took my tea out back into a little cove of benches behind the ferry building and relaxed while my tea cooled off.

Sipping my tea slowly and watching people enjoy their day, particularly the little Brownie selling her Girl Scout cookies from a Red Flyer wagon, the tea was perfectly comforting and very good tasting.  It was really good Oolong. I had never really contemplated that Oolong could be so good tasting.  It was an unexpected delight!

That's a memory that bears repeating.
author: Rebecca B.

description:
Highlights: 
- Jicama and Grapefruit Salad ($8): Red cabbage, candied pecans, and sweet soy dressing. I can't get over how great the dressing accompanies this salad. Pricy, but the sauce makes such a big difference and the mixture of everything provides a fresh and filling lunch. 
- Steamed Pork Bun ($3): The best pork bun EVER! Not like your typical red food colored honey glazed pork buns. This one comes with naturally colored pork accompanied with pickled vegetables and the taste is so fresh/unique. I love it! 
- Order, get a buzzer, and pick up your food. 

Improvements: 
- Chicken Salad and Rice Noodles ($9): It comes with white meat, green cabbage, basil, fried onions, rice noodles, and fish sauce. Nothing unique or spectacular. For the price, I'd rather get the Jicama and grapefruit salad. 
- Vegetable Bun ($3): Clear bean thread, Chinese mushrooms, etc. I wasn't wowed by it and would rather get their pork bun instead for the same price. 

Tip: Remember to check out their daily specials on their board to the right of the cash register.
author: Tracy T.

description: The lines do get long for lunch. Luckily we were at the tail end of the rush and didn't have to wait too long. We had the 5 spice chicken banh mi, 5 spice chicken with vermicelli, and the Vietnamese iced coffee. Everything was good. The staff was helpful as well. I'm allergic to sesame oil and I asked if that was an ingredient they used in the 5 spice chicken. I knew there was still a line behind me, but the staff person took his time to check the recipe binder to make sure. I appreciated this because, you know, anaphylaxis is bad juju. Also, while all my friends' food had already come out, my order was taking a bit longer. The staff person who took my order noticed this and checked on it. Shortly thereafter, my order came out. My tummy appreciated that.
author: Claudine D.

description: Honestly I have only had the spring rolls from out the door, but it's the same as the Slanted Door and they have delicious food so I'm sure the To Go spot does too! But, these spring rolls are phenomenal and fresh. They are big enough to fill you up and they don't skimp on the peanut sauce for dipping. The best part of Out the Door is that if you just want a salad or spring rolls you don't even have to wait in the line... if you turn around they have a 3rd option.. the kiosk sitting along the wall behind you! They have a decent amount of options and it's still really fresh since nothing stays on the shelf long enough to go bad. Not to mention if you walk outside you can enjoy your meal while sitting in the sun with beautiful views of the bay.
author: Brandi B.

description:
This location of Out The Door is a grab and go kind of place. There is limited seating if you really need it, but I don't recommend heading here with plans on sitting there.

Sir Nicholas and I stopped in late one afternoon to grab some food for lunch and it appears they run out of a lot of menu items in the afternoon so I would recommend going early. However, I nabbed the 5 spice chicken vermicelli; Nick and I took it outside by the pier while I waited for Amtrak to take me away and we enjoyed a nice little lunch outside in the sun.

Friendly and fast, this is a nice stop if you're taking a train somewhere, or are just in need of a quick bite in the area. But, the food isn't wowing enough for me to make a special trip here.
author: Tiffany N.

description:
American version of the banh mi.
5 spice chicken sandwich was more like 'little to no' spice chicken sandwich.
No jalapeno on it.
Not a terrible sandwich, but just not the one I thought I'd get.
Hmmm.
$9.50.
Hmmm.
I feel sad.
Hmmm.
author: Kev M.

description:
Really good spring rolls! Probably one of the best I've had. But yes, it's $8. For 2 spring rolls, that's kind of a premium price. I enjoyed every bite though. The peanut dipping sauce was crazy good!

Green papaya salad ($9) was sort of a blah experience. It was a large portion, but it wasn't as flavorful as other papaya salads I've had. I wanted a little more spice. The papaya also didn't taste as fresh as I'd hoped. 

When I come back to the ferry building (because I definitely will!), I wouldn't mind stopping by out the door for some spring rolls! 

I haven't tried their bahn mi so maybe I'd give that a shot as well. 

There's no seating for this place. But we found tables by the door of the marketplace.
author: Junel S.

description: I stopped by this location at the last minute before they closed and tried my first pork Steamed Bun and my usual Springs Rolls.  The food was really fresh and good!  After eating, I wanted another steamed bun but they had closed, despite my pleads to purchase another.  If you are a bottled water fan, I suggest trying the Ty Nant water.  I usually drink Evian because it is light, but this water is just as good.
author: E D.

description:
Its sad this is associated to the Slanted Door which I really enjoy, but this take out in the Ferry Building is just plain below average.  

I have tried their Chicken Salad which was mediocre with too much cabbage, then their Chicken sandwich not that great quality of meat and bread still hard, then today was the ultimate will never go here again....I tried their beef pho.  The rare meat would not cook since the broth was cold.  I took the bowl back let them know the soup was cold, they just cooked the beef and poured some more broth over it and gave it back.  It was still lukewarm.  When I took it back the 2nd time, they asked me if I every ate Pho before and the beef is always rare.  I replied the soup is always hot regardless.  They refunded my money but still not worth that lip service or the food

Mr Phan really whats going on here?
author: May M.

description: I've been craving Indonesian chicken porridge which I have yet to find in SF, and was curious to see chicken rice porridge on Out the Door's menu. Wanting to make sure I am not paying $8 for Chinese porridge, I asked the cashier if the porridge has fish sauce, he said yes so I ordered it. It was Vietnamese porridge indeed - cooked with fish sauce, ginger, chicken, sugar, and pepper and topped with crispy shallots, cilantro, onions, and rau ram. Yum - delicious comfort food!! Portion size was large, too. While I am still looking for Indonesian porridge served with a side of shrimp chips, Out the Door's Vietnamese porridge was a close second. I've been back for the porridge, and it tasted even better with the Chinese donuts (the server forgot to give me Chinese donuts the first time).
author: Diana B.

description:
Now that I've tried it, I'm over it.  Not my cup of tea since I've experienced much better Vietnamese sandwiches.  The flavors were okay.  This is really overpriced food which I'd much rather skip to get something more gourmet.  The place is a little small, and the wait time for sandwiches was too long.

But if you're craving some Vietnamese food on the go, this might be the place for you.
author: Julie C.

description: A bit overpriced for the type of service / environment (e.g. barely anywhere to sit). However, I do like the duck with rice. Yum. Banh mi's should be purchased elsewhere (like the restaurant called Vietnam in North Beach).
author: Margaret R.

description:
(See pic)

Came by to get a "quick" pickup. Got the Vietnamese crepe which was very delicious and the pork bun which was even better (steamy)!

But the wait for the crepe was long. The buns were ready pre-made and kept in the bamboo trays. I think we waited for about 10 to 15 minutes. I felt like ordering at a restaurant, except that I was standing and waiting.
author: T L.

description: This is a great place to grab Asian food in the Ferry Building. Also Out the Door is a much more affordable option than The Slanted Door. The lemon grass chicken with rice is my favorite. The curry chicken is also very good. The food is good, the portions are generous and the prices are reasonable.
author: Jennifer L.

description: There chicken noodle soup is amazing. I wish I could have brought some home. It's a nice comfort food that's healthy and light.
author: Glo C.

description: Really tasty although it's pricey for to-go food. However, that's to be expected since it's inside the ferry building. Can't go wrong with the beef pho - very tasty broth with wider and soft pho noodles than usual. Their rice porridge is fragrant with a nice ginseng flavor. Their tropical boba drinks are really good too. I actually prefer this over their main restaurant - The Slanted door. Recommended if you're in the area.
author: Foodaholic G.

description:
Out the Door is turing into one of my favorite lunch place.  The takeout version of the highly raved Slanted Door offers different selections and price compared to the main dining.  Having dined at their main restaurant Slanted Door (http://www.yelp.com/biz/ZuhygpLHdwsELMWa3Nbymw), I felt that Out the Door is a much better value and is a 'steal' as you get to enjoy quality meal below $10.   

Staff's highly recommended Hanoi beef noodle soup ($7.50) was quite delicious; furthermore, I was impressed that they packed the soup and the noodle in separate containers.  When I first opened the well sealed noodle container, I was surprised that the thinly sliced beef was still raw, but when I poured the hot soup, it became cooked just like shabu-shabu.  It was a noodle dish adjusted to taste buds of non-Vietnamese customers, like me.  There was so much that I couldn't finish it.  

Another takeout that was really good was their Braised pork spare ribs with rice (around $7), which was on special.  Pork on bone came in easy to bite sizes and make it a really nice lunch.  Flavoring was nicely done, although I felt it was a bit strong in flavor like many of their dishes at Slanted Door.

They have other light dishes like green papaya salad and jicama salad.  Note that their counter seating is only for 6-8 people, so you may have to find a place to eat.

Oh, they also have Blue Bottle drip coffee ($2) on their menu.  In about 4 minutes after ordering, I was treated to a nice cup of fresh coffee.
author: トモ T.

description: Portions are small for the price, but I was sorta expecting that in the Ferry Building. The taste is spot-on though. Great flavors and nice, greasy Chinese fritters (for some reason they call them donuts! LOL!)
author: Kat C.

description:
I need to grab something fast before catching the Ferry to Alameda, so when I saw the no line or crowd at this to go establishment, I jumped on the chance to grab some of my favorite dishes from the Slanted Door team. 

I got the clay pot chicken with the broken jasmine rice and the spring rolls.  These dishes made me super happy!  Definitely grab it to go...the few counter seats are just not worth it when it is nice outside.  

Will have to come back again to try some other items.
author: Caesar R.

description:
As if I have not spoiled myself enough recently, I came here for my first real sustenance since my first YEE looking for a simple chicken jook.  I know it's over priced, and I can make it at home, but I really need fresh, simple, and quality ingredients on these recovery days.

I have to say my opinion of this place dropped a little after today.  Dont get me wrong, totally  fresh and high quality.  But just not what I was expecting or looking for exactly.

Maybe it's a personal preference thing.  Maybe it's that I'm trying not tax my system with bold flavors today.  But this jook wasn't the simple delight I was expecting.  Loaded with white pepper, fried onion, raw green onion, cilantro, and large slices of fresh ginger. it was an explosion of flavor.  I like the chicken which was soft and delicious.    I personally thought it was a bit watery and could also have used a bit more rice and cooked a little longer to breakdown the grains.  Props for the slices of fried bread to put in it. Nummy!

They also switch the lettuce in their fresh spring rolls to iceberg (I'm fairly confident it was romaine before.)  I understand the economy sucks and it's a good way to cut costs, but it just isn't as yummy.

I like their selection of food items and it's convenience and will still be going back occasionally.
author: Susan C.

description: Average. I stopped here before heading home after an appointment. I got the vegetarian spring rolls, (which were pre-made), and a very burnt Vietnamese Iced Coffee. My expectations were on the floor, because the Ferry Building caters to a revolving door of hungry tourists. Anyway, nothing to write home about.
author: Erin J.

description:
This place is my new obsession. Fresh, quality Vietnamese-inspired food on the go? YES PLEASE!

All the sandwiches are great, but the pork is my fave, followed closely by the meatball. The chicken salad is also fantastic--super flavorful but light--and, believe it or not, I even enjoyed the very non-Vietnamese scones they were offering. 

If you're expecting this to be like some authentic Little Saigon spot, it's not, What it is, is a great spot for a quick meal or snack in the Embarcadero.
author: Eeeeestar T.

description:
I needed to grab a quick lunch before heading back to the conference so I decided to try this place knowing very well that I couldn't understand all the hype about the food at Slanted Door and was skeptical that this place, which was rather expensive, would be good.  I tried the Saigon sandwich (chicken) and altho' there's a lot of chicken in the sandwich for a pricey $8, it didn't knock my socks off.  (Yup, socks still there).  

My new conference friend joined me for lunch and she got the Vietnamese roll (2 rolls for about $5) and told me she thought the rolls were really good.  I'd be willing to try something else next time but not sure I'd pay those prices, it was $8 for a bowl of congee which is technically diluted rice soup.
author: Ry T.

description:
Beware of the prices for dishes at this restaurant.  I paid $12 for the Chicken Curry, to go, and there was a bunch of rice and two tiny pieces of chicken.  A wing and a tiny leg.  

The food is definitely tasty, but, the price should be $6 for what you get.  The Ferry Building in general is a pricy complex of tasty foods and desserts, but, "Out the Door" is way too expensive for what you receive.  

The fried spring rolls are a whooping $10!

Buyer beware, I mean seriously folks it's just take out food.
author: Jerry H.

description:
I was feeling vegetarian that day, and got the vegetarian steamed bun and steamed vegetarian sticky rice. Both were pretty good. I think Out The Door gets an extra star just for being in the Ferry Building because it's my new favorite place on earth....... :P

OTD gets pretty packed during lunch time because it's a teeny tiny quick-food take-out version of Slanted Door (or so I hear), but they work fast and get people going on their way pretty quickly.
author: Judy L.

description:
Spring rolls and chicken wing appetizers are a must!  Both are so delicious in very different ways.  The spring rolls were just delicious, I am not even sure of all the ingredients besides shrimp, lettuce, clear wrap and pork possibly?  I could not stop eating them.  So fresh and delicious!  The chicken, which I assumed would be spicy since wings usually are, we not spicy at all.  They were a crispy burst of flavor that pretty much melted in your mouth.  YUM!

For my entrée as basic and bland this may sound, I went with the cellophane noodles with chicken, broccoli and mushrooms.  DELICIOUS!  It was the perfect portion to fill me up and not knock me out too.  The noodles were just divine, I could have easily taken a bath in them they were so light and fluffy.  The seasoning was so refreshing too, made for an overall great plate.

I would like to set you up with the size of my party; there were about 16 of us for an hour lunch.  The servers just were not on their game.  They seemed extremely overwhelmed and forgot to bring some items including one of our main plates because he simply "forgot" to put the order into the kitchen.  Nothing horrendous happened, you could just feel their overwhelmed vibes.  

Side Note: I simply went with water for my drink but can I please tell you about one of the most unsettling experiences in the history of my texture-obsessed life?  This by no means affects this review it is just a side note because this place was GREAT!   Others in my party had tapioca tea.  Being a fan of "normal" textures I was not ready for this experience.  I assumed that the tapioca part would be similar to the pudding, which is why I never eat the pudding but it was not like what I expected at all.  First of all it comes with this huge straw in order to suck out the balls.  I got one in mu mouth and I almost projectile shot this gooey little sucker across the room.  It was like a ball of rubber cement and not something I wanted to chew.  So weird!!  The texture caught me so off guard that I can't even tell you about the taste of the tea or anything of that nature.
author: Colleen B.

description:
I went here once because I couldn't actually find the place I wanted to eat at in the farmer's market.  Now I say this because you might think that this was some sort of consolation prize deserving your pity, but no, not really.  The banh mi is really very mediocre, there aren't enough places to actually eat, the food is overpriced, etc etc.  My main issue with Asian fusion is that it always seems like cooks it never actually learned how to cook Asian food properly, so they cobbled together their dish with whatever they could find at a local Walmarts and had the chutzpah to call it high class to gullible hipsters.

This definitely feels like one of those places.
author: Norman S.

description:
I swore off Slanted Door after my last experience and was nervous about going here but I am glad I did. The spring rolls were fresh and good and so were the pork and veggie buns.

I went here as part of a taste tour which I really enjoyed. Check it out! http://inthekitchenwithlisa.com/
author: Sunil R.

description:
I've only been here once and tried the chicken congee and the lemongrass pork with vermicelli to go.  While the prices here are not as egregious as The Slanted Door, they are higher than your average Vietnamese restaurant.  But don't expect traditional renditions of Vietnamese food since the food here is Vietnamese fusion, so it is marketed to people who are used to paying more for their food.

The chicken congee was surprisingly delicious.  They put it in a large tub, that was larger than the regular quart sized containers you would normally get for soups in take out restaurants.  The flavor of the congee is more robust than your average Chinese congee because it had acidity from lemongrass and lime juice.  There are chunks of succulent chicken that settles at the bottom of the container, so remember to scoop some out while you are eating it and add some of the fried dough that accompany the congee on the side.  The finishing touches of fried shallots and cilantro rounded out the congee.  I was a happer camper eating this congee and would highly recommend it to anyone who needs a nice filling porridge for a cold day or if you're feeling under the weather.  I would definitely order this again.

The lemongrass pork with vermicelli was not as fulfilling as the congee.  Contrary to large quantity of congee given with an order, there was less given for this dish.  The ratio between the pork and the vermicelli with salad was off because there wasn't enough vermicelli noodles.  This would probably be sufficient enough for a light meal in case you weren't that hungry. But it's not substantial enough as a sole meal for lunch or dinner.  I probably wouldn't order this the next time I drop by since I didn't love it enough and there are plenty of other things to try out on their menu.
author: Kai C.

description: Flavor flavor flavor!! I live here and can have my pick at a lot of good restaurants . I often sit at the bar here with my sis and chow down. Yes it's a pinch pricey but you're in San Francisco where the bar is set high and the drinks are not watered down. The food here is delish and this place is awesome because you can grab a Blue Bottle Coffee afterward very close by. The Ferry building has excellent food and an awesome farmers market. I love living in SF and the Ferry Building and Slanted Door are a huge plus!
author: Cecilia D.

description: Good food, but super pricey in comparison to other Vietnamese fast food places- $8.50 for a banh mi is ridiculous!! However, their chicken porridge is a great deal for only $8- it can easily feed two people. A good stop if you're looking for a quick meal, but want quality food.
author: Amy D.

description: I had the spring rolls and they were delicious!!! The chicken bun was also yummy! Definitely going back...probably tomorrow when I go to the farmers market :)
author: alex a.

description:
Grapefruit & Jicama Salad: 4 stars
- Surprisingly very tasty for being mostly red cabbage
- Wish there were more than 4 segments of grapefruit though
- Has a kick, but not too much even for a spicy wimp like me

Vegetarian Sticky Rice: 3 stars
- Pretty bland without the sauce even though it was stuffed with mushrooms, but with the sauce it was enjoyable

Green Milk Tea w/ Boba: 5 stars
- Excellent milk tea
- Boba had the perfect balance of soft and chewy consistency

Prices are very reasonable, especially compared to Slanted Door.
author: Amy X.

description: If you don't love this country then get the #$&% "Out the Door." ROFL. Tongues up for the Pork Bun, Shrimp rolls and the Roasted Chicken Sandwich. Oddly, everything was good except the beef on the vermicelli was far from prime cut. If nothing else, this is one helluva refreshing cup of lemonade (with a lime slice).
author: Sean C.

description: I went to this place years ago, but to this day still remember the soup and crave going back. Amazingly good find and delicious, fresh food. Entirely worth a visit and a great take-away lunch to whisk to a bench by the water.
author: Amber L.

description:
NOTE: This review is only for the CHICKEN RICE PORRIDGE.

I was super stoked to try this place since I heard all the great reviews from friends and co-workers-- then I finally came here and was extremely disappointed!

I came here around 1ish on a weekday thinking that it would be empty. NOPE. It was STILL packed. (strike 1)

After waiting for a long time, I finally got to the counter and low and behold-- everything I wanted to try was SOLD OUT. (strike 2)

To be honest, I wanted to try multiple things on the menu, including their sauteed shrimp vermicelli, 5-spice chicken, papaya salad, and spring rolls, but at $8-10/dish, I could NOT afford it! (strike 3)

I finally decided on chicken rice porridge since it looked pretty good and was probably the best deal on there ($8... sigh, my Chinese parents would not be pleased). BAD IDEA. Taste-wise it was sub par and not satisfying whatsoever.  It came with some "Chinese donuts" which got super soggy after a few minutes. The dish itself was bland and the only positive was that the portion was "pretty big," but hey-- for $8 it better be big.

Overall, OTD was too overhyped. The other reviews were right: you can get better Vietnamese food at a fraction of the price.
author: Krystie M.

description:
The name of this restaurant says it all! It should take itself, 'out the door!' This has to be the WORSE Vietnamese food I've EVER tasted!!!!

 I had the spring rolls which tasted like they've been sitting there for a few days. The peanut sauce that came along with it was gross, to say the lease. For my "entree" I ordered the chicken curry and it was surely disappointing! I wouldn't even call it a curry dish, it was mixed between a stew and hints of curry powder. It was NASTY!!!!

The prices here are way too expensive for bad quality food. I would not recommend going here for authentic Vietnamese cuisine. 

I WILL NEVER EAT HERE AGAIN!
author: Anne D.

description:
Slightly pricey food for the portions you receive; I didn't mind since I wanted to try a few things to snack on. The pork steamed bun and vegetarian sticky rice warrants a second visit. Nice iced Vietnamese coffee too.

Nice job, OTD.
author: Bruce M.

description:
I'm PRETTY sure that I got charged $9.50 for an $8.50 sandwich. My hunger must have masked my cognitive reasoning abilities and led me to believe that the extra $1 was justified. Damn you stomach!!

The pork meatball sandwich was delicious, but they charged me extra for it! It was a daily special, so that could have been the reason why.

Anyways, strictly based on the tastiness of the food, this place deserves 4 stars. But $8.50, let alone $9.50, was a lot for the sandwich. It was filled with big chunks of meat with plenty of GARLIC (mmm). The line was daunting, but the wait was not that long. However, one of the employees did call me to the counter with the buzzer before my sandwich was done.
author: Jason T.

description:
I usually see long lines here so I thought it would be a good place to try, WRONG

The pork bun taste like those frozen buns you buy at the Asian supermarket and then steam up.

The milk tea boba was all watered down.

Overall, a disappointing experience, lesson learned.
author: Emmie N.

description:
After scoping out all the places at the Ferry Building, I decided I wanted to try "Out the Door". The 10 minute wait wasn't too bad considering the lunch hour rush, but I was sorely disappointed with my vegetarian curry ($10). 

1. The bag they put it in ripped. (+1 great, sturdy containers)
2. The curry was really watered down. My jasmine rice literally looked like an island floating in the abyss.
3. The curry boasted of sweet potato, carrots, potato, brocolli, cauliflower and tofu which lured me to buy it. Unfortunately, everything was just bland. A girl needs a lil' spice in her life. 

I also ordered a milk green tea with no ice. To be sure, the boba was soft, but the tea was a little too sweet for my taste.
author: Tiffany C.

description: Good and solidly done vietnamese food. Ordered a vermicilli and pork noodle. Good, not great. Be aware of long lines of slow-moving tourists and their families. There is very little seating. So you are required to order take out by necessity. While you are waiting on the long food line, take a moment to glare at the tourists around you in the massively crowded Ferry Building.
author: Susan T.

description:
Who gives this mediocre reviews?  Seriously delicious Asian fusion. I love the sandos, specials and the concept. The drinks are over priced(3.50 for a fancy gingerale) But, I think the food is a great value. 

They have a ginger chicken over broken rice that causes me to..slurp...excuse me...drool.
author: Dusty B.

description: Chicken with vermicelli noodles has ruined me forever because you will compare all others to theirs. Pork buns are good at any time of the day if you are at the ferry building. Jicama salad is also surprisingly delish!
author: Abby H.

description:
I had been in San Francisco all of about 2 hours and after dropping my bag off at my hotel, I headed directly to the Ferry Building. I knew it was going to be a foodie mecca, which always sits well with me, but I only knew that I wanted to hit Blue Bottle for coffee. 

Since it was lunchtime and I hadn't eaten that day, I figured lunch might hit the spot. I'd heard good things about Out The Door, so when I saw that it was right by Blue Bottle, I decided to stand in line and grab something. Unfortunately, since I was so hungry, I got a little more food than I really needed. I tried a pork bun, which I'm so sad to say, I didn't love. I guess I'm not totally into bread-type things and wow, there was a lot of bread. YMMV. BUT, I did very much enjoy the spring rolls with the delicious dipping sauce. Very fresh and totally hit the spot. Even better, I got to sit outside, looking at the water while I chowed down. Lovely first lunch!
author: Renee E.

description: I enjoy the Out the Door locations, though I was not thrilled with my steamed chicken bun I ordered most recently.  I'll stick to the duck dishes and pork buns and their excellent rolls which I have had consistently good results with.  This location is sometimes a bit chaotic at the Ferry Bldg, especially when the weather is nice.  Not one of my top selections in the Ferry Bldg, but they are consistent, offer quality food products, and decent value for what they are (but I wouldn't call them 'cheap').  I will return from time to time.
author: Andy S.

description:
I didn't have the time nor the energy to pack lunch for work.  I was waiting for my cheeseburger to be ready at Taylor's right across anyway.  Plus there's something on the menu that I need to try to cross off another item on my Big Eats SF list:

#87 Fresh spring rolls at Out the Door. 

I've eaten at numerous Vietnamese joints around the bay and I can pretty much say that these rolls are about the same as everybody else's.  Although the size of the prawns on my spring rolls were bigger than I'm used to seeing.  Pair that with thinly sliced pork, vermicelli, lettuce and mint tightly rolled into a rice wrapper.  It was delicious but it would've been boring without the peanut sauce, which is really the stand out in this dish.   The sauce has a nice consistency and has a little kick to it -- which is a nice surprise since I'm used to sweeter versions. 

These spring rolls are a better bet than my work's cafeteria food, but next time, I'd try something else at Out the Door.
author: Janice C.

description: I waited 18 minutes for a spring roll sandwich. C'mon! I was the only customer.
author: Kevin F.

description: I really want to try the food and I will eventually, I swear, but for now I am totally inappropriately in lust with the taro boba! It's creamy creammyyyy in all the right places and you really get a chance to appreciate taro if you don't already do, which you probably don't, but that's ok because I believe in second chances and you should drop the $3.50 for a super delightful taro looove affair.
author: Natasha P.

description:
I just love how reviewers are complaining about OTD's prices *eye roll* The prices are clearly listed; you can check it out before you order & choose to walk away. But people are sucked in by the allure of the popular...their friends have all tried it & you wanna be able to nod your head knowingly & contribute your two cents when the topic of Charles Phan comes up. I get it-- if you're spending double what you would at a more authentic, hole in the wall joint, you expect magic in your mouth...but OTD fails to deliver that level of deliciousness & so you take to yelp to express your disappointment. To that I say-- what did you expect from an Americanized Vietnamese joint made to please the masses located in an SF tourist destination?!

Damn, my rage is outta control today. 

So I've had OTD at Westfield, at food festivals & here at the ferry building... It's always consistently good (not four stars good, but three stars is still admirable!) When I'm eating on the go, I always get the same thing: steamed pork bun if I'm sharing with someone & steamed chicken bun if it's just for me ($3, which is what I got today.) Smeared with a ridiculous amount of hoisin sauce, it tastes the way I  like my buns to taste! I also had a milk tea ($3.50, sans boba) which was not sweet enough. Decent eats for a quick energy boost when shopping at the Saturday farmers market.
author: Fancypants X.

description:
A sunny Spring day means walking down Market St. to the Ferry Building for lunch is a must! 

Anyone who works in the area can tell you how crowded and busy the Ferry Building gets during the weekday lunch hour. I decided to be efficient and call ahead to place an order, but was quickly told that they do not take phone orders. This was disappointing and could have been a missed opportunity.

Braved the line anyway and while it was long, it moved quick enough and we all got through it pretty fast. The men at the counter were very nice and surprisingly calm in all of the chaos. I ordered an iced Vietnamese coffee and asked if they could add more condensed milk than coffee (I can't drink that much coffee!), what a pain I am right? In the middle of the lunch rush, here I am making customized orders! Anyway, I was waiting on the side for my order thinking the coffee comes when the food comes and this man walks up to me with an iced coffee, asks me to have a taste and let him know if it's sweet enough and to the flavor I desired. That was very nice of him and totally not necessary, but thank you so much! They were so busy, I thought this was so kind of him to go out of his way to make sure a customer was happy. The coffee was perfect by the way and it came with crushed ice which is +2183893271 points anywhere!

I ended up trying the rice porridge with chicken, which was ok because it was a little bit gummy. I love this dish because it's so simple and reliable, but Out The Door added a twist with some kind of leafy green that was grassy/lemony (not lemongrass). I will order it without it next time. This is to be expected though because you should know you are coming to Out The Door and not your typical hole in the wall restaurant. Anyway, they definitely dress it up with healthy portions of chicken, veggies, fried garlic and even a little bag of sliced Chinese donut - yum! And of all the rice porridges in the area (excluding Chinatown), they arguably serve the best.

I would definitely say the staff was extremely nice and service here was redeeming, I would come back and brave the line again.
author: Stella C.

description:
I had the best fresh spring rolls I ever had there. I think it was the peanut dipping sauce that didn't really taste too much like peanuts or maybe the pork in the egg roll. I don't know. It was just really good. 

The BBQ pork bun was just okay, hence the 4 stars instead of 5 stars.
author: Hae A.

description:
Yum!

It's California Chinese food. And I don't mean the exact location of Cali, I mean the Cali-Cuisine movement. 

The veggie bun was fantastic. It's not just filled with left-over veggie debris made to feed vegans, but truly tasty morsels of whole mushrooms! It was gorgeous and a delight to eat. The steamed bun bread is on the sweet side--- along the flavor profile of Cantonese dim-sum. That flavor can get a little cloying after one bun. 

Their rice porridge comes in only one flavor: chicken. And it is fantastic. It has a really clean chicken taste and comes topped with loads of scallions and dried shrimpies. The best part is that they give you a bag of little Chinese donut croutons to sprinkle on top. It's so authentic but comes at the steep price of $8. My grandmother would shake a cane at them, but I just smile and eat. Quality ingredients don't come cheap.  

The Niman Ranch beef salad was really, really yummy but a little overcooked for my taste. I loved the sesame and fresh oniony flavor that raced through my mouth with each bite, very aromatic. Mmmmmmm.
author: Lisa Q.

description:
I'm not a big Vietnamese cuisine eater, but after falling in love with Saigon Sandwiches yesterday, I decided to continue my Vietnamese kick with Out the Door's fresh spring rolls with prawns and pork.  

The good news:  I've actually never had a spring roll that wasn't fried, so I was pleasantly surprised by these!  At first, I thought paying $7.50 for 2 spring rolls was a rip off, but they're actually cut up into 6 large pieces and filled me up perfectly.  The prawns were cooked well (not rubbery at all), the pork had a great spice to it, and there was just enough mayo in the roll to keep the ingredients moist.  And how could I forget-- the sweet peanut sauce that accompanied the spring rolls was freaking foodgasmic.  I would buy it by the bottle if I could and pour it over everything!!

The bad news:  I also ordered a Vietnamese iced coffee.  Scratch that, I ordered Vietnamese ice, because there wasn't hardly any coffee in it.  I literally took about 4 sips and it was gone.  Complete rip off for $3.  Maybe if you people didn't overflow the cup with ice, there would be some room for actual liquid in it :( 

Aside from my coffee bitterness, this is a nice place to grab food if you're over near the Embarcadero, and a solid alternative to full sit-down service at its sister restaurant, the Slanted Door.
author: Christy L.

description: It was a quick lunch so here's a quick review.  The sandwiches are good but not worth the price.  Anyone that has had Bahn Mi anywhere knows 9-10 dollars for a sandwich is a rip off.  I get they are using the best ingredients but they taste no better than what you would find in a traditional Bahn Mi shop.  There are far better options in the area for sandwiches not to mention the farmers market nearby.  I will credit them for being very efficient but in the end you're paying for the label and not the quality of the food.  If you're hard up for Bahn Mi and nothing else is close then this is fine but if you can walk 4 blocks to the doughnut shop down the street that sells the same sandwiches I'd go there and save some money.
author: Joco F.

description:
Duck... duck... gone. 

It is impossible to find good duck. 

I ordered the duck over the salad. The duck barely had any meat. The salad was even more bland against the non-existent duck meat.  The rice, was possibly my favorite part of meal, and it was just WHITE RICE.

$11, still unsatisfied.
author: Lisa L.

description:
Well I must say the bar is great .. Fun and chic 
But I wouldn't go for dinner the portions are way too small .. I have a love for art of food and presentation .. But in this  place I would defiantly have something to eat first . We spent $200 for two and my husband have water to drink .. I had two drinks . And felt like I should go somewhere else to eat so I don't get sick .. But I would go to the bar for great drinks and snack again  .. P.S I'm small woman that is always watching what eat ..
author: Noushin N.

description: The best pork bun I have ever had, the filling was excellent.  Veggie spring rolls very so good the filing was very flavorful on its own.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Should be 3.5 stars. Pricey vietnamese food, but it's in the ferry building, what do you expect! You get what you pay for: cleanliness and good ambience, even if you have to eat at one of the standing tables or if you're lucky and can grab one of the 5 bar seats. 

The pho was solid - flavorful and filling. i like their steamed buns too. Not worth the $3 a pop but when I'm in the area and craving a steamed bun it definitely satisfies. The pork is more of the thinly chopped up cha siu pork variety whereas the chicken bun is a big mass of meat. both delicious, but i prefer the chicken bun.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Review only on drinks: 
They pre-make all their drinks. They charge 3.50 for a cup of boba so I thought it would be half decent.

 I wanted to try the green milk tea, but they ran out. So I tried the black milk tea instead. It was bitter, tasted like they left a tea bag in the pitcher all day. I threw away more than half the cup. I should know better than to have tried it here of all places, but I regret it. 

Very bad first impression. Better to have kept this item off the menu!
author: Natasha S.

description:
I like Slanted Door, so on my cousin's Birthday (Hola Fabiola~!), my sister, nephew and I decided to take her to the Ferry Building. It was her first time, so walking around showing her all the places and what to get there was a treat for me.

We decided to come to Out the Door, then take our food outside to enjoy the view and people watch while eating our lunch. 

We ordered the Niman Ranch Steak Salad, Chicken and Vermicelli Noodle Dish and the Won Ton Soup along with a couple Vietnamese Iced Coffees and Lychee Ice Tea to drink.
