The Niman Ranch Steak Salad was good, but the steak was a little dry. The dressing was light, which was not bad - but had to mix some of the dressing they give you with the noodle dish in it. 

The Chicken and Vermicelli Noodle Dish was perfect. My nephew liked this dish the best - the chicken was roasted well and very moist.

The Won Ton Soup was decent, but not the best Won Ton Soup I've had.

The Lychee Tea was great, very refreshing and sweet enough so that you dont need to add a thing. The Vietnamese Iced Coffee was not as memorable for my cousin than ones she had before.

All in all, the food was good, we had a great time and got to spend my lunch hour with my family. Great Day!
author: Rebekah T.

description: I love duck, so I ordered the crispy duck with green salad. It was one of the worst lunches I've had in a long time. There was no seasoning on the duck, no salt even, it seemed. Some of the duck pieces were also quite rubbery. I regretted spending 10+ dollars, when I knew there were other items on the menu that would probably be good.  I had to have a cupcake at Miette to end on an up note.
author: Linda J.

description: This is a great location to go in and grab a quick tasty Vietnamese lunch.  I had the chicken over vermicelli and a ginger ale.  I was such a happy camper!  Order, quickly served, ate, done.  Happy.  :)
author: Maile N.

description: I've passed this place so many times and was also scared to try it because of the line.  I like to enjoy my lunch breaks and not spend the majority in line for food.  (Although that's what you get for buying lunch in the ferry building)  Anyway, the line was finally a decent length so my friend and I decided to try it.  I ordered the Chicken curry and my friend ordered the pork with lemongrass and rice.  Although both smelled very good, my chicken curry was chickenless and the pork was too dry.  I was disappointed but will be up to trying this place out again.
author: Caitlin C.

description:
after seeing out the door on an episode of food network's 'the best thing i ever ate', where they featured the papaya salad, we decided we'd give it try and see whether the palate of a celebrity chef was really as discriminating as one might think.
and, well, it certainly lives up to its stardom.

the salad itself is worth traveling from las vegas for.
fresh, refreshing, delicious.

we'd never dined here before so didn't realize until after we finished eating our "fast food" style lunch at the takeout counter that they had a full service restaurant just around the corner called "the slanted door."
decided we'd check it out on our next trip out to san francisco.

i find myself craving the papaya salad especially on extremely hot, miserable summer days here in vegas.
author: Christina W.

description: Good food, but so expensive! I suppose that's to be expected at the ferry building, but this place really adds up quick. I had the green tea and milk boba, veggie steamed bun, and egg and wonton noodle soup. Yummy things, but not necessarily worth a total of $21. Good for indulging your inner tourist.
author: Eliza D.

description:
I made it a point to check their fresh spring rolls of my list.

$7.50 for an order.  Seriously?!  As an Asian person, I feel completed ripped off.

But at least it was mighty tasty.

Oh, the lychee iced tea is fab.
author: Jenny L.

description:
I came to SF a year ago and my friends took me to this place for dinner! It was great! Everything was so delicious. Their spring rolls are just right!

Last Friday I came to OTD again.  Completely forgot I was there before.  

The service was very good. Excellent food! Coffee is good, tastes like real coffee you can get in restaurants in Europe.

I will return again!
author: Julia G.

description: I think if you don't order the right food, you wouldn't like it here very much. I've tried a lot of things on the menu to say this. The only thing that keeps me coming back is the lemongrass tofu. It's different on weekdays and weekends. Go on a Saturday, the chef seems to be different and he makes is GOOD. My bf isn't a vegetarian and he loves it, every single Saturday he wants this for breakfast and we'd walk about 2 miles for it. Everything else is mehh.
author: May G.

description:
Our final stop of the afternoon was at the Ferry Terminal's incarnation of Out the Door. On walking up, I realized that we'd made a critical error not visiting before: the menu at this location is roughly twice the size of the one at Westfield Centre. And, unfortunately, we're mostly full so we're not exactly going to be able to exploit the larger menu, but Loria wanted to grab another green papaya salad for dinner later. Our coaster buzzed, indicating that our order is ready to go, and I go up to pay and decide to be that obnoxious guy who tacks something on. Fortunately, I was just after some spring rolls, several orders of which were stacked next to the register ready to go.

Back at the room later, we tuck into the crisp, tasty salad. I'm almost glad Out the Door doesn't exist at home because it isn't cheap and I don't possess the self-control necessary to stay away. So I would be destitute. So, lucky for me, right?

The spring rolls were beautiful: a great balance of rice noodles, vegetables, and shrimp with that beautiful mint leaf providing a nice, refreshing lift at the end. Buried in peanut sauce they're even better.
author: Ryan C.

description:
We threw out three out of four dishes we ordered!  Really disappointing.

I had heard really good reviews about the Slanted Door / Out the Door group of restaurants and when a few of us were at the Ferry building at lunchtime, we were excited to try a few dishes from Out the Door.  Unfortunately, the food was pretty horrible.  

We ordered Vegetarian Imperial Rolls, 5-Spice Chicken, and two of the daily specials - a curry dish and a chicken dish.   Of these, the Imperial Rolls were great (as was the iced tea that we had to drink).  However, the other dishes were so unappetizing, we actually threw them out after only a few bites. 

There was a huge line so it took a while to get up to order and then we had to wait for the food to come up.  Because we had ordered separately, the food didn't come up all at once and we ended up trying the curry first. All of us agreed that it had a very bland off taste (hard to describe - kind of reminded me of dish soap).   The curry was so unpleasant, I actually went back up to the counter to ask about it and the girl said the the curry was "supposed to be bland" with a look that suggested that we weren't the first people to have this reaction.  She was friendly and offered to make us some Lemongrass Tofu instead.  

The 5-Spice Chicken came next and did not taste fresh, the sauce was unbalanced, and the chicken had a rubbery texture.  After a few bites, we agreed that it just tasted terrible and having already said something about the curry, we did not want to complain about a second dish and ended up tossing it out.   

Then we tried the Imperial rolls and the chicken dish that was on special.  The chicken special was a stir-fry dish with chilis (I don't recall the exact name).  While not rubbery like the 5-Spice chicken, the special chicken was very greasy and extremely salty.  It had no flavor otherwise.  We ended up throwing this out as well because it was just too greasy to eat. 

We devoured the Vegetarian Imperial Rolls because we were hungry and they were MUCH better than anything else we had tried - crispy with a nice mushroom flavor.

Finally, the Lemongrass Tofu came up (by now it had been over an hour of waiting in line and waiting for food).  This dish was better than the others but still not great.  It was also greasier than other Vietnamese food that I've had and it lacked the nice fresh, clean flavors that I am used to from other restaurants.

I would not go back.
author: R M.

description:
WTF??? This used to be my favorite place to eat! I am stunned by this awful experience.

I went to the to go counter to get a quick bite. There was a clerk there doing *something* I'm not sure what, but she didn't make eye contact and carefully avoided helping me. Then dashed off. A new clerk walked up and starts doing the same thing. Fluffing the straws and stuff. She made eye contact. I was expecting her to help me. yet a couple more minutes pass while she's doing nothing important. Finally she's like "Oh have you been helped?" I say no I've been standing here a while and she knows it. So I place my order.

As she hands the receipt and makes a big circle over the helpful gratuity table at the bottom of the receipt. OBNOXIOUS! They made me wait while they ignored me for 5 minutes and then want a tip. WTF? seriously. It's a togo counter. Their only job is to take orders, and they couldn't be bothered to do that.

Eventually I get my food. It's cold. Perhaps it got cold while it was sitting somewhere because she couldn't be bothered to hand it to me either. But it actually seemed like it had be made a while previously. It was also unusually bland and badly seasoned. I get this same dish every time and it's usually warm and very flavorful (5 spice chicken).  

Also they've raised the price quite a bit since they opened. At 8 bucks it was reasonable. At 10.50 it's pricey for cold chicken that didn't seem to be prepared quickly.

I will try again next time I'm there but I am very unhappy with the experience.
author: vickie j.

description:
I hate when people say "I can get much better [insert ethnic food] in [insert ethnic neighborhood] in [insert bridge & tunnel town] for at least half the price!"  I'm sure that Alabama has some great inexpensive soul food, but I'd no sooner go there for a restaurant than the East Bay!!!  Out The Door serves up hygienic, high quality ingredient and tasty Vietnamese take away with almost all menu items being under $10.  Some menu items are a tad watered down from the authentic version, some spot on and some even better than the original after being jazzed up.

Hanoi Beef Noodle Soup: No choices on beef, just well done eye round and brisket.  I do miss when eye round comes raw so you can get some rare portions as it slowly cooks in the broth.  The noodles are thicker than typical rice vermicelli, kind of like the Northern Vietnamese style.  All the basic greens are included, though they do skimp on the cilantro.  The broth itself has a great beef stock base, but lacks the complex spice (such as star anise) and herb combination found in the better phos throughout the city.

Steamed BBQ Pork Bun: Very strong ginger flavor in the meat.  The sauce is ok, but could have been a bit more BBQy.  The small cubes of pork are perfectly done with a firm exterior, but softer meat inside... often times pork buns have BBQed-beyond-recognition tough pork.  The fresh and chewy bun was probably the most stand out aspect; perfectly executed!
author: Adam B.

description:
I fell asleep Friday night watching "Full Metal Jacket".  Fast forward to Saturday afternoon, and I find myself sitting at Out the Door having lunch.  Power of suggestion?  Perhaps.  Whatever the case is, I have visited this sweet little takeout arm of Slanted Door twice in two weeks, and with or without Stanley Kubrick in my head, I will go again.

My favorite dish so far has been the Duck Rice Porridge.  The warmth and smoothness of the porridge is fortified by the duck meat and brightened by the strong flavors of lemongrass and ginger.  In my opinon, this is a near-perfect dish - absolutely delicious, and the only thing I would change would be to add a little more duck meat.   Even if you manage to get a stool at the counter, get  the take-out container (not the eat-in bowl) - it's one of those heavy, large sized ones that  you can take home and use over and over.   It will make you feel like you got your $7.50 worth if you are worried about that.  Plus, you will only be able to eat about half of this dish unless you are really ravenous.  It comes with a side of this fried bread which is very good.

I have also had the Clay Pot Chicken, which was tasty (although the sauce was a bit salty) - it came with sticky rice with grains that were so small, they were almost like couscous.  These micro-grains had a wonderful texture, and I would love to find that rice to cook at home.  

My Chrysanthemum and Lychee Iced tea was refreshing and a great accompaniment to the richly flavored food.

On my list to try for next time:  Spring Rolls,  Daikon Rice Cakes, and the Nieman Ranch Beef Salad.  

Beware of one thing - on Farmer's Market Saturdays, the customers can be a little bit cutthroat at the counter and especially around those stools, which are a hot commodity.  Remember that guy in Full Metal Jacket that talked to his gun and ended up shooting the sergeant in the bathroom, while Matthew Modine looked on in horror?  Yeah, that kind of cutthroat.  Unfortunately, unlike the soldier-gone-mad, these folks don't have the decency to shoot themselves after they've totally cut you off or taken your seat.  Manners, folks, manners.  It's just food.
author: Liz S.

description:
I don't know why this place is so popular and busy.

To most people who have had authentic Vietnamese food, Out the Door is overpriced and overrated. 

Went for lunch on a weekday. Because of the high volume of customers, the whole experience was pretty sour from start to finish.

After waiting quite a while to even get to order, the guy at the register was definitely cranky and short tempered. 

To top it off they screwed up my order and gave me a rice plate instead of vermicelli bowl. Not exactly what I expect for paying such a markup.

For Vietnamese in FiDi, I'd recommend Sai's or Soup Junkie over this place.
author: Tina G.

description: Eh, the chicken bun I had was mediocre.. And for that price, I could be getting 3 of those monsters at a real dim sum restaurant. I might try their other food next time, but definitely not the buns.
author: Michelle L.

description: This is my third time getting take out here and by far the worst. It's bad enough that you have to wait on a very long line and pay 11 bucks for a bowl of noodles. My friend and I ordered the pork noodle bowl. The overall flavor was good, but the meat was almost inedible. It was more like jerky than the tender pieces of pork I get at any other Vietnamese place at almost half the price.  Don't waste your money, people!
author: Ellyn K.

description: Fantastic steamed BBQ pork buns and beef noodle soup! This is definitely the best fast Asian fusion restaurant that you can find downtown, though the lines are long around lunchtime. The food isn't like what you'd find in the Richmond district but it's still delicious! One thing that I would say is that it is pricey, but that is to be expected in the Ferry Building. The milktea with boba also wasn't too bad, and they have good Thai iced coffee too.
author: Jing L.

description:
I've been giving allot of five star reviews lately. That because I eat good sheet. This joint is no different.

Give me some sriracha and soy sauce!

What a great place to grab some reasonably quick Vietnamese. I went for the lemongrass chicken with cashew nuts (That day's chef's special). At $14 it's a bit steep but the portion size, quality, and taste made it well worth the cost. What wasn't worth it was the $4 coconut water I purchased... Perhaps a Vietnamese iced coffee next time. Price aside, the food comes out timely, taste delicious, and they're located at such an iconic spot. How could you not enjoy?
author: Daniel C.

description:
I was very skeptical of eating at Out the Door since I'm used to eating Vietnamese food at hole-in-the-wall joints in the South Bay, but surprisingly, the food was pretty good. It's a bit on the pricey side -- I mean, who in their right mind would play more than $2.50 for a Vietnamese sandwich? (They're at least $7 here). With this in mind, my friend made me eat here because she knew I wouldn't do it willingly on my own.

I ordered the fresh spring rolls (a.k.a "goi cuon" - $7.50), which were generally good, but the roasted pork was flavorless. Luckily the dipping sauce was really nice and picked up the slack. There were two rolls in the order, but they were longer than usual and were cut into thirds, so i guess $7.50 is a fair price. I also got the 5-spice chicken vermicelli (a.k.a. "bun" - $7), which was also really good, with fresh ingredients, a nice dipping sauce and just enough food for a light lunch.

My friend ordered the green papaya salad, which was nice but a little too tart for me. She also sprang for some chicken buns, which surprised me not only for being tasty, but for having plenty of meat filling with a minimum of bread (usually, it's the other way around).

This sounds like it was a lot of food, but actually it was just the right amount for both of us. I'm not sure if I'll be going back to Out the Door anytime soon, but I'd definitely recommend it to people who want to give it a try (with a caveat about the prices).
author: Arnold G.

description:
past all the distractions luring you with their smells and lines, past the incredulous lines for blue bottle coffee, and voila, some pretty tasty boba is in store for you at the ferry building!

if there's boba, I can't help myself but try it and at out the door, the boba is decent enough for me to go back again. I've had the green tea and milk boba and the black tea boba, and they drink itself is alright, black tea is obviously a bit more bitter than green tea but I like both!
the boba texture is mediocre, too soft and small but there's a healthy dose of boba to liquid ratio which is good.

$3.50 for all of their 6 different boba drinks!
author: Sandra L.

description:
Asian food that don't live up to it prices.... i never thought it would exist...

The only reason i paid this place a visit was because of 7x7 magazine 100 things to try in sf. I got the chicken porridge.  Let me tell you, nothing was special about it, it tasted like any other porridge.However, it cost me twice as much!!!! What the hell?? Are you serious? I paid around 8 dollars for a bowl of porridge i could have made at home...OK, OK.. I am Asian so that is why i can eat porridge anytime and maybe that is why i am a little harsh on this place.

Let me look at it from a non- Asian point of view, i guess? or maybe a person who can't have porridge often. This chicken porridge may be the freshest i have had but still, i don't know if it is worth the money.
author: Daniel L.

description:
I'm going to throw the wet blanket here.  True, the chicken in the vermicelli bowl was oustanding and really flavorful, but the rest of the contents were surprisingly bland and hardly filling for the money.

Reminds me of that Woody Allen joke: "oh, the food was awful and the portions were so small!"  Err... you want *more* crappy tasting food?
author: Laurence W.

description: Solid food; relatively expensive prices.  Quick if you want a bite and don't want the Slanted Door experience.  Wish there was more seating and/or tables.  Wish the lunch hours were longer.
author: Anon M.

description:
I thought my 5-spice chicken sandwich was very average. And I came here really wanting to like it.

The seating is pretty uncomfortable - a couple stools (no backs) at a table next to the ordering line, and near a door that lets in drafts. You're better off bringing your stuff to the tables outside Mijita.
author: Kathleen M.

description:
Pretty hard to find parking here so we took the bus instead. It was a long ride but it would beat finding parking. Followed my friends here didn't know what to expect at all. I looked up to order and the menu was very organized and VERY pricey. I didn't want to get anything since it was expensive but it was w/e. The cashier was really nice though.

I ordered the chicken rice porridge and it was not good at all. You can find porridge else-where for way cheaper and way better. It's probably because my parents makes porridge better that's why I didn't like what I ordered. I tried my best to finish it but the more I ate the worse it tasted. I finished a little over half way and couldn't take it anymore and threw it away, feeling like I wasted 8 bucks just like that. Wasn't my type of place to eat at all but it was with friends so it's all good.
author: Hui L.

description:
Lemongrass pork vermicelli noodles - Quite wonderful.
Spring roll - The one I had at the California Academy of Sciences was a looot better but still pretty good!
author: Ruri S.

description: I think this place is WAY overpriced! $9 for two crispy egg rolls?! We got the pho, papaya salad, and the 5-spice chicken vermicelli. Nothing was impressive and the pho was probably the worst out of all of the dishes we had. It was really bland and had very little meat. Overall it was a disappointment.
author: Twitney L.

description: I had highish hopes because the food people were walking away with looked really good & the descriptions were enticing, but my vegan curry came up pretty far short. It was a clear broth - not what I expected from a "curry" - almost zero flavor, but a little oily. Vegetables seemed pretty fresh & the broken jasmine rice was good... But for the 10 minute wait in line & the bland flavors I ended up with, I was not terribly pleased w/ my selection. Would probably not go back.
author: Abby D.

description:
Walking over to the Ferry Building I expected to get ripped off during my lunch, but man, this place is beyond a rip off. 

Being Vietnamese, I almost felt ashamed even purchasing a banh mi for $9 here. I'm even a little embarrassed that I'm even publishing this over the world wide web for all to read. Yeah the sandwich was good, but damn, for $9 I expect a little more mind blowing to be had during this sammy. 

I definitely won't be returning for a banh mi. I'm very much over this establishment, but I won't let this experience take away from the fact that I still want to try Charles Phan's Slanted Door one of these days.
author: Lisa T.

description:
Really great vietnamese food in the Ferry Building.  A lot of fun to go there for take out during the Farmer's market before you shop for some produce.

Their spring rolls were phenomenal.
author: Chris F.

description: Consistently well prepared dishes here. My favorites are won ton noodle soup and crispy imperial rolls. Go after 1:30pm to avoid lines .....
author: Rex W.

description: Paid over $10 for what I thought would b a great chicken salad. Got it, and there was so little chicken in it and it was mainly a cabbage salad. Dont buy it or dont waste ur money here.
author: Toby V.

description:
FROM A VIETNAMESE P.O.V.
I've been eye-ing the Slanted Door for ages now, curious about their popularity and Vietnamese food... being Vietnamese and growing up around Bolsa/Garden Grove as a kid, I had the best of the best (outside of Vietnam). Thus I'm always a skeptic when it comes to Vietnamese restaurants outside of heavily populated Vietnamese areas.. and especially with the Slanted Door carrying huge price tags and located in the heart of tourism, I had a right.

Regardless.. I was always curious.. so while at the SF Farmer's Market, I stopped by here at Out the Door -- the Slanted Door's cheaper take-out version, and gave it a try. I got the Spring Rolls(goi cuon) that included the traditional pork&shrimp and was accompanied by Peanut Sauce, $7.50 and a cup of Vietnamese Coffee (cafe sua da), $3.. Vietnamese classics.

Besides the food being way over-priced compared to normal Bolsa prices, or any other REAL Vietnamese joint even in SF.. the food was.. aite? Nothing spectacular; not bad, not good.. just aite.. for a lack of a better word. The Coffee had the bitterness to it, but wasn't the same. The peanut sauce was _____, surely missing something.. but I can't name what. If this is what Slanted Door is like, I'll feel safe passing it up now. OTD will suffice for when you can't get Vietnamese anywhere else.

FOR THE NON-VIETNAMESE/American
OTD and the Slanted Door are good introductions to Vietnamese cuisine in a high-class/pricey type of way... If you want REAL GOOD Vietnamese food, keep looking. Otherwise this place is A-OK.
author: Lana N.

description:
Sampled the food here on my first visit to the Ferry Building since I came back to the Bay Area. I'd been hearing much of the Slanted Door and inadvertently happened upon this place, and as most of the stalls were closing shop BF and I decided to grab a quick lunch here as the options seemed the best of the stalls around us.

The grapefruit, red cabbage and jicama salad is superb and inspired me to make my own version at home. Unfortunately the prices mean I will likely be continuing to do that instead of coming back. The steamed spring rolls were bland, certainly nothing compared to decent Vietnamese restaurants.
author: Kit A.

description:
Had to try the last sandwich here, since I already had 2 of the 3 they offer.  I'd have to say, the 5-spiced chicken banh mi is my least favorite.  It says 5-spiced but it lacked in flavor! But I gotta give it to them...the chicken meat was quite generous.  I was expecting cut up pieces of chicken but it came as a big piece for the two halves of the sandwich. Trying to bite through the bread and chicken was a challenge.   

I also tried their black milk tea which wasn't too sweet.  All the times I've stopped by I was helped by the same guy- he gets your order down quick and always so nice.
author: Lisa C.

description: Timing is everything.  Good quick lunch spot if you are shopping in the Ferry Building (especially during Farmers' Market days).  I normally order the Wonton Noodle Soup (clear broth, thin wonton skin - if ordering takeout, request the soup to be put in a separate container), Five Spice Chicken Vermicelli (with fish sauce), or the Curry Chicken with broken rice.  Check out the daily specials board as they sometimes have interesting dishes (halibut, flank steak, short ribs, etc.).  Hard for me to order the pho since Chinatown is only a few blocks away.  Staff is very nice, but orders can get confused if there are long lines.  Check your order before leaving.
author: Mike C.

description: I work near here so this place is pretty much my default go to for lunch.  It's pricey Vietnamese food, but you are getting quality food and great taste.  And besides it's the Ferry Building.  Everything is expensive as it's a tourist trap, but you get what you pay for and what you get here is good food!  Love the Imperial rolls.  It's crispy and they give you a side of lettuce leaves to wrap them in and some vermicelli noodles on the side.  The chicken noodle soup is great for a cold day if you just want some comfort food.  The lemongrass vermicelli bowls are easy to eat and to-go containers - which most dishes are easy to grab and go.  It gets super busy on Tuesdays and Thursdays because of the Farmer's market days.  Usually long lines between 12-1:30pm, but it goes pretty fast.
author: Cindy D.

description:
Tried the spring rolls and the pork bao here - it was good, but nothing super special.  The peanut sauce for the spring rolls was pretty good.

I would still come back, but only if I were already in the ferry building to get other food too - I wouldn't make a trip specifically for this place.
author: Jenna L.

description: Having passed Out the Door many times, I finally tried their Beef Noodle Soup today. I was quite disappointed, unfortunately, to discover that their pho was not very authentic and I've definitely experienced better pho elsewhere at $12 per bowl. There was little meat and the noodles were not very chewy. Definitely disappointed at the quality and makes me wonder about the quality of food at Slanted Doors as well :/
author: Michelle Y.

description: Expensive, quick and tasty.  It wasn't great, the lemongrass pork vermicelli bowl was very greasy and the veggies were wilted.  I'd give it another chance, but wouldn't go out if my way to eat there.
author: Rebecca H.

description:
I only get the Niman Ranch beef salad here. It's really the only thing that's good on the menu. Everything else is bland (porridge) and overpriced (pork bun, spring rolls, etc).

I had a pretty bad experience here last year where the quality of the food plummetted. It was really really bad... the beef was more than 80% fat, and had less than 3 slices; the taro chips were soggy, and the salad tasted old. I promptly wrote them an e-mail of disappointment, and they fully refunded me my money, and it looks like they've been doing more quality checks now.
author: Mari K.

description:
Meh. Looking at the menu choices and the prices, I was expecting some crazy good food. My Chicken Curry was pretty disappointing.

The curry wasn't really curry. It was like, tomato soup. Extremely watery tomato soup with bits of carrots and potatoes, a green onion here or there, and some 2 wimpy pieces of chicken. I don't even think it was a chicken drumstick/thigh. It was more like a baby chick's drumstick/thigh. 

For $11.50+tax, that's just ridiculous. Nothing is cheap on their menu, but I was willing to pay the crazy price because I was craving for curry. Too bad it was nothing like curry. Next time, me and my money are going elsewhere.
author: Florence S.

description: This place always has a line! Luckily they're pretty fast. One of the few places to grab lunch in the ferry building so whenever I'm out grabbing Blue Bottle I occasionally swing by and pick up lunch as well. Based on other yelpers I got the green papaya salad and the chicken and pork steamed buns. They were alright, nothing too outstanding in my opinion! I really disliked the chicken bun for some reason, the pork was way better so get that one if you're deciding between pork and chicken. Green papaya salad was good but I didn't think it was anything out of the norm. I will be coming back to try the chicken porridge, spring rolls, and 5-spice chicken though!
author: Emily C.

description:
Extremely overpriced Vietnamese cuisine. I decided to order one of their three Vietnamese sandwiches, interested in finding out why/how their $8.50 sandwiches are better than other places out there that charge $3.50 or less. The short answer is: they aren't any better at all.

Your sandwich choices are: saigon roast pork, grilled 5-spice chicken, and hoi-an meatball. I opted for the chicken because it sounded really good. In my opinion the flavor of the chicken was only okay, and the bread was way too hard. It's possible to have a soft bread with a crunchy exterior, you know...

Anyway, pass on this place if you have better and/or cheaper options. I'd much rather go a mom 'n' pop vietnamese place to get 3 of their sandwiches for the price of 1 at Out the Door.
author: John C.

description:
As an old fan of The Slanted Door, I've been meaning to come and try this place for a while now. 

You should know, this is not a sit down restaurant. There are 6 counter seats at the location. You can take you food to-go and sit outside where there is a patio with lots of benches and tables around. Most of them are in the sun, so it gets really hot. There are a few shaded tables from the trees or plants nearby though.

Clay pot chicken and rice. YUM! The only complaint I have is they put CILANTRO on top and that hurts me badly. I had to pick it all off. I have this weird allergy to cilantro and I can't eat food that has been cooked with it. If it's sprinkled on top and I can take it off, then that's usually doable. I would rather they ask or not put it on at all.

It's highly overpriced, although the amount of food is decent.
author: Lorrie N.

description:
My usual order is the lemongrass tofu but with this heatwave I needed something cooler. I decided a green tea boba and a beef with orange salad would be perfect and it was. Even though the line was long (the longest I've ever seen it) I had my food in 10 minutes. The beef was perfectly medium rare and the salad was the perfect size. I'm not a boba expert but that was also perfect. Next time I'll try something from the specials board! Today I learned it pays to try something new :)
AND we found seats outside.
author: Sara P.

description:
The line for this place wasn't as crazy or slow as Il Cane Rosso, so already plus points there! Got the chicken porridge, and SO SO DELICIOUS. I don't even get how slushy rice could be so yums. Maybe the chickeny-seasoned soup base they used.

At first I was a little disappointed because it looked like it was just all porridge ($8, expensive!) but then I discovered that all the chicken pieces sank to the bottom (better value for price now)! Also, I'm not sure how this works, but I saved half for later and when I ate it cold later, it was TWICE AS DELICIOUS.

Anyways, would definitely come back here, but maybe when my wallet can take the hit of $8 rice porridge again (still pricey).
author: Melody L.

description:
We stopped here during a recent SF trip. The restaurant serves Vietnamese fusion dishes to go at the Ferry building, making it a good location to grab a quick lunch while you are perusing.

That being said, the prices are a bit steep ($8.99 for a sandwich), and the service was a little slow, it taking about 15 minutes for our food to come out of the kitchen. So, while perhaps not an ideal workday lunch stop, if you have time it is great.

We went with the noodle bowls and were not disappointed. The chicken was fresh, the noodles nice and cool, and the broth it was served with was pleasantly tangy. The lychee ice tea served with it was delicious and refreshing.
author: Jan T.

description:
The GF BF and I were walking off our oyster appetizer and stopped by Out the Door. Immediately the Vietnamese coffee and pork buns special (with gluten free rice flour) caught our eye on the special board and we knew we would be back!

After a lovely little walk around the Embarcadero allowing our oysters to digest, we returned for our snack and OMG, the buns were large steaming puffs of heaven filled with sweet, delicious pork!  And the coffee is really out of this world! Also, love the fact it is so fast and easy with all the same great flavors of the coveted Slanted Door! Delish!
author: Elizabeth A.

description: I had missed the Ferry Building during my last few trips to the Bay Area so I was glad to be able to stop by this go around and grab a quick bite from OTD. I had been to the old Out the Door location at the Westfield and the Slanted Door is a long time fave of mine, so I had a good idea of what to expect - fresh, tasty and quick. I have to say that I was hoping for some newer dishes on the menu, but understand that there are limitations when you have a walk-up restaurant. I'd recommend doing Slanted Door first to get the full flavor and then OTD is a good way to get a quick refresh on those flavors.
author: Steve J.

description: Amazing spot to grab a quick lunch. My personal go-to favorite is the chicken vermicelli bowl and an iced coffee. Everything on the menu is delicious. The only downside is the high prices and the lack of seating.
author: Candice D.

description:
My cousin and I were at Out The Door for lunch on Dec, 10th, and we ordered the Green Papaya salad with 3 other dishes.  As I was eating the Green Papaya salad, I bit onto something very hard and it hurt my teeth.  I spat it out.  To my astonishment, it was a piece of green jade that belonged to a ring.  My cousin looked at it and told me it was a very good piece of jade.  I was very upset over the pain it caused and grateful that I hadn't swallowed it!

I called the waitress over and asked for the manager.  The manager came and took the jade and as I watched, he returned it to the kitchen help who later came up to thank me for turning it in.  The manager later returned, and rewarded us with 2 free dishes.  Big Deal!!!  My cousin was a bit put off by the stinginess of the manager, considering the fright and pain it caused me from that bite!   Luckily, I hadn't swallowed it, nor did it break my teeth!  Thank goodness!
author: L B.

description:
Crutching in San Francisco is a valiant endeavor...if I do say so myself. By the time I arrived at Out the Door, I was panting, covered in sweat, and shaking from fatigue after feeling like I had conquered the gauntlet. 

Food was great. My friend's Cellophane Noodles with Dungeness Crab was probably my favorite. The summer rolls, the beef with leeks, even the broccoli with tofu were pretty fantastic. 

Service was fast, it came with a smile, and for being a mall restaurant, I was pretty satisfied.
author: Monica S.

description:
Out The Door? Sure... Just like my brother says he's "out the door" when in actual fact he's brushing his teeth, showering, filing his taxes, organizing his closet... while the rest of us are waiting impatiently in the car.

Sure you're "Out The Door," but obviously on what my family lovingly dubs "Troy time" as our friend's dish did not arrive until after all 15 of us had completely devoured our meals and were analyzing the bill. We were out the door before his meal even arrived. Peace out (the door).  ...Ok, that's all I got, I promise...

To be honest, this is one of those plot-thinning dining experiences where everything on the menu sounded much better than it came out looking. The few exceptions were the broccoli tofu side dish and the dungeness crab noodle dish, which were two reeeeeeally great exceptions that kept this star ranking hovering above a two. Many of us also enjoyed the fabulous bubble tea and cane soda. 

Would I go back? Potentially. But certainly not if I needed to get out the door in a hurry.
author: Laura N.

description:
I am on the fence about Out the Door. Yes, the food is good...but seriously, did I really just spend close to $15 for banh mi and a drink??!!

It wasn't even exceptional banh mi. For that price the friggin thing should give me compliments and wash my car.

I like the concept - kiosk type service for on the go people. I just can't wrap my wallet around spending close to $9.00 for a banh mi when I can eat 3 of the same thing at a hole-in-the wall Vietnamese joint with sticky floors. I can endure sticky floors to save a few bucks ;)
author: Christy L.

description: The Dish: I got the Lemongrass Chicken and the pork bun (totally $18). They either charge a lot for tax or they jipped me. The food was pretty good, but it definitely wasn't worth the price. With that price, I expected top quality food. Not only was the food not up to my standards, but there was lack of presentation. It was a little better than average. I got the pork bun because many reviewers spoke highly of it. It's good, but I've tasted better.
author: Gina T.

description:
first time here, was just walking around looking for something quick. stopped at out the door (wish i would've just kept going)
this place is super pricey for Asian food, but if your walking around this area you already know. 
I ordered the Vietnamese sandwich with chicken. the small positive was there was a large chunk of chicken in the sandwich. the Negative was the taste or lack of taste. Also the dryness of the sandwich as a whole. It hurt my jaw to chew this sandwich, I would not recommend this for others.

I would never go here again. my friends had the Pho, said it was blahh.
author: Henry C.

description:
+ 
- Chicken Porridge (on the 7x7 list)-  Hearty enough to easily feed two. It's a little different from traditional jook, since they throw in a bunch of spices (roasted garlic, I think?) but it gives it a unique flavor and I'm down with that. All of the chicken sinks to the bottom so make sure to stir it before you eat, or you'll be left with a bowl of chicken with rice topping.
- Imperial Rolls- Can't go wrong with crispy fried rolls!
- Papaya Salad- Standard, nothing too special but refreshing when all your other dishes are on the heavier side.

-
- Saigon Roast Port Sandwich- Wow what a TERRIBLE sandwich. I was expecting similar to banh mi but the flavors were definitely different. The bread and pickled veggies were fine, but my pork was literally 75% fat. I basically had to make my sandwich a veggie one since I had to pull out the majority of the meat.
- Grilled 5 Spice Chicken Sandwich- Another letdown. The chicken was really tough and dry and the sandwich was lacking flavor overall. Would not recommend.

Just took a look at their menu online and holy crap this place is so overpriced! $7 for bok choy to cook at home?! You've gotta be kidding me.
author: Stefi C.

description:
I have to take a break for a second to Yelp about this while I'm eating it for two reasons:

1) I'm feeling THAT passionately about my meal right now.
2) I'm eating everything so darn fast it's going to be gone before I know it. :(

First thing I tried was the vegetarian sticky rice. The mushrooms inside are so meaty that this dish could convince this carnivore to become a vegetarian. The sauce they give is the perfect complement to it.

The next thing I tried was the steamed pork bun. Unfortunately I'm now done feeling like I could be a veg because this thing is so darn amazing. Think claypot pork inside a steamed bun. A huge switch from the generic way pork buns can taste at dim sum places (don't get me wrong, I still love those!). 

I guess the best way to sum it up is that this place is pure quality. 

I actually chose these two things because I didn't want to spend too much on lunch - it came to just over $8 for a wonderful desk-side culinary treat. 

5 stars for the food. 1 star for the guy in the grumpy mood who rang me up and never once made eye contact. But the guy who gave me my food made up for that with his friendly personality.
author: Jen N.

description:
Tasty pork bun and chicken porridge. Too bad the price is on the high side.. for tourist level. I really don't think it's high for San Franciscan. Since the minimum wage at San Francisco already pretty high anyway.

Up to this day, I still fail to see which part of this joint is Viet food. Maybe the prawn and pork spring rolls.. but what else? Where's the pho and the porkchop rice?
author: Yohann S.

description:
I've had better!
My friend loves this place.  I wasn't too much of a fan but the food was good :)
She's been dying for me to try this place so finally I did.  I actually wasn't impressed and the way she talked about it I though I would get so much more :(
The food was just mediocre and I've tasted way better Vietnamese.  I don't know if I'll go back but I finally got a chance to taste it :)
author: Sandra S.

description:
bottom line: a slanted taste, but faster and cheaper. stick with the food.

i opted for the 5 spice chicken + vermicelli and have to say the chicken was done perfectly. everything else tasted fresh and it was a light yet fulfilling meal.  i also got the black pearl tea but the pearls were way too mushy so i wouldn't recommend it. we came a little later so there was no wait, so i'd definitely come back.
author: Aaron T.

description:
My first impression of the name Out The Door: Taco Bell commercial with MC hammer?
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3nYM8z8HuSI

Impression recanted after I tried my favorite bun dish..and thus proclaim this:

Attention Tu Lan #17 lovers: No longer need you brave 6th and mission for awesome bun with bbq pork and imperial rolls!

Don't get me wrong..I don't really mind stepping over crack heads and side stepping knife fights for good vietnamese, but Tu Lan is also a long wait and a long walk from where I work.

The catch, and thus the 4 stars instead of 5: The bun with pork is $9. And the side of imperial rolls...$9 as well! A die hard like me had to have both, but had to go hungry for a day to save up.

Also I they forgot my iced coffee and fork at first, not a big deal because the coffee was legit. I was almost too wired to speak at an after lunch meeting.
author: Casey D.

description:
Yes, this place is overpriced for what you get.  However, it is in the Ferry Building and frequented by FiDi lunch crowd.  It is on par with all of the other overpriced places in the FiDi.  

I had the spiced chicken sandwich.  It was pretty good, but there were pieces of chicken that were not recognizable to me.  Yuck!
The bread was good.  If you do not like cilantro do not order this--the stuff is piled high inside!  I added hot sauce because I felt the sandwich needed something.
author: Katharine A.

description:
WHY!?!  Why isn't there boba near my work!  From all the great reviews I've heard about the spring rolls here and food in general at Slanted Door, I was expecting something really satisfying when I ordered their taro milk tea...meeh.... It tasted like milky tree :( ... like bark-y...?  (no, not like a dog...)  Ok, given taro is a leafy...root veggie...it shouldn't taste like freakin tree....

I hear their black(?) milk tea is better but...I've heard alot of things already and I'm nervous to pay up and be disappointed again.  :(  I'll just have to stick with froyo @ YoCup.  :P
author: Kat C.

description:
Fresh Vietnamese to go. Nice ingredients but 5 Spice Chicken is nothing to write home about. The Imperial Rolls were well crisped and I enjoyed wrapping them up in lettuce but not really all that great. 

Pedestrian Vietnamese food for a decent, quick lunch. Nothing spectacular, nothing too bad.
author: Rajiv S.

description:
On beautiful days like this, I enjoy taking walks along the Embarcadero - also its close by my office - and stopping into the ferry building.

My friend raved about Out The Door awhile back, and I have been stopping by there ever since. They offer many of the favorites from The Slanted Door's menu and its especially convenient when you don't have the time to sit down. 

A couple of my favorites are the green papaya salad and the Saigon roasted pork sandwich. The green papaya salad is fresh and great on warm days. The pork sandwich is delicious - carrots, cucumbers, pork, cilantro, and a mayo spread. Only downside is that its a little too much for me, I think there have only been a couple times where I have finished the whole thing in one sitting. I have also tried the spring rolls, lemon grass chicken and rice, and the buns - all amazing as well! 

I only knock off a star because it is a little pricey - it is the ferry building so everything is a little more expensive. Definitely stop by if you are on the Embarcadero. Be sure to sit outside as you are enjoying your lunch :)
author: Stephanie C.

description:
Horrible service. Waited about 20 minutes after we sat down for the waiter to come by. I asked if the corn appetizer was vegan. Waiter curtly said no, but if I really wanted it to be, he could tell the chef to do something special. If the chef wasn't busy.

Appetizers and entrees arrive AT THE SAME TIME. Waiter just sets them down without a word.

5 minutes later (before we're even finished eating), waiter deposits the check on our table.

Food was hella greasy, too.
author: Is K.

description:
This Vietnamese fusion restaurant is located in the ferry building.  Slanted Door is one of the most popular restaurants there and I wanted to give it a shot.  I came for a late lunch, however, and it was closed.  Out the door is a to-go place that serves some of the dishes at Slanted door in bento boxes.

I had their pork bun, lemongrass pork vermicelli noodles, and lychee drink w/ boba.  

LEMONGRASS NOODLES W/ PORK:  The vermicelli noodles were delicious.  They chop the lemongrass up and mix it in with the noodles.  That gave them a really nice, spiced up flavor.  Unfortunately, I didn't like the meat too much.  It was covered in an adobo sauce that gave it kind of a mild spice.  In my opinion, this sauce was not necessary and it didn't work.  If you get this dish, definitely don't forget to use the fish sauce (the sauce in that plastic container) and mix it up real good with the lettuce (at the bottom of the bowl) and the noodles.  This dish was okay, but it isn't worth $9.  

PORK BUN: This is a steamed bun that's filled with pork.  The pork is like something you'd find in the middle of a dumpling at a dim sum place.  It's perfectly cooked and very tasty.  I just don't feel like it's worth $3.

LYCHEE DRINK W/ BOBA:  I recommend this.  Strong, distinct lychee flavor.  It's sweet and the boba is nice and soft.  

Overall, the food here is pretty flavorful.  As can be expected in any fusion place, some of it works and some of it just doesn't.  It's worth a try, but just know that it's twice what you'd pay at any Vietnamese restaurant. 

This review is part of my "AWESOME SF DAYTRIP" list.  Check my profile to see my other recommendations.
author: Ken C.

description:
This goes for the Powell SF Shopping Mall and Ferry Building Restaurants. 

Their Wonton noodle soup. A+
Their milk tea. A+
Their Vietnamese sandwich. A+

That is all.
author: Jason W.

description:
All I've ever had and all I will ever get at Out the Door are the chicken humbow. Every time I go I have two for lunch and get two to go for the lunch the next day. They always taste the same: Delicious! Just like how my mom makes them. Quick, easy and inexpensive. 

I only WISH they would open a South Bay location. Santana Row seems like a perfect fit if anyone there is reading this :D
author: Stacie T.

description: The bread of the chicken sandwich is sharper than my teeth, and cut my lip.
author: Ning L.

description: DISAPPOINTING!  Crispy Duck over rice was not tender and juicy.. hard to eat.. too much rice not enough duck. The duck wasn't rendered properly so the fat layer between the meat and skin was still there. The tropical fruit boba was ok but the boba was hard. The pricing on such mediocre food is apalling. I could walk into chinatown.. order 4 plates of rice with roasted duck on top and 4 boba drink and still have enough to buy 4 crepes and 4 coffees.SMH!!!!
author: Bobby T.

description: I love my OTD's, Bush Street being my favorite and it kills me to have to give this place a 3. Yes I love most of their food, but I can say, the roasted duck and salad, was far from being favorite. It was pretty much a dry, anorexic pice of duck that required tons of chewing and gnawing. You would think that OTD has solid dishes across the board, which it has as I live and die by their pho and chicken porridge and their buns...and their spring rolls and their imperial rolls... so this just didn't live up to their gold standard. Anyways, I hope they can find some juicier duck in the near future - and then I'll have no prob turning it up to my usual 4 or 5. Gotta love their pho though. Hangover or no hangover.
author: Jessica C.

description: Slanted Door, but faster and cheaper? Can't beat that! Tried the 5-spice chicken w/ vermicelli, and it came w/ a tangy vinaigrette (which I added siracha chili sauce to), light and tasty w/ some green onions, shredded lettuce and cucumber. Sat out front at a picnic table in the sun looking out at Coit Tower. Perfect lunch spot on a perfect sunny SF day!
author: Amber E.

description:
The only thing that I like here are the steamed pork buns and the mango pudding...
Other things I've tried were unimpressive, bland..
The end...
author: Elektra T.

description:
**this review is only for the jam across from Out the Door**

Sampled the Blueberry lemon jam and fresh strawberry jam in the Ferry building today. A couple of the BEST jams I've ever had. EVER.

I looked at the menu for Out the Door and it was pretty darn expensive. However, next time I'm in the ferry building, I'll try their boba milk tea - i'm a sucker for them.
author: Julia K.

description:
Their spring rolls are delicious!  I had the chicken vermicelli and I thought it was just ok.  
My friend had the rice plate and it looked a lot better.  I think I prefer dining at Slanted Door more. Out the Door seems just ok to me.
author: AhLin C.

description: I loved the vietnamese sandwiches. Excellent ingredients and very convenient for lunch.
author: Guillermo M.

description:
Two words: overrated and overpriced.

I don't know what the hype is about Out The Door. I've given it two chances and so far, I haven't been impressed. I've had their Hanoi beef noodle soup, chicken rice porridge, and 5-spice chicken with vermicelli. Honestly, you can get the beef noodle soup and chicken vermicelli at any Vietnamese restaurant and it'll taste just as good (if not better and more authentic) for a fraction of the price. The soup was tasty enough but there wasn't enough of it for me to eat the noodles with. The chicken rice porridge (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/CALxYrt__KaPU-4JA3MvsQ?userid=5bmpGbzPd-gfcUl6o5j7FQ) is a little different than the Chinese congee I'm used to. It was flavourful but tasted oddly sweet to me - not the comfort food I was looking for. Maybe they're trying to cater more to the American palate. The Chinese donut that comes with it is stale. It's supposed to be crispy so that when you soak them in the congee they soften up. I'd just walk 10 to Chinatown and get some cheap congee there. 

Also, $3 for a steamed bun is ridiculous! Just go to Chinatown and get a giant baked/steamed BBQ pork bun (or steamed veggie/chicken bun, since that's what they have on their menu) for $1. I'm also sure that any of the Vietnamese sandwich shops on Polk will serve a better sandwich for $4 than the ones they charge $8.5 here for.

One last pet peeve is their so-called "Hong Kong milk tea". For the record, real HK-style milk tea is made with evaporated milk, not sweetened condensed milk. Not only do they not make it properly, they have the audacity to charge $3 for that cup of crap. (I know the misuse of condensed milk is an issue in most of the Bay Area, this is the only place I've seen that actually calls it HK-style in the menu... AND charge you a ridiculous price)

All in all, if you're looking for authentic, reasonably-priced, and tasty Vietnamese food, go to Chinatown or the TL.
author: Steph L.

description: Out the Door might be old news now, but I'm still a fan of Phan. Salt and Pepper Squid is excellent. So are the Pork Spareribs. Ambiance is pretty amazing with great views out to the Bay. It's a little busy and crowded to make it a great date night venue, but it's really good for entertaining clients or work colleagues.
author: Paul V.

description:
all i had was congee. hugo and wendy recommended it and RAVED about it.

i really wanted to hate it, but they really do a good job and the congee was cooked perfectly, and the ginger was a great touch.

it's so hard for me to love expensive chinese food, but i was pleasantly surprised.  don't know that i'd go back for it, but if you want that chinese craving with high quality ingredients (i.e. not chinatown), this is a legit spot.
author: Eric L.

description: Expensive Vietnamese Food to-go.  That's pretty much says it all.  I have to give them credit though, they helped me get through a sick day at work from their chicken rice noodle soup.  Pricey at $8.50, but I felt so much better after eating it.  I haven't tried their Banh Mi here because I refuse to pay more than $5 for a Vietnamese Sandwich, I don't care how fresh the ingredients are.  I was also a little disappointed that they don't take phone orders since it can take a while to get your order when you order at the counter.  I have yet to try The Slanted Door, though I'm assuming that the food is much better inside than at Out The Door.
author: Rodney H.

description:
Of late, there's been a noticeable inattentiveness to the food and service at the Slanted Door, and I've been loathe to remark upon it via update to that review.

I am pleased to note that the congees at Out The Door will likely revive the near-dead.  I was definitely one of the walking dead earlier this week, and attribute my return to a surprisingly generous portion of chicken congee.  The four huge slabs of ginger were life-giving.
author: Mutant O.

description:
We were planning on going to the Slanted Door on the other side, but the bar was full and the wait was about an hour long for lunch (on a Saturday). No thanks. Maybe some other time. So we headed back to this little To Go joint for lunch instead.

I had the duck porridge. It was really tasty, like ducky flavored tasty. With crispy fried dough on top, my favorite! About $10, which is pretty pricey, but it was definitely enough for two...I ate the whole thing and was really full...

My boyfriend had the pork vermicelli and loved it. He wished they had some kind of tangy sauce with it though.

All in all, it's quick and pretty good. I like this place. I'll probably go back again to try the pho. Be warned that this is pretty pricey Vietnamese food.
author: Angela H.

description:
Chicken curry + green papaya salad = Twenty two United States Dollars. There is something wrong with this equation.

Chicken: a leg and a thigh. Inconvenient, unwieldy. Should've been chopped up into smaller pieces. Curry: tomato flavored tinge, watery, unremarkable. Those words should never be used to describe curry. Rice:  broken rice, which is traditional, but somehow ours had a weird texture, like couscous to it. My friend didn't even finish his.

Green papaya salad: Very green, very salad-like, very papaya-y. However, tasted like crunchy cool cucumber with fried egg and peanuts. Not bad...until you realized that it cost you SEVEN DOLLARS. I ate 1/3 of it and composted the rest.

Will not come back. My own mistake of trying to eat higher end Asian food. I think I will stick with the hole in the walls. Like the pho shop that I went to right after, where I got stuffed full for $5.
author: Emily H.

description:
One of my favorite places to go, along with Acme, at Embarcadero.  Yes, it is expensive, but you're worth it!

The food:
1) Chicken Bun:  A mouthwatering chicken filling inside a light, fluffy bun.  Well, the bun isn't always light and fluffy, but when it's perfect, it's perfect.  This is so much better than the minced meat filling and tough bun that I usually have elsewhere.
2) Pork Bun:  Much like the chicken bun, but with a savory, fatty pork filling.  Also one of my favorites here.
3) Vegetable Bun:  Unless you're a vegetarian, I would recommend skipping this.  It's good and has a filling of noodles, sliced mushrooms, and other veggies, but the chicken and pork buns are so much better.
4) Vietnamese Sandwich (banh mi): A luxurious amount of meat combined with a nice balance of vegetables (pickled carrots, cucumber, cilantro) inside a crispy baguette roll.  I prefer the grilled 5-spice chicken sandwich over the Saigon roast pork sandwich which has very large amounts of fat.  Overall, a nice alternative to your typical Vietnamese sandwiches to enjoy once in a while.

I haven't tried their spring rolls yet, but if the peanut sauce that comes with it is anything like the peanut sauce at it's sister company, The Sliding Door, then buy those spring rolls and eat that sauce!
author: Joe G.

description:
Order the Fresh Spring Rolls and ask them to hold the pork. They will make you a fresh roll right on the spot and you can taste the shrimp and mint better without the pork. The peanut dipping sauce is amazingly tasty. 

Get this and a black milk tea with pearls and you are set. 

I would give it 5 stars, but it's a bit pricey, just coming in under $14.
author: annie s.

description: *Sigh* I was really let down by you Out the Door.  I loved eating dinner at your flagship restaurant and at your twin sister on Fillmore.  Of course, now that I'm a new resident in your area, I figured it'd be awesome to try out lunch at Out the Door.  The last few weeks I've been absolutely OBSESSED with Bun Mee's Lemongrass Pork Bun bowl.  Naturally, when I saw the same item on the menu, I absolutely went for it!  After taking two bites into the pork, it was completely overcooked.  My pork was tough, dry, and lacked a lot flavor.  For $8.50, I expected to be blown out of this world, especially since Bun Mee's bowl is cheaper.  I hardly had any noodles, and the flavor of the nuoc cham didn't have enough garlic in it.  The vegetables that were in there were fairly standard, so really it came down to overcooked pork in my bowl.  This just wasn't worth the amount of time spent and the money paid.  Next time I'm going to take my money down to my usual spot, Delica, in the Ferry Building.
author: Lisa I.

description:
Extremely overpriced!  Yes it's located in the ferry building and it is located right off the water, but it's not worth paying $20 bucks for a vietnamese crepe and lemonade.  Paying triple the normal price is not worth it at all!

Is the food any better than any other normal asian place in a normal asian neighborhood.  HELLLL NO.

If you really are craving vietnamese food and you want to have a scenic view while while you're eating, then I guess you can go here!
author: Edwyn D.

description:
I think I can qualify myself as a boba tea addict since I've moved in California and discovered this magical drink at Loving Hut (in Palo Alto, CA). However as I live in San Francisco, going all the way to Palo Alto for a boba tea is a definitely expensive and very time consuming ride.

I'm glad that I've discovered Out of the Door today as they do offer what I was looking for so long and that only Loving Hut was able to offer to me in Palo alto: a not sweet boba tea in San Francisco!

Apart from the boba experience and since this place is Vietnamese I've tried their Sprint rolls and they were good. I'm less an expert on this food than I am on pearl tea so I will just say that is was tasty, fresh and that I will definitely go back when I would like some more. This place is also in a great location of the city!

(Btw, if you do are a pearl tea addict and do know a better place than Out of the Door in San Francisco, please get in touch with me and let me know!)

==============================

Pros:
- Probably the best boba/pearl tea in San Francisco!
- Line went fast

Cons:
- Very limited seating. However since this place is located inside the Ferry building, it is actually better to take your food to go and enjoyed it outside, with a nice view on the Bay Bridge.
author: Cedric L.

description:
Went there today after the Breast Cancer Walk to get an early lunch. I ordered a roast pork sandwich and it was awful. I love me some banh mi but this was dry and flavorless. After trying to choke it down I gave up.

I was starving so I ordered a green papaya salad and some spring rolls to share with another person in our party figuring they should be fairly safe and . . . the spring rolls were decent. Not great, but decent. I didn't care for the sauce that they served with it -- it was not nearly as flavorful as the sauce I've gotten at every other Vietnamese restaurant, the hundreds of times I've ordered this dish at the scores of other Vietnamese restaurants I've been to -- but it wasn't awful.

The green papaya salad was awful. It was dry and what little dressing it did have was flavorless. To make matters worse, the green papaya was woody, tough and flavorless. I suspect it was maybe too "green" to use.

My niece said the broth of her Pho was "decent".

So, all in all, it was pretty awful. I would definitely NOT go back to this place.  I've been to the Slanted Door many times (though, not for a few years) and always enjoyed it but this spinoff isn't worth the money -- even if the food were free.
author: Patricia G.

description:
Working nearby, Out the Door is my go-to spot for somewhat healthy, fresh Asian food.  I am always slightly unnerved by how much more expensive it is than other Asian places and how the food never quite lives up to the price, but it's decent and I chalk the prices up to the Ferry Building location and the supposed effort they exert in sourcing local, sustainable veggies and meats.

But today, I had a beef pho dish that bordered on disgusting.  The beef broth had almost no flavor.  The flavor in the beef (uncommonly fatty, dull brisket and rare beef) also seemed to have been leached out by boiling.  A good broth will give flavor to the raw bean sprouts and noodles, which add crunch and texture, respectively.  But here, the naturally flavorless ingredients just enhanced the overall grossness of the dish.  I felt like I was eating thick, smooth, tasteless noodle chunks (yes, the noodles had broken up into chunks, making it impossible to eat with chopsticks) with raw bean sprouts, floating in warm water.

I have had decent meals from here, even decent pho, but I almost never think the food is worth what you pay, especially considering the awesome, affordable options you can enjoy in almost any other part of SF outside of downtown.  For the price you pay here, the food really should be more consistent.
author: Pearl L.

description:
Dear owners of Out the Door, the man with the shaved head who works the cash register is a jerk.  Every time I'm waiting in line about to order, I break into a sweat for fear that I will have to interact with him.  If, God forbid, he does have to take my order, he acts like he can't be bothered, won't make eye contact, and when I refuse to tip him based on his attitude he either a.) circles the tip line on the receipt and makes a snide comment under his breath, or b.) reaches down and moves the tip jar in front of me.  I swear he's talking smack about me in another language.  

Here's the thing: I would tip these guys if he weren't working the counter!  The rest of the staff are very sweet and make delicious food.  This guy is a total tip nazi and will NEVER be tipped because he's so horrible to deal with.  It's a vicious cycle.

I've been going to Out the Door since it opened and I'm really torn about this.  I love the food, but I leave every time thinking that this guy has spit in my soup.  

Why does the man with no hair hate us so much?  With so many sweet and lovely people out there who would give their left arm for that job, why is the grumpy man working your counter?
author: Peppermint Paddy W.

description:
Pork chop with vermicelli ($9.5)--Good portion of pork, and tasted good, but too little vermicelli.
Vegetable bun ($3)--good

Boba black milk tea--Excellent!!  My favorite place to get bubble tea.
I'll give it 5 stars if it's a bubble tea place.
author: Elena L.

description:
Yes, this place is a tourist trap and yes, it is not exactly an authentic Vietnamese restaurant but I come to this place for convienence. Terrible service and the waiting is kinda long, but on a brighter note, their food and their drinks (milk teas) are actually a lot better than the other location (SOMA).  

If you're on a go and want a quick eat, then this place is not too bad. I come here from time to time on Saturday mornings ( Farmers Market).
author: Clementine D.

description: Best passion fruit boba tea I've ever had, but as for the pork bun and my beef noodle soup, a huge meh. I didn't like the musty flavor of the pork bun, and the beef soup had a strange flavor to it as well. Maybe I was expecting the soup to taste like those Japanese Noodle bowls I'm used to. The chicken empanada is a 4, just wish they would serve it warm, but alas they serve it cold. The filling is tasty and the pastry is super flaky and delicious.
author: Dawn J.

description:
The steamed vegetarian bun was okay but I would not buy it again.

The steamed sticky rice was tasty but I've had better versions elsewhere.

I've eaten other things here and everything I've tried is okay, but this is SF and better food is available.
author: Jolie S.

description: I had the vegetarian sticky rice in tea leaf.  It was spot on and excellent!  I've not had a vegetarian one before and theirs was filling, and delicious - I could have eaten two of them!  But again, these are filling.  I would definitely be back to order this again.  I may try other menu items as well next time.  At 5.00, it is a bit pricier than going to chinatown, but slanted door/out the door are known to price on the higher end, and it's nice to be able to eat everything in the tea leaf without picking out the bits of meat.
author: Bebe W.

description: BEST spring rolls ever!  Shrimp, sliced pork, rice noodles, lettuces, etc.  This is the fourth time I have stopped for some in the past year and they are always outstanding!  An amazing and healthy lunch for $8.  I have tried three other meals and they were also great.  The only thing I was marginal on was the pork buns - ok, just not amazing...
author: Christa N.

description: I love the jicama/cabbage/graprefruit salad and that I can get it to go, stars.  Today I caved to temptation, and $8.50 roasted pork bahn mi.  Would it be worth it.  I would say yes.  Very generous portion of meat in this sando, nothing like your typical $3.50 sando.  More like 5 spiced pork, not the bbq variety I know and love.  I love the pickled veg and would have loved more of them in the sandwich.  That said, it was stuffed to brim with filling and a hefty lunch.  I'd go back for another, definitely.
author: Donna H.

description:
Went here with my bestie and enjoyed a delightful lunch outside by the ocean. 

We shared a copious amount of food that included: Fresh Spring Rolls ($7.50), Crispy Vegetarian Imperial Rolls ($8.50), and a Niman Beef Salad w/ Orange Dressing ($9.50). We added two fancy bottled sodas to the order and it came out to a whopping $35!! Pricey lunch if you ask me! But it was definitely delicious.

Would definitely recommend it for a lovely lunch at the Ferry Building!

In fact. we wrote about it on our food blog: http://nomists.com/2010/08/20/out-the-door-and-into-the-sun/
author: Lauren F.

description:
I crave the wonton and noodle soup here. It's salty, full of carbohydrates, and delicious. We normally head over here to lunch on the later side, about 1:30ish, to avoid the Ferry Building lunchtime crowds. The line for Out the Door normally takes about 5-10 minutes and then you have to hover for a seat at the bar (there are only six). I've never gone though and not been able to get a seat. 

I highly recommend this!
author: Briana G.

description: Most delicious special treat for lunch! Although the line can get kind of crazy and you have to wait with a beeper to get your food, I enjoyed every single bite! Delicious sauces and flavors! Definitely going back on my lunch break!
author: Melanie R.

description: Not sure why I keep coming back here for lunch. The portion is a tad smaller and cost nearly double from my usual Vietnamese joint but its convenient. I usually order the pork or chicken vermicelli noodles ($10.50) and green or black tea boba ($3.50). A little over $15 after tax. Not a cheap lunch but the ingredients are fresh and overall pretty yummy!
author: Anne T.

description:
Curse you OTD!

I try something, hate it, swear I'll never come back...
Then I come back, try something else, love it...
Come back again, try a new item, then hate it!

I give up...
author: Burrito M.

description:
Out the Door is my go to place for black tea boba and pork buns. Their imperial rolls are also delicious, and my boyfriend is obsessed with the coffee boba. 

I generally try and avoid going when the farmer's market is open (Tuesday, Thursday, Saturday) because the line can get long. However, when I get a craving (which is at least once a week), I don't mind facing the line or the tourists.

The service is always fast - if you order the pork buns you usually get them right away.
author: Ranee B.

description: Waited 45 min for a sandwich and it was the same as any other Vietnamese place. If you're gonna wait might as well go to a better place in ferry building.
author: T N.

description:
I went back to Out the Door with my Mom about a week ago and the food was fabulous. We had delicious shrimp and vegetable rolls and the delicious papaya salad. The shrimp and vegetable rolls were fresh and absolutely divine! 
In all, it's on the pricy side, but these dishes were really yummy - perfectly seasoned and flavored!
author: Writer G.

description:
Lychee/Chrysanthemum  iced tea!!! SOOOOOOO YUMMY!!! 

Their milk tea is actually really good too!
author: Jen D.

description: I live near by and go here at least once a week. I am a big fan of the chicken porridge, chicken and noodle salad, spring rolls and imperial rolls. Their sandwhiches, pork and wonton noodle soup and rice dishes are also great.  Actually, everything here is damn good.  The food is a little pricey for Vietnamese food, but I am more than willing to pay the extra cost for quality of ingredients and convenience. Of all the great spots in the Ferry Bldg, this is the place I frequent the most.
author: Grant L.

description: Pretty much like any other SF Asian restaurant: overpriced for decent quality. I ordered the beef noodle soup which was more Vietnamese pho style + big chunks of meat, only the price was $12. I'm pretty bitter since I can get something way better in San Jose for nearly half the price. Also since I ordered this to go eating out of the plastic container was difficult leading me tohave a lot of soup spots ending up on my shirt =\.
author: phil c.

description:
When you crave the Slanted Door's delicacies, but don't have the time to have a sit down lunch or dinner, check out OUT THE DOOR!

They offer an abbreviated Slanted Door menu, highlighting some of the real deal's best items. My absolute fav is Sauteed Shrimp Vermicelli. If you love shrimp, this is your dish!

I'm also a fan of their spring rolls and chicken buns! So yummy!
author: Lauren T.

description: Had the sticky rice, a chicken bun, and (quite possibly the most delicious thing I ever tasted) walnut cheesecake for lunch. Perfect.
author: Robert M.

description:
I've never been to Slanted Door but my friend told me this is the "take-out" version of the swank Vietnamese Fusion restaurant. I want to give them 3.5 stars, but that's not possible so I thought I would round down. 

I ordered the chicken porridge ($8) and my friend had the shrimp vermicelli ($9.50 i think?). both dishes were very good. HOWEVER, i am repeating Jenny L's comment....as an Asian person, this is a complete rip off!! You can get the same quality stuff at a real Asian place for probably $3-4 less. But....it is the Ferry Building so I guess you're paying for ambiance.

You can either grab a seat at the counter (very limited seating) or stand at a table. We stood around eating, which wasn't that bad. I like how they use biodegradable utensils and bowls. This is a first for Asians...but i guess if they are charging us $8 for a bowl of porridge they better damn well give us eco-friendly ware.
author: Jen C.

description:
On a weekend visit to SF, we found ourselves on a beautiful Saturday morning at the Ferry Plaza Farmers Market. As we were just about to leave to go back to our hotel, my wife gets in line for gelato. Off the corner of my eye, I see this place - Slanted Door or Slanted Door Outlet, Express, whatever. 

I walked over and thought it would be absolutely hilarious if I got a sandwich and put it in my pocket (since they were the long-size sandwiches) to eat later. We had already turned the Market into our personal buffet so we were fully stuffed. 

As I order the roast pork sandwich, the guy taking my order asks, "Is it okay that it has Paté?" I wasn't sure whether to do a Three Stooges slap on him or reach over and kiss him. I guess you can classify that as the stupidest question that made me so happy. 

So, I get a sandwich, put in my pocket and I meet my wife. We get into a cab and she looks down and sees this huge bulge in my pants. Next to the bulge was the sandwich and of course we busted out laughing with the "happy to see me" jokes but really, that's just how I roll (get it? sandwich? roll?)!

So I get back to the hotel, pull the sandwich out of my pocket and take a bite. I literally said out loud, "ARE YOU FRICKIN' KIDDING ME? THIS IS A PARTY IN MOUTH!" This roast pork sandwich was seriously the best thing I ate all weekend in SF!

I took one bite, wrapped it up, and went back to bed (we were seriously hungover). About 20 minutes later, another bite, and this went on all afternoon until the party that came from the bulge in my pants was all gone. 

What a party it was!!
author: Tom S.

description: After reading a number of reviews both good and bad, I have to agree with both.  Good, the spring and steamed pork roll were tasty and would recommend.  Bad, we also got the beef noodle soup which did not have the depth of flavor I would have thought.  The five spiced chicken vermicelli was dry, like it had been cooked in the morning and left sitting.   There is very limited seating and a swarm of people in the Ferry Building on a Saturday which makes for uncomfortable dining.  For take out, it was expensive and difficult to find a place to eat.
author: tom s.

description:
Overpriced Asian food. 

Yes, I get that they probably use organic veggies but it's just a bit hard to swallow (figuratively).  I've had quite a few items on their menu and dined at Slanted Door as well.  It's a 4 star restaurant but I had to minus half a point because it's too pricey considering it's Asian food.  

However, on the up side, it's the only place that serves decent milk tea in the Ferry Building.  Their green milk tea hit the spot yesterday when it was so freakin hot in SF.  After standing in line outside in the blazing sun for 30+ minutes for my porshetta sandwich, and then inhaling it, I was craving for an iced cold milk tea.  This was the dialogue between me and the worker at Out the Door:  

worker:  Hi, can I help you?
me:  Hi. Yes. I'd like two iced milk teas please. One with boba and one without. 
worker:  Do you want black tea or green tea?
me:  Black for both please.
worker:  We're out of black. 
me:  Ok then green is fine.

I just thought it was so funny how we went in a circle.  He could have just told me "We're out of black tea is green okay?" right after I told him my order.  But then again, the workers are all really young so I'm sure it was a learning experience for him too.  For the record, the green milk tea was quite delish.
author: Connie W.

description: Talk about expensive porridge man !  Most places would charge $5.50-$6 bucks for porridge to go.. but $8 ?... better be some damn good porridge... and it was!!  The Chicken porridge tasted authentic and had defenite "substance" not just water and rice but had big chunks of chicken in it and also ingrediants did taste very fresh.  Also I love their Vietnamese Ice Coffee as well.
author: Margie C.

description:
Ok, here's what you do...and don't say I never did anything for you...dig?

Go on a Saturday, around 4:45 pm or so.  

Order something scrumptious.

Eat slowly.

Do this, and you will (maybe) be happily rewarded with free delicious treats.  

You see, when they close at 5 pm, the nicest young gal will (maybe/probably/hopefully) offer you some of the desserts left in the case!  FREE!  MY FAVORITE WORD!

Since they are closed on Sunday, I am assuming that they do not keep the treats for later sale.  At least I hope they wouldn't...yucky two-day old mango panna cotta?  Bleah.

But end-of-the-day-free sticky rice with coconut milk and papaya dessert?  

WOO!

Aherm...send me thank you cards...it's only polite.
author: Kristina R.

description:
What a great idea for Slanted Door to have a take out window! The prices are reasonable too.  They have the BEST BEST BEST BEST BEST shrimpy spring rolls, especially dumped in the bomb spicy peanut sauce.  AWESOME!!!

NOT OPEN ON SUNDAYS, SO DON'T BOTHER COMING ALL THE WAY DOWN HERE LIKE I DID. FAAAAAAAAWK!!!
author: Rick H.

description:
