Today I had lunch with two friends and prospective employers in the Ferry Building. We talked about old times, business and designer clothes. You know, typical conversation for three straight men. A thought approached me as we enjoyed the beautiful day. HOLY SHIT, the women who work around Embarcadero are SMOKING HOT! No lie. I must have turned my head 50 times to catch a glimpse of a curving neck or exposed leg in perpetual motion. I WANT TO WORK HERE!

The food at Out the Door itself is fairly pedestrian. It's not good, but it's not bad either. The same could pretty much describe most of the Ferry Building in my opinion. It's like a very beautiful woman who knows she can get by on her looks alone, without much substance. But HOT DAMN, it's nice to look at on a daily basis.

As my job search continues, I feel drawn to destinations around SF. The people seem industrious and resolute, astute without being arrogant. Or maybe we're all just megalomaniacs with something to prove. Such talk probably won't get me a second interview though. 

Dang, I almost forgot this is a Yelp review. 3 stars for Out the Door.
author: John T.

description: Food still very good, but the prices keep going up.  Perhaps rents are too, but I am starting to wonder if there's much value for the dollar here.
author: Jane D.

description:
$7.00 for Chicken Rice Soup. 
Of course they forget to tell you it's minus the chicken.
$7.00 for Rice soup.
Fast service for $7.00 Rice soup.
Rice soup doesn't = Chicken Rice soup.
Did I mention there wasn't really any Chicken in the Chicken Rice soup?
It was the most delicious non-Chicken Chicken Rice soup.
author: Aim E.

description:
Pop quiz hotshot - where can you go to get a fantastic meal with a little more than an hour to go before a movie?  Out the Door!  

Located next to the food court but world's away when it comes to atmosphere and service, the Westfield Center's outpost of Out the Door serves up some tasty Vietnamese food with style. Our beers were cold, our noodles hot and our waitress pierced.  What more could you ask for? Ok, maybe not spending $25 a person for a quick bite.  But you definitely pay for quality and I'd happily pay it again the next time I'm hankerin' for some pre movie chow.
author: phil h.

description:
Overpriced Vietnamese food. Some dishes are more reasonable than others. It is the FiDi, after all. In a normal situation, 3 stars max. Location is nice. When we want a lunch spot outside, this is where we'll head. 

So why 4 stars? It is soft foods friendly! The braces are on. I look like Fugly Betty, and the teeth are in quite a bit of pain. The day after I got them put in, I could only swallow rice - no chicken or veggies. I wanted to call my mom crying!

The 5-Spice Chicken & Vermicelli is perfect. The chicken is tender and flavorful enough. The vermicelli is soft. They sprinkle peanuts on top, which might get stuck in your teeth - you can just brush that aside.

And if we eat out again after I get my bands in, totally going for the Duck or Chicken Porridge. Sure, it's 2 or 3 times the price as in Chinatown, but 1) not walking all the way to Chinatown, and 2) my teeth deserve the treat.

Damn right, this is Useful! I'm looking out for all my brace-faced peeps!
author: Tinna H.

description:
Lemongrass pork and vermicelli bowl
yummy fish sauce/dressing
small portion of greens and bean sprouts
tasty pork that was hot, but a bit on the dry side (not overcooked, but the consistency of a really tender jerky) like it had been marinating a long time which meant it was flavorful.

I finished all the noodles and greens before I realized I still had lots of pork left, so it's definitely a filling bowl as my stomach can attest. It should know, it's getting pudgier. *poke poke*

I've had the chicken curry in the past and wasn't too wowed. It's pricey for what it is, but I liked what I had today. For a complete meal sans drink in the ferry building, 8.50 wasn't too bad as long as you like your food. Some Vietnamese restaurants are creeping up to that price anyhow. I've heard the sandwiches are good, but that's a pricey sandwich. And $3 for a bun! I'm sure it's good but you could get so many more in Chinatown for the same cost! Remember when they were 50 cents? Ah, the good o'l days...

Don't forget to check out the specials, because they had some tasty halibut over vermicelli today, too. And they have boba drinks.

EDIT: Oops, the vermicelli bowl is 9.50. Pricey!
author: Amy N.

description:
In through the out door...

Morning after the night before and I decide to meet up for some brunchfast with some of the more dedicated of the Wage-slave crowd who have to work with their hangovers from DYL and Bitter...

NiH --- Where do you want go? We're going to meet Ed M and Luis M...Myth cafe? 

Me --- Ehhh Frenchy food - not so much...I think I'm growing a beanie and I have a hankering for Jerry Lewis?

NiH --- Food court at the 'Mall Jesus Would Have Built'? 

Me --- YESSSSSSS! (Frightening isn't it...)

Who would have thought that you'd see Slanted Door in a food court? Funky no? Ehhh, just go with it...

Nice big place, kinda laid out like a cafeteria, cool staff, good menu...let the games begin...

NiH --- I'd like the pho...

Attention Deficit Disorder Out The Door Waiter --- pho ga or pho bo?

NiH --- Uhmmm, I'd like the pho

ADDOTDW --- pho ga or pho bo?

NiH --- Pho

ADDOTDW --- Chicken or Beef?

NiH --- Beef...

ADDOTDW --- Beef or Chicken?

NiH --- Beef...

ADDOTDW --- Chicken?

NiH --- Beef!

ADDOTDW --- Beef Chicken????

NiH --- You had a good night last night didn't you? Were you at the Ambassador?

ADDOTDW --- Uhmmmm, *looks down sheepishly* yeah *looking back up with a BIG smile on his face* - Sooooo you want Chicken with Beef...

NiH --- WTF????

ADDOTDW --- Just kidding...


Bring in the clown head...And den? And den? And den? No more 'and den'!!!!

Just kidding but I started to wonder if ordering through a giant clown head at a take out window wouldn't work better...



5 Stars for the GREAT food also as a plus we got free food for looking 'local' and a balloon animal! 


****I tried to write a short review - honestly I did....I know...not so short...I tried...sorry! ****
author: Todd E.

description:
Out The Door gets a lot of attention by virtue of its relationship to Slanted Door, but I'm not sure the chef(s) at Slanted Door are holding up their end of the bargain.

The food is fine but definitely not exceptional.  And the prices are well above the standard Vietnamese fare found throughout the city.  I'd rather sacrifice a bit of the Ferry Building/foodie ambiance and just get a more inventive and cheaper meal in the Tenderloin.
author: Stacey M.

description:
I heard the fresh spring rolls were excellent, so we decided to try these on an early  Saturday afternoon (a.k.a. a pretty prime time for getting food at the Ferry Building).

eh.......okay. so they weren't exactly fresh. nor were they excellent. I think my mom makes better spring rolls, for one (no, she's not Vietnamese....but she learned from Vietnamese friends) . But maybe that's cause hers don't sit in a plastic bin all day. You know, they're actually FRESH. And her's sure as heck don't cost some ungodly amount. $8.21 for some dinky spring rolls? Really? Haven't you heard, there's a recession going on?

They weren't terrible, but for $8.21 I expect a little more than a mediocre "they weren't terrible." I just don't get it. It's not like this place has to worry a whole lot about service or anything; all they have to do is get the food right....

You can get a better at a Vietnamese restaurant, most of the time for less than $8.21. And they'll serve you. At a table.

So we left and got oysters...and then ate at Hog Island after. Yeah, ok, I should not be able to eat an additional meal after eating your spring rolls.
author: Tiffany L.

description:
I've only eaten here once--

We had the Jicama-Grapefruit Salad and the boiled dumplings with shrimp and pork.  Both dishes were excellent--the dumplings soft and pearly, toothsome, and filled with a juicy crumble of meat and seasonings.  I was blown away by the salad (my girlfriend seemed less impressed with it).  It was full of tasty grapefruit segments and topped with caramelized nuts (walnuts or pecans--it was hard to tell).  The cabbage and jicama were crisp and the dressing was tart and savory at once, made herbal and piquant by the generous shreds of rau ram, the "Vietnamese" cilantro (as the Thai call it: "pakchi wietnam").  I'd have sprinkled on some chili flakes had I had them, but overall it was well worth it.

I'll definitely be back.  The service was quick, too.
author: Anthony R.

description:
I had high hopes for this place and my experiences here have been mixed.  I've been disappointed in the watery, bland congee and the meatball banh mi.  They're pricier than what I'm used to and they weren't very good.  The banh mi fell apart and was too drippy.  The meatballs didn't have much flavor.  The baguette was good (probably from Acme?) and the ingredients were fresh and high quality, but the elements didn't work together well (e.g., proportions, flavors).   The milk tea is premade but it's decent and comes with pearls/tapioca balls.

They do have delicious buns (expensive though) and the claypot chicken  (great lemongrass flavor) was tasty.  The portion size of the claypot chicken was generous, and it came with some very good broken rice.   

They also have various kits for at home cooks that look interesting (I haven't tried any).
author: Lolia S.

description:
Best enjoyed with Miriam W.
This lovely little station in the ever gorgeous Westfield Shopping Centre, is well done and without all the noise of its accomplished originator.
author: Sean S.

description:
If you know what you want, and what you want is a sandwich, this place is awesome. 

I highly recommend that you don't waste your time with the tiny-salad that takes an hour to make or the blah noodle soup if you want your money's worth (and this is a relative money's worth, since everything on the menu here is three or four times what you would pay at an authentic vietnamese place). 

One other word to the wise- skip their other location at the new mall. They hardly give you any meat in your sandwich there. =( I bought a sandwich there once and actually went back to demand more meat, and still only got about half as much as the Ferry Bldg location give you.
author: Chris Y.

description:
What a great way to start the week with a lunch to go that is both tasty and healthy.

The "green papaya salad with tofu, rau ram and roasted peanuts" - Delicious AND refreshing.

The "Hodo Soy Beanery organic lemongrass tofu with fresh shiitake mushrooms, onions and chili sauce" - Excellent!

My friends seem to love the steamed buns with either pork or vegetables. (It is usually the only time at our bayside table (just outside of Slanted Door) that everyone gets quiet as talking is replaced with chewing enjoyment).

An added bonus is that after placing your order you are given a pager which flashes when your order is ready for pick - this leaves you free to wander over to the Miette pastry case a couple of doors down...
author: Dakar D.

description:
This branch of the chain may have fallen off the wagon.  I have had a Vietnamese sandwich at the other branch in San Francisco Centre and I think it tasted better.  Two of the sandwich varieties here were sold out, which left me with one option, the spicy chicken sandwich, which was not spicy.

It took a really long time to make this sandwich.  Whenever this happens, I think of New York and how I get skipped over in the sandwich line if I don't order immediately.  This place would go out of business in New York, but I guess most sandwich places around here would.  The service in the San Francisco Centre outpost is quite fast.

This branch seemed disorganized despite being fully staffed.  The staff was very friendly, but could use some efficiency training.  Sorry guys, it's your manager not you.  The counter looked very messy and the store was disorganized.  Oh Door, if I had an exposed counter I would do whatever it takes to keep that clean.  There was a carton of milk for coffee in the the soda case.  A bit disappointing because the other two Slanted Door chains really know how to run a business.
author: apple r.

description: This place is just the best.  Love their chicken noodle soup, their green papaya salad, their chicken salad, their imperials rolls (regular and vegetarian are both delicious), and Mary's Chicken Claypot.  Oh so good!!!!
author: Dagny C.

description:
I'm a little disappointed to say that I wasn't too impressed with this restaurant. For the price and the descriptions of the dishes, I really expected a meal that I wished I could get in LA.

Do try:

Salt & Pepper chicken wings. Not because it's innovative, but I love salt & pepper anything, especially when there's some Chinese 5-Spice thrown in the mix.

Cellophane Noodles with Dungeness Crab: Don't expect a whole crab. This is a noodle dish more than anything with chunks of crab thrown in. It wasn't what I expected, but it was very tasty, and I found myself grubbing harder on it than many of the other dishes.

Caramelized Tiger Prawns: This dish was meant to go to another table, but was placed on ours instead. Not that I'm complaining, it turned out to be one of my favorite dishes. Fresh shrimp. Robust flavors.

Not Bad:

Chicken Claypot - Great flavors, but we were told this would be the spiciest dish option on the menu. Well... It wasn't spicy. At all. But the flavors were there.

Pepper Corn Duck - I love duck. It's a flavor that can't be beat. But for $19.50, I did expect a bit more of a gourmet flair to this dish. It was very good, but disappointing for the price.

Not a Fan of These:

Fresh Spring Rolls - The spring roll wrap was tougher than I would have liked. The peanut sauce didn't have enough flavor. I feel like if they had made the sauce a tad bit sweeter, it would have brought the flavors of the shrimp & basil together better. I've had better.

The Lamb Sirloin - Don't expect a big chunk of lamb, because you're getting smalled chopped pieces in a stir fry, that ended up being a little dry. If you're going to serve lamb, do it so that the customer can appreciate the flavors of the meat. This dish could've been made with beef and I wouldn't have noticed the difference.



All-in-all: I would say, check this place out. You may find yourself loving it a lot. But I feel like the prices are jacked up because of the location, not the food.
author: Jenny D.

description:
As much as I love to hate it because of the long waits and also because it's not as good as it used to be, Out the Door is still one of the best lunch options that a person who spends 40 hours a week at the foot of Market Street has.

It's annoying, because it really used to be qualitatively better. But then again, I guess that goes for all the food at Slanted Door. So anyway, you can get a great lunch for under $10 here if you only get one item. Which is actually plenty, especially if it's five spice chicken with rice noodles, or lemongrass tofu and rice. For a lighter lunch, the green papaya salad is a favorite.
author: Megan W.

description:
Dang good stuff. 

Crispy Duck with Watercress - I have dreams about this.


Soemtimes they are a little slow and deliberate with the prep:  just put the damn carrots on the sandwich - I got to go!

Oh, the flourless chocolate cake is NOT worth $5.  That'll teach me not to ask the price before buying.
author: Tracy Y.

description:
i LOVE this place b/c now I can get my claypot chicken rice b/c the main restaurant does not do take out (I think)

AND they have this kit to make the shaking beef, I made it and I am NO chef, in fact I hardly ever cook and it was awesome! made me look good and made my tummy very happy. oh so good!

was not impressed with the Jook - it was way too mushy for me. though generous serving

Lemonade was wonderful!

minus one star for eh jook. and for running out of Boba. and for the long wait.
author: Sophia Y.

description:
If you crave Slanted Door, but already blew your whole paycheck already or can't get a reservation at Slanted Door, then you can grab some food from Out the Door. 

Out the Door is a take-out version of the Slanted Door, which means the food is almost equally as delicious, but the prices are much lower.

Located in the Ferry Building right next to the Slanted Door, it makes a very convenient lunch or dinner.
author: Elaine S.

description:
I don't understand why people like this restaurant.  The pho here tastes nothing like pho...in fact, it doesn't have any taste at all.  The spring rolls are okay, but really...why pay $7-9 for something that you can get for half the price with better and more authentic Vietnamese flavor at a less yuppiefied restaurant?  The Vietnamese coffee here would make any self-respecting Vietnamese person sad.  The vermicelli with lemongrass pork is no good either.  The fish sauce that comes with it too watered down to be good and the vermicelli was not cooked properly. I will admit that the steamed bun with chicken was pretty good.  That was probably the only thing there I enjoyed.

If you enjoy expensive Americanized Vietnamese food, I suppose this is the spot for you.  However, if you want real Vietnamese food, then I suggest you go somewhere else with less focus on stylish food and more on delicious food.
author: Linh N.

description: Whenever I'm looking for a quick and consistent meal at the Ferry Building, I usually grab either a vegetarian or a chicken bun to go along with a "Blue Bottle" Vietnamese Iced Coffee.  Other rice dishes and the soup are good, but if you are on the run, you have to go bun!
author: Jason A.

description:
Anything Slanted Door is fine by me.

Yes, it's overpriced and not too authentic. But I love me some chicken clay pot and vermicelli noodles. Spring rolls are flavorful. I wash it all down with iced chrysanthemum tea. Plus, they serve you fast. When that vibrating order thing lights up, it's pure excitement from my belly.

Really, isn't this a better option than Panda Express? Not that I am hating on the Panda.
author: Michael S.

description:
No time to wait around for a spot at TSD? This is a quick and fair trade-off -
super fast and just as delish...plus they'll give you a little buzzer so if you do want to run over to Miette and get dessert while you're waiting, you'll know exactly when to be back. Love it.
author: Bridget W.

description:
This is, of course, the junior/take out version of the Slanted Door. As you'd expect, the food is uniformly excellent here--good, high quality ingredients, well-prepared.

However, the portions are small, and the value for money is therefore very poor overall, especially compared to the other options in the Ferry Building/Westfield Mall (depending on which one you go to). For example, they charge $7.50 for a BBQ chicken banh minh that is about 25% better than a very similar one you can get at a dive in the tenderloin for $2.75. (Actual prices!) You do the math.

So, basically, if you happen to be in the area and really craving Vietnamese food, and don't mind paying $12 for a light lunch, it's a good option. But I wouldn't make a special trip for it.
author: Mark G.

description:
it's ok.

i managed to hit the place right before it got super busy for lunch and didn't have to wait too long for my lemongrass tofu and veggie steamed bun.

the tofu in the dish was chewy, like pre-fried tofu puffs that restaurants buy frozen.  i'd expect this from cheapy take out places, not daddy warbucks ferry building caliber take out places.  the lemongrass sauce and veggies though were good and the broken rice was cooked perfectly.  the steamed veggie bun was piping hot and made up for the disappointing chewy tofu.

for the $$$ tho my veggie dish wasn't worth it.  if i was here and there wasn't a line i might grab a steamed veggie bun but vegetarians, the $9.50 for the one vegetarian rice/noodle entree isn't really worth it.
author: Jen I.

description:
Out the door means out the door. There shouldn't be a ton of seating. Take OUT, not in, but there enough seats at the joint & around the ferry building if you can't wait long enough to get home to eat. I recommend a bench by the bay on a nice day or evening.

$6 chicken buns?! SIX DOLLARS?!!!! Why yes. & I'd pay $10. These are the best little buns I've ever laid my taste buds. The ingredients are so fresh & not a chicken part was found undesirable (as in so many other take-out bun shops).

Taro root boba, imperial rolls, duck porridge, fresh spring rolls... I didn't have a treat I didn't LOVE. It is pricey, but so's gambling (at least the way I do it) & you won't be gambling on Out The Door's wonderful food. Get some take-out today!
author: Amy D.

description:
Love it for two things: 

Steamed Hong Kong Milk Tea
Chicken Steam Rolls

Thats my idea of a fancy light lunch - will do it over and over again.
author: Michael W.

description:
hands down, the second best beef salad I've ever had in my life. 

I have gotten a ton of people hooked on this salad all because I have been craving a beef salad since I came back from Australia in 2006. I have tried multiple places to try and find a beef salad that comes remotely close to the one I had there and all failed EXCEPT this one.  I figure this is definitely the next best thing since I can't go back to Australia for that salad. Every time I crave a beef salad, this always hits the spot.
author: Jessica L.

description:
The best part about Out the Door is its location. On a leisurely afternoon, there's nothing better than taking the muni down to the Embarcadero, and propping your feet up on the railing overlooking the bay bridge with a pearl tea. Yes, they serve pearl tea. If only it tasted better. 

I've never sampled Out the Door's cuisine other than its pearl tea. Sadly, it is the only place in that immediate area that sells my drug of choice. But this crack is not as pure as others - the pearl balls are always too soggy, and the drink ranges anywhere from really sugary to not sugary at all, seemingly at random. 3 stars for average.
author: Frank B.

description:
I would give this place three stars, but their service is exceptional.  During the lunchtime rush of the ferry building, it can get a bit crazy over here.  I waited and waited for a soup that I ordered and finally had to ask what happened.  

The person who listened to my complaint apologized profusely and said she would make it right then.  It was finished in under three minutes and they gave me a complimentary chicken bun!  Both were delicious, although I thought the soup (beef Hanoi noodle, pretty much beef pho) was a little bland...nothing sriracha can't fix though :)

**Update: I took the pho home to eat later, and it does not keep...so, you either eat it there, or just chuck it, not worth lugging it around.
author: Kristin E.

description:
All of the quality food, none of the scene.  There's nothing better in San Francisco than walking over to the Ferry Building on a sunny day for top quality Vietnamese take out. Don't leave without trying the lemonade, made with organic sugar.   Both the five spice chicken and lemongrass pork were delicious, and I will be back again soon.

UPDATE, 7/26:  I just purchased the cook at home chicken clay pot, which is only available as a special (and my favorite)  This will be my future go-to new parent dinner, as it has all the necessary ingredients and required a mere ten minutes on the stove.  It was outstanding.  Mushrooms and green beans are next on my list to try.
author: Beth V.

description:
Better doesn't equal better. 

Hmm..

The ingredients don't live up to the cuisine. Let's just say, you can go to Little Saigon, take a three-block tour, and eat every dish that you can find on Out The Door's menu, except better, cheaper, and so much more flavorful. 

Pork Banh  Mi (Called "Roasted Pork Sandwich") at Out The Door= 8 bucks of flavorless fatty pork, soggy cucumbers, and ITALIAN(?!?!) artisan bread. Pork Bunh Mi at mostly any of the sandwich shops along Larkin=2 or 3 bucks full of salty, spicy, tender pork, fresh carrots, and even fresher jalapeos on the appropriate (In the way the French occupied Vietnam) FRENCH baguette. Not even a fair comparison, really. 

Come to Larkin street and see what you think the next time you go to Out The Door. 

Hmphf.
author: Libby T.

description: It's the cafe version of Slanted Door. Some of the dishes are exactly the same but cheaper. The food is fresh and tasty. It's not uncommon to see menu items disappear during the day.
author: John S.

description: Out the door is the slanted doors express restaurant, and faster Vietnamese from this place makes me a happy girl:-) I'm often in a rush during the day and don't have time to dine, so the convenience is perfect for me! Not to mention this place has possibly the best Vietnamese food in the country...
author: Danielle M.

description:
It's a Wednesday night and you can't make reservations for Slanted Door until nearly a month away?  Still craving the green papaya salad (so scrumptious!)?  Don't go to the ferry building, head to Bloomies, dahling!

This is a brilliant idea!  Take a fabulous, yet pricey restaurant like Slanted Door and make an affordable restaurant in a food court.  You have a couple options:  you can take things literally out the door OR you can dine in for an affordable taste of renowned restaurant Slanted Door.  

Delicious!
author: Krista C.

description:
I LOVE LOVE LOVE OUT THE DOOR! I don't know why I didn't write a review sooner.  I frequent the ferry bldg location at least 4x a week.  Not everything is perfect, but this place makes me happy.  First, it's not authentic vietnamese cuisine; it has been altered to suit the non-asian palate, but I'm ok with that.  I'm not looking for authentic fare, I'm looking for a place that uses sustainable, fresh, and good quality ingredients.  Plus, I'm looking for something that is healthy and reminiscent of home cooking (i.e., rice, certain flavours, and ingredients).  

I feel the prices are reasonable for the ingredients they use; I cook quite a bit and shop for the best ingredients, so I know how much things cost and understand the time it takes to prepare it (time is money).

They are definitely hit or miss items on the menu, but I've stuck to items that are usually a hit for me.  I love the chicken salad (not greasy at all and very filling), spring rolls with no mayo, and occasionally on a wet and cold day, I'll pick up some chicken noodle soup.  Also, the 5-spice chicken sandwich is delicious, but be prepared for major food coma!
author: Miss H.

description:
This was a great idea by the owners of Slanted Door. The restaurant is always swamped, and sometimes, you just want something to eat instead of a meal. Out the Door solves this. I love the steamed chicken bun and the sandwiches are tasty (though the crusty bread can make it a bit of a challenge).

I had never seen compostable utensils before, and I think it's a great idea. They aren't weird in looks or texture; they're just better for the environment. I hope other takeout places follow their lead.

Yes, the place is more expensive than other dining options, but it's in line with other restaurants in the Ferry Building. Nothing is particularly cheap there.
author: Timothy O.

description:
Another great day in SF for a long-ass walk in the sun. I'll show my punk friends who got President's day off who's got the better job. My friend and I leisurely walked to the Ferry Building and got food from OTD to go. Am I the only one who might get this place confused with "Out of the Closet?" http://www.yelp.com/biz/NavZ2wFv_qgIwKv7IVOnQg

My friend got the pork and veggies while I ordered the chicken curry. The chicken was extremely tasty and infused with spices. It had stewed a bit and fell off the bone making me feel cool that I could eat it with chopsticks. The carrots were sweet, mixed in with soft tater chunks. I only wish there had been more veggies. The yellow curry sauce was somewhat oily, and the rice was a tad dry and too reminiscent of couscous. For eight bucks each, it was a winner lunch.

(3.75 * stars)
author: Brady K.

description:
Food was good, but it was VERY slow...apparently "out the door" means nothing to them...but the food was good.
Why are Vietnamese sandwiches not more prevalent?  They are SO good!
author: Nilu r.

description:
Still hungry after my oyster-fest/coup at Hog Island, I decided that instead of making a fool out of myself by sampling all the food items laid out at the food boutiques in the Ferry Building 30 times each (let's call it Chez Costco a la Ferry), I should actually pay for a more substantial meal.

The Out-the-Door concept is keen enough.  Why not give people a little better quality of fast-food than we're used to.  Why not indeed.  For anyone who grew up in a culture of great street-food, this is no revolutionary concept.  Why it should be revolutionary here in the States, I still have no idea.

But Out-the-Door misses a bit on the execution.  Now to be fair, I tried only one of the dishes, Rice with Duck and Watercress.  The rice has chopped up green onions, and the duck is roasted well enough.  But the duck is still missing a bit of that juicy crispy goodness that good Peking duck has.  This duck had a consistency half-way between roasted and smoked, not bad but a bit schizophrenic.

The rice could have used some more umph.  Simple white rice is not enough here.  It needs something more.

There's still a lot of potential here, so I won't condemn the place.  I think the Shaking Beef and claypot items are bit overpriced for the "fast-food" theme, but hopefully the execution is well done.  I'll try that for the next stop here.

Oh, and for the tourists family that could not laugh hysterically at the word "Shaken Beef" (shaking uncontrollably to give added effect), we get it...haha....now move on.  Bubba Gump is a few blocks away.
author: James K.

description:
A place I frequent for lunch during the work week. I probably shouldn't, but Its quick and the food is yum. Its best to get here a little before noon to avoid a long line because other people like this place too and so the line is just long during prime lunch time. Regardless, the line does go pretty fast.

I usually order the spring rolls for lunch and that is enough for me for lunch and it is made just right and with this order, you don't have to wait, once you pay, its handed over to you. great for when I have a short period for lunch. Or I usually order the chinese noodle salad which makes me full but doesn't make me feel sleepy later. I've always tried their pork sandwich which is yum. So far I haven't gone wrong with anything I've ordered here.
author: Bernadette L.

description:
I can't believe I'm only giving them 3 stars, but I have to. Although I love the Out the Door in the San Francisco Centre, I can't warm up to this one. Tried the Saigon BBQ pork sandwich today (for $8.50) and found that it was dry... Perfectly edible and pretty good, but the meat was definitely disappointing. 

I've tried the gamut at Out the Door and have yet to find anything I looove. I'm a huge fan of their take-away cook at home meals, but I've only done it twice. Nevertheless, it's a great idea.
author: Amanda C.

description:
Got the lemongrass pork vermicelli noodle bowl.

Oh man, this sucker was delicious. I had just eaten an entire order of garlic fries from the restaurant across the way, Taylor's, which were insanely satisfying. So I was pretty full by the time I started up on the noodles. After pouring in that thin brown sauce stuff and taking a bit, I felt like I unearthed my secondary appetite. 

The pork was amazingly delicious, the sauce made the vermicelli explode in flavor, and the veggies really tied the room together.

Yes, this place is expensive, especially since I live in East Bay, where Vietnamese food is usually mega cheap. But I was really wowed at how much I enjoyed this dish.

Recommended!
author: Jenton L.

description:
Overrated. The Slanted Door restaurant food is much better.
Prices are high. $3 for one vegetarian bun? It was not the best quality, not a lot of freshness or good taste to it.
author: Christine P.

description: I like the veggie buns.  They are a good snack.  They're filled with vegetables and rice noodles.  I sort of overdosed on them and now I'm taking a break.  I hate cilantro and a lot of the stuff here has it, so I never come with other people, for fear I will have to order more than a veggie bun to go.  This location does have a sit down area for non-cilantro-fearing people.
author: Julia D.

description:
After a long week at work, I go to Out the Door to treat myself to lemongrass pork over rice. Sometimes, I eat that dish more for the rice than the pork because their short grain rice has this incredible fragrance and perfect sticky texture. I wish I knew where to buy these grains!

It's also one of the only places nearby my work place that serves jook. So when I feel sick or cold, I down their jook with Chinese fried donuts. I just wish they had pieces of the thousand old eggs in the jook, but then again, that addition would probably scare off most people.
author: Cathy H.

description:
When one considers that a combo with a small sandwich and chips costs almost $8 at Quizno's, one would do well to walk themselves to the too-often-fallaciously-called-"overpriced" Out the Door takeaway restaurant in the Ferry Building.  

For a mere $15.62 (again, I implore you to consider the cost of much more mundane fare in this neck of the woods), my dining companion and I enjoyed fresh Vietnamese spring rolls stuffed with vermicelli, shrimp, chicken and mint  and also shared an order of 5-spice chicken and vermicelli.  I was surprised at how substantial the spring rolls were- more than enough for a meal for 1- and they were served with a very tasty, but not overpowering peanut-like sauce.  The chicken was flavored delicately (not spicy, just a bit smoky and tangy) and the cucumbers and mint added just enough "extra something" to the dish.  

Best of all, we enjoyed our meal out on the back patio of the Ferry Building, soaking in the GREAT September weather. We left feeling satisfied, but not stuffed or weighed down by greasy, processed crap. 

I will return, and may even make it a weekly tradition!
author: Jenni D.

description: I had chicken noodle soup.  The taste o the soup was kind of bland, but overall it was comforting quick fix for Asian like me. I would like the broth to be a little bit hotter in temperature. My friend had lemongrass pork with rice. I tasted the pork. The lemongrass taste did not come through the pork and it was a bit salty for me. But all ingredients were very fresh. I would come back for a quick meal.
author: Art T.

description:
The "fast food" version of Slanted Door, this place is great for a quick lunch.  I love the 5 spice chicken and the vermicelli noodes with grilled prawns.  Last time I was there, I ordered a mushroom steamed bun (manaupua)- which never came.  The server blamed the kitchen, so I don't know whose fault it was, but I was sad I didn't get to eat my bun.  

The menu has variety, for meat eaters and vegetarians alike.  My sister even ordered the 5 spice chicken *without* the chicken- and the waiter didn't flinch.  

Solid restaurant, and in the mall to boot.
author: Sarah F.

description: For Ferry Plaza and for a Slanted Door kitchen I expected much more.  We ONLY had the spring rolls but its a staple.  If they're not doing them right they're not doing the rest right.  Our spring rolls were "interesting" to be generous!  The wrapper was the worst, it tasted day old for sure.  Sadly I know what day old spring rolls taste like, you know when you have great ones and you want to save them cuz they were so good but you can't eat anymore?  You know they won't be good but you keep them anyway...that's what I tasted first round with the Out the Door ones.  The pork was perfect, cut really thin but really flavorful.  EWW the shrimp was fishy.  The greens not Vietnamese fresh which is just explode with flavor fresh.  The noodles were nondescript.
author: Todd O.

description:
Just not very good, for a few reasons:

1.  When you're standing at the end of the line, it's hard to read the menu (you have to bend over to see under the overhang).  This is just poor design.

2.  The line, which moves oh so excruciatingly slowly (though, admittedly, this is a ferry building problem, not an out the door problem).

3.  Food (chicken curry) was a big disappointment.  Curry was more salty than curry-y, and the salt was ultra-absorbed by the potatoes and carrots making them almost inedible.  Chicken was ok, but the decision to serve on the bone with skin made it difficult to eat with plastic silverware.
author: Matthew R.

description:
This morning my husband had the great idea to head out to Out the Door for lunch. We had just finished breakfast maybe 30 minutes before he was talking about lunch...

Didn't disappoint. 

Short line (yea!) I weaved around the uncertain people and ordered. Shrimp with vermacelli, beef noodle soup and a chicken bun. With a bottle of water and a Vietnamese coffee the bill came to $30. Perhaps *a bit* pricey but once we sat down....

Heaven.

Yummy in my tummy.

All parties (including the little one) left satisfied.
author: J B.

description:
2 orders of vegetarian spring rolls set us way back. It felt sort of stupid to eat  this expensive snack while standing up. I almost needed a white tablecloth to feel justified.

Flavor-wise everything was good and arrived nice and hot. Just not sure it was the right value. Vietnamese iced coffee was not authentic at all - already completely mixed and hardly any coffee.
author: Mariangela S.

description:
It's Slanted Door --- it must be incredible --- except it's not:
1) It's in a glorified mall (as far as mall food goes I guess its okay, but...)
2) Selection is limited in severe ways (BBQ chicken only bun? WTF?)
3) It's overpriced --- by a long way when $5.95 --- $6.95 is appropriate for a good bowl of bun with rolls & meat everywhere else. 
4) Oh, and the food is a specter of that had elsewhere.

But it's slanted door!  Yet, the food is faltering, beneath even the lowest other bun spot I can think of.  

The BBQ Chicken Bun mentioned above and eaten by default was a mass of unvaried rice noodle, with a cloying sweetness in the Nouc mam (weird --- and not in a fusion cuisine "neat" way either).  Don't get me started on the chicken --- I hate sinewy chicken.  Spices on the chicken weren't bad, which is some relief and allows Out the Door to escape from the orbit of a single star.

Still the place is clean looking --- right? So are most Burger Kings.
author: Gustie L.

description:
I agree with Libby T.....the $7.50 (!) roasted pork sandwich was a big, overpriced disappointment. It wasn't even well constructed....too much chewy fatty pork on one half, a sprinkly of veggies and dressing on the other. And the wrong bread. Plus the service is eh....my veggie friend ordered two veggie buns and got two chicken ones, and had to stand in line again to fix the order. And they prepared our hot vietnamese coffees and let them sit on the counter until the rest of our order was ready. Not so hot.
I'm sticking with Saigon Sandwiches.
author: V. R.

description:
I have only had four items here:
Duck Rice Porridge
Chicken Steamed Bun
Veggie Steamed Bun
Veggie Spring Rolls

The duck rice porridge is so good I can't stop ordering it! The Steamed buns are totally delish and I didn't really like the Spring Rolls. It's $7 for the porridge which really fills you up, so that seems like a good price to me. It gets a little crowded at lunch time, but so do most places in the Ferry Building.

1/27/2007 - Once again I got the wrong item yesterday. Ordered the Duck Porridge and got Chicken. I couldn't really take it back cause I had eaten enough that it didn't seem right. I probably won't be going back again. The people at that counter are consistently spacey. GRRRRR.
author: Jocelyn A.

description: Mmm sooooo good, but it sucks that they keep raising their prices.  I couldn't believe it but they milk iced tea, soooo good!! Their chicken and veggie buns are great snacks too, I used to get them for $2 but since they raised it to $3 I don't see myself buying such a little bun, idk why but that additional dollar just won't come out my pocket lol maybe if they made them bigger.  All their soups are very good and my favorite plates are the Grilled 5 Spice Noodle and Grilled Prawns Noodle.  That hint of mint in each plate makes every bite soo good, the taste is great, I don't think I've had anything like it.
author: Christina O.

description: This is a Vietnamese takeout restaurant located at the end of the Ferry Building Marketplace (merchant #5). Like its name, everything here really should be thrown "out the door." I don't understand why people bother eating here. I haven't bothered wasting my time writing reviews for sub-3 star establishments thus far, but this place was so far below average that I felt compelled to write my first one. Hanoi Beef Noodle Soup for $11.50? Spring rolls for $8? Vietnamese iced coffee for $3? Wait, this place is TO GO right? I came here with my parents on a weekend and ordered the above items. Wow I'm still amazed we waited in line at this place and still see one sometimes(!?) when I visit the Ferry Building. I guess we discounted the fact that people were hungry and just didn't want to wait in even longer lines elsewhere. This place fits your typical "bad food + not worth it" experience - the worst possible combination. We sat down at the small table that seats maybe 5-10 people and waited around 15 minutes before our food was ready. The pho was extremely diluted, the noodles were extremely average, the meat was extremely difficult to chew, and the garnishes were extremely lacking. Since this is supposed to be a takeout place, I'm not even complaining about the cheap plastic bowl and utensils they provided. The four small finger-sized spring rolls (more than $2/piece after tax) were very average without much food. To be honest, the best thing going for it was the dipping sauce. Finally, I was expecting some decent Vietnamese iced coffee, but it literally came from a pre-brewed pitcher of diluted "coffee" (more ice, milk, and sugar than anything else). Was this made from instant coffee? Perhaps The Slanted Door is actually "good food + not worth it" or even "good food + worth it." Perhaps. But that is a bet I'm unwilling to take. For Vietnamese cuisine, there are too many inexpensive and delicious options in Little Saigon for me to consider returning here. All in all, I would avoid this place like the plague.
author: Andy C.

description:
I will probably be ousted for saying this, but what's all the hype about???  Seriously?
I tried the spring rolls (mediocre, though the peanut sauce was killer), the chicken dumplings (pretty damn tasty...dipped in the peanut sauce anyway), and the lemongrass tofu/veggies (tased like the tofu had been sitting outside in the rain for a few hours).  Icky.
Don't get me wrong, I LOVE good food, so I was shocked that this wasn't better.  I even know Charles Phan  (who would not be pleased with this review I'm sure).  
Oh well, I guess I'll have to try The Slanted Door and see if that holds up to it's reputation.
author: Stephanie W.

description:
So sooo good.  Tried the 5 spice chicken VN sandwich -- thick, juicy, wonderfully spiced chunks of chicken, tangy and plentiful carrots, fresh cucumber and bright, leafy, flavorful cilantro, all tucked into a thick chewey roll.  Plus the black rice pudding -- subtle, not overly sweet, with complementing coconut milk and mango; love the chewey, grainy texture as well.  So very very good.  Everything on their menu looks divine, so the worst aspect is having to choose. But then 97 of you already know that, don't ya?  Smart Alecks. 

N.B.  Came at 1 today for lunch, and, for once!  the line was short.  I  got my order in about 5 minutes.  Not even enuff time to negotiate myself into a Scharffenberger & / or Miette compulsive buy.
author: Natasha S.

description:
Yea, it's kind of on the expensive side but like everyone else says, it is the Ferry Building and it is the offspring of Slanted Door (I'm still on the waiting list to get seated for that one). It is delicious though. The Spring Rolls are nothing to write home about but something to write Yelp about. The Imperial Rolls are really good. I still have lots to try on the menu but I was blown away by the Vietnamese Meatball sandwich. Imagine that! The marriage of my two favorites. It's pretty messy so it's not ideal to take outside to eat while using your lap as a table. You'll end up with numerous stains but the tasty goodness was worth it! I love the papaya salad. The serving is pretty big. Whenever I go, I always get the Leche Flan for dessert (they don't call it Leche but it is flan).

Out the Door my ass, I was waiting a while. That's my only qualm but do try that Vietnamese Meatball sandwich!
author: Tatiana D.

description:
I liked the overpriced food and can deal with the crowds, my only peeve is that they don't honor gift cards from SLANTED DOOR - even though they share a kitchen and it's the same place.   

To compound my problem the SLANTED DOOR doesn't do take out - so you really are trapped/forced to go to the restaurant to use the gift card.  This is fine when you have 2 hours for lunch, but after dropping $100 on a gift card you'd think they'd honor it at either place.
author: William G.

description: Slightly more affordable than its counterpart and almost worth it.  Had a chicken curry dish aaaand it was mediocre, rather bland actually.  I wish they hadn't run out of the Vietnamese sandwiches.  There was one redeeming part to my visit--the Vietnamese iced coffee.  Refreshing and delicious!
author: Karen N.

description:
Could have been better... I paid $8 for a Vietnamese sandwich and no place to actually eat it. 
Luckily there are plenty of benches nearby ... but at the same time .. plenty of begging pigeons. 
The next time I want to spend $8 on a Vietnamese sandwich .. I'll go to Saigon Sandwiches and buy 2 whole sandwiches and a can of coconut cream peanuts= $8.50 ... then I'll drive to a place with a better view and enjoy a much better sandwich.... er actually 2 sandwiches.
author: Jeremy R.

description:
I was out training in SF for the week and decided to visit my old haunts in DT... and I decided it was time to revisit the grossly overpriced Slanted Door.  My coworkers recommend I try the takeout section and I was pretty impressed! 
For $7 I got the Lemongrass Pork and Rice plate, and I was pretty impressed by the portion size and the quality of it (although a little oily). It came with string beans, chopped rice, and really really good marinated pork.  I sat down back in the office to eat and people looked at me curiously.  I think the rice plate are the few decently priced items on the menu!
author: Crystal K.

description:
Strolling through the ferry building Friday during lunch, I decided to get food from here and eat outside on the deck out back.  So apparently this place is a 'takeout' version of Slanted Door Vietnamese.  I was pretty impressed by the menu, ranging from everything from steamed buns, fresh spring rolls, soups, sandwiches, noodles, seafood, and meat dishes!  I ordered the grilled 5-spice chicken w/ lettuce, cucumber, and mint over rice vermicelli.  My friend had the same thing except had the grilled prawns instead.  

The food was super fresh and delicious!  The mint and cucumber make it very earthy and light tasting, and the meat was grilled to perfection.  Don't forget to add some of the fish sauce that comes on the side, it's really great!  Prices were about $3 more than at a typical Vietnamese restaurant, but I guess this is the standard markup for being at the Ferry Building!  

There are a million good food options in the ferry building, but if you want something light, flavorful, and pretty damn tasty come here!
author: Rahul S.

description:
The service was fine. The Hanoi beef soup (sorry but I judge Vietnamese places, even the really frou frou ones by their pho) was fine.

But so not worth it for 10 dollars. 

Maybe I'd come back if I were desperate? I actually think that the pho is cheaper at the Slanted Door, but I don't think they'd let you only order that. Plus you'd have to pay tip. Even though they suggest tip on the Out the Door Receipt - WTF do you expect me to tip when the whole concept of this restaurant is fast food? I don't think at Mickey D's and I won't tip here. Sorry.

Also, imperial rolls are not worth 10 bucks. Can get them elsewhere - like Tu Lan - for much much less.
author: Karina Q.

description: I love their five spiced chicken and vermicelli plate! It's perfect on a bed of salad, fresh mint, pillowy vermicelli and the grilled five spiced chicken is so good! I'm coming back for more!
author: Mika D.

description:
A great takeout place!  (Or you can sit down at the Westfield mall.)

I enjoy their duck and chicken porridges, steamed buns, salads, and pearl milk tea.  Slightly pricey, but hey, it's the ferry building!  And it's delicious.
author: Carol L.

description:
I'd probably give it a 3.5 instead of 4, but i'm not complaining.
(1) Spring Rolls:  it's on the "100 things to eat in SF before you die" list.  The reason why it's good:  the SAUCE!!  Second reason why it's good:  the spring rolls have mayonnaise in it, which keeps it moist.  Third reason why it's good:  on a hot summer day when you don't feel like soup, this crisp, refreshing spring roll will hit the spot.
(2) Vegetable Bun:  over-priced (~$3 each, and it's not a big bun like some other Chinatown bakeries serve), but it's really really delicious (especially if you're a fan of the mushroom family).  I was really impressed by the taste, but not by the pricetag.
(3) Taro milk tea w/bubbles:  The bubbles are inconsistent, and the flavor is ok.  I don't recommend this if you're in the mood for Taro Milk Tea.
Be prepared, 'cuz during lunch time, the line goes "Out The Door"...
author: Laura C.

description:
The rice porridge is ok, not anything to write home about.  The pork sandwich was, as others point out, chewy fatty, icky.  I've ordered some other things from this location, but nothing stands out.

The service is absolutely horrid if you get there around noontime on the weekdays.  They've messed up my order a couple of times and the staff is indignant when asked about the status of the messed up order.

I've some friends who really like this place...they're not Asian.
author: Maggie K.

description: Really nice Asian (Vietnamese-ish) food for the on-the-go luncher. The Ferry Building was a bit too busy for my tastes, and I would have liked a bit more in terms of formal seating than a belly bar. The spring rolls were delicious, the pork bun also good eats. My boba tea was bobalicious. I'd give higher marks if service was faster and I didn't have to share my lunch with the gulls outside. Solid.
author: Brian P.

description: At 10:40am on Sunday they did not have the vegetarian sticky rice or the meatball sandwich. Instead I ordered the claypot chicken rice dish, papaya salad and the spring rolls. Yes I know the prices do seem steep "for Vietnamese food" but I've heard so much about Charles Phan, I just had to see if his food was really all that by getting some of the basics. Taking price out of the equation, I enjoyed the food very much. I had reservations thinking that the food would be too bland or Americanized for the non-Vietnamese palate. As a Vietnamese person, the food stuck true to the basics. The papaya salad and claypot chicken were as expected, tasted like the stuff I would eat at other Vietnamese restaurants and I enjoyed it. The spring rolls were soft and moist, I think there was mayo on the pork to make it more moist? The sauces were as spicy as it should be, not too spicy but growing up, my parents always kept the extra peppers and chilli sauce on the side for the people who can handle it, so just ask for more if you need it. I was very pleased with the choices. I'm glad the Vietnamese elements didn't get compromised too much. If you want to eat cheaper Vietnamese food then go elsewhere.
author: Giang L.

description: I love Out the Door's fresh rolls but today I tired the pork banh mi. Would have been decent except for the fact that there was more pork fat than meat in my sandwich. Desk-butchering and food dissection, doth not a good lunch make. Ugh.
author: Molly D.

description:
shrimp & pork spring rolls: 
the pork was kind of gross so I pulled it out as best I could. otherwise, pretty standard--nothing special. could have used more mint. came with plenty of peanut sauce.

steamed pork bun:
the bun had a nice light texture, but the meat was extremely salty. i love to eat, but didn't finish it...that says a lot.

overall, i thought it was alright if not a little disappointing. was hoping for better since it's associated with slanted door. maybe the hot entrees are where it's at?? i'll report back.
author: Kate M.

description: Great lunch spot if you're craving some "modern" Asian/Vietnamese fusion.  The steamed buns and vegetarian sticky rice are my go to lunch selections, and if you don't eat a lot, they're a decent deal for the Ferry Building.  The chrysanthemum ice tea is delicious too.
author: B. Y.

description:
I was so excited to come here after hearing so many things about Slanted Door so I had really high expectations.  Nevertheless, the food was good, it just wasn't my favorite.  I ordered the a chicken curry and it came out really quick.  Super.  My friend ordered duck and hers took a bit longer to come out.  But once we were able to eat, we sat outside looking at the Bay Bridge on a bench.  What a great afternoon.  

The food itself was alright.  The price was right-- not too much for a lunch which was nice especially in the ferry building.  I wish my chicken wasn't so chewy but it was dark meat so what can you expect.  Even though my experience was just mediocre, I really do want to try the Slanted Door!
author: Cara D.

description: i have had banh mi in Westminster and Garden Grove before and I have to say I was disappointed with the banh mi from out the door.  The meat is flavorful, but the bread was not the typical baguette you would see in a banh mi.  Seemed like they just took a french roll and stuffed meat and pickled veggies in it.  The spring rolls were fresh and a definite plus with the banh mi.  Just wish they used authentic french baguettes with their banh mi recipe!
author: Janice M.

description:
Hellloooo Lemongrass tofu! 

So -- now that that's out of the way... 

Tried to get in a slanted door -- but couldn't..

so we decided to just head around the corner and get the "to-go" version... We shared the tofu, Crispy vegetarian imperial rolls and a salad.

I didn't eat any of the salad because I was too enamored with the lemongrass tofu and imperial rolls. Really, wonderful. (And I'm not a big tofu person... really.. I'm a vegetarian who is reallyyy picky about tofu) 

We were lucky enough to snag a couple seats at the bar so we didn't have to search for a place to eat... or eat standing up. 

The portions -- as most people have complained... are not your average American ridiculous portions. You really need that much food????

We got three things, it was enough for both of us... and we had some left over... total cost: $26. That's a pretty reasonable lunch for two...
author: Kristen G.

description:
This review is just for the steamed buns.

When I want to get out of the office at lunch I'll walk down to the Ferry Building, order 2 steamed chicken buns from Out the Door, maybe get an iced coffee from Peets or a gingerbread cupcake from Miette and then walk back to work happy and not too full. 

I'd give these buns 5 starts, but at $3 a piece I can't champion them as much as I'd like to. $3 is a lot for steamed buns, but they are good so I continue to shell out the cash every once in a while.
author: Alexis W.

description:
The Clay Pot Chicken makes my stomach happy.

*SUBTLE SEGUE*  My favorite character in the movie Clay Pigeons is Lester the Molester.  *SUBTLE SEGUE OVER*

The pigeons galore behind the Ferry Building make me feel dirty.
author: Patrick C.

description:
Out the Door is to Slanted Door as Marc by Marc Jacobs is to Marc Jacobs and Miu Miu is to Prada: the slightly cheaper, diffusion line that the masses can enjoy.

Lunch favorite: lemongrass pork vermicelli.  Yes, I've had cheaper Vietnamese food elsewhere, but this entree is worth the price - the pork is perfectly infused with the lemongrass flavor, tender & succulent...paired with the vermicelli, fresh vegetables and that killer sauce...so good!  The shrimp & tofu veg plates with brown rice are good and hearty options as well.
author: Courtney B.

description:
Expensive fancy Vietnamese mall food, except that my mom says it sucks.  Worst banh mi ever; most expensive banh mi ever.

Out the Door gets one star (from a base of three) because it is gross and expensive.  Why are you eating at a mall?  I give you one star, too.
author: Amanibhavam K.

description: This is the original take out place by the Slanted Door, and for some reason, the Ferry Building location seems to taste better, not to mention is cheaper for the very same dishes.  The San Francisco Center location has a much larger menu, but for the basics, I prefer the original.  I love their rendition of pho, but the dish could use a bit more meat.  The wonton soup was way salty, though.  The roasted pork sandwich was very filling and good, and for a snack, the steamed chicken buns are nice.  I also tried the crab vermicelli at San Francisco Center, which was flavorful, but a bit too oily.
author: Peter L.

description:
I'll have to say it now....I'm not a fan of shi-shi (expensive asian food).
We came here not really by choice but out of necessity (no seat in the open court). We arrived...a tall asian woman seated us(hostess)( cute and curvy...I notice) The price is what I expected....10-15 for dishes.....but surprise surprise....they had boba.....it even said boba on the menu....I was shocked....A wonderful thing to have among the snobbish clientele...Now for the food....a couple of fried spring rollls, some fried chicken (hold the heat) and some beef with noodles...they also had some interesting cane soda. I had to get one.....The friend spring rolls were good...not great....beef with noodles was good. The fried chicken was ok......could have added something else to it.....all in all after about 60 duckets...we were full and not stuffed. I would go back just to see the hostess not totally sure on the food....Vietnamese food can be had for a lot less than 60 duckets and tastier....So I say....I'm out the door....really
author: d o.

description:
Bahh Just as bad as the Slanted Door.... NO WAIT WORSE.
Basically the food is horrible, the chicken is grey and your just paying because of the popularity of the other restaurant. To be fair I have given Out the Door a try on a few occasions with different things off their menu in the hopes that something would be redeeming... but alas NO. I wont be standing in the long ass line full of up-their-ass business types who think they are cool for eating at this horrible place anymore. Give me a dirty/greasy Vietnamese restaurant that does take away any day over this place.
author: Sarah S.

description: I am so happy that Out the Door brought its fresh and high-quality food to the Bloomingdales mall food court.  This restaurant distinguishes itself from the others in that you can sit down out of the throngs, and the food is very good.  It is also quite pricey: today I paid $23 +tip for lunch , which was beef and asparagus with rice (perhaps this has something to do with the rent at this location??).  The service, as others have said, is pretty good, but sometimes things are forgotten, etc. when it is especially busy.  So having said that, I would give this restaurant a 3.5 stars.  I will continue to get take-out here for sure.
author: june b.

description:
Their start was not good at all. I noticed they had boba on their drink menu so I ordered a green tea with milk and boba.  It was the most undercooked tapioca I've ever had, but the manager was very nice and helpful when I returned the drink and he took it off the bill without having to be asked.

For food we ordered:
Crispy imperial rolls:  Delicious, crunchy, again the service was amazing they asked if we had eaten them before else they were going to show us how to wrap them in the lettuce leaves.
Niman Ranch beef bavette: i think that was what I got, but the beef was tender with it still pink in the middle...perfect.  The sauce was sweet and tasty.  Perfect dish to eat with rice, which was what I did.
dungeness crab meat with clear noodles: that was what my friend got and it was real, fresh crab meat in the dish just not as much as she had hoped, but she said it was a good dish.

Overall the food tastes great here it's just that they totally overcharge.  There's a lot of Vietnamese restaurants around SF such as Sunflower, which taste as good and way cheaper with a lot more food.  I would come back here just because it is close to where I live and the food is delicious, but you can find way better deals elsewhere.
author: Stephanie Y.

description: I'm a Charles Phan fan.  I love Vietnamese food.  Bahn mi's are my jam.  That being said, The pork bahn mi here is special.  When I ordered it, I almost decided not to.  I mean come on, I can get a bahn mi for $2-3 at a sandwich shop. Why on earth would I spend more than $8 on one here? Well, it's 2-3x the meat and filling of a normal bahn mi.  If I split it, both of the people would be as full as if we'd eaten a normal bahn mi, and the ingredients were excellent, and very well seasoned.  That made it okay for me. I've also had their green papaya salad.  I love that I can take it home, and it has the dressing on the side, so it stays very crisp and fresh.  Now, if I wanted to eat there, they have a tiny counter and a stand up area, but it's just not enough space to really enjoy the food right there.  I don't know how I would enjoy the warm dishes, but for what I've used it for, I do like the place. The wait is a bit much (I had 1 person in front of me, and still waited 10 minutes for my two items), but the food does a lot to make up for it.
author: Erin O.

description:
This is a review for their boba.  I honestly didn't know they served Vietnamese.  But then again, I was across the way waiting to order a Taylor's garden burger, when I started the mental debate -- which is better, tropical boba or a vanilla heath milkshake?  The answer was neither is good for me, but I opted for the mango juice + tapioca.

I do like the fact that their ice is bigger than the hole in the straw, so initial drinking enjoyment does not include ice with tapioca.  They offer pretty standard (boring) boba, so my initial impression was 1 star for lack of creativity.   However, I threw in an extra star for the environmentally-friendly cup made of corn.  Maybe I'll try the food here in the future and comment on that.
author: San D.

description:
I had the pork with vermicelli dish yesterday and it was very yummy.  I think it's certainly above average for a Vietnamese place but not extraordinary.  It's pricier than other places but this is the Ferry Building so what do you expect??!!  You are paying for the location!
Tables are hard to come by and there was a continuous line although they seemed to serve pretty quickly.
author: Evelyn H.

description:
Slanted Door is overpriced...so then Out the Door is as well.

Although on a cold day, the duck porridge hits the spot!  I applaud them for serving quality and great tasting fare.   Nice concept!
author: Alex L.

description:
I had a shrimp with vermicelli and a Hong Kong Milk Tea here.

I rate this a four star for the simple validation that there are some take out places in the US that are not all about greasy and soggy food.  Out the Door stays true enough to its Slanted Door reputation and has healthy, good food that you can take home.  That means a lot to me.

Oh, and you can eat outside Slanted Door and have a better view of the Bay Bridge than the regular guests there ;)
author: Yu T.

description:
Espensive for a takeout lunch, but delicious, delicious, delicious. Love the vermicelli bowls (mmm fish sauce) and the shrimp rolls. Yum.
Lines are very long durning lunch but once you order, the wait isn't so bad.
author: Rennie L.

description:
Food is good, but too expensive for what it's worth and practically no seating.  I used to work close by and came here for lunch numerous times... but in all seriousness, if you are just looking for good Vietnames Pho, Goi Cun (shrimp roll), or Imperial rolls (fried), you might as well go to Pho Hoa at Embarcadero 4. It's cheaper and more seating.  If you are looking for steam buns, go to China town, you can get steam buns that are 3 times the size for 1/2 the price.

Just remember, Out the Door is really not the same as the Slanted Door; the Slanted Doors offers a whole other experience that is not meant to be fast, cheap or convenient, even though they are owned by the same people and are attached to each other.... the Ferry Building Out the Door is just not compelling" for me....
author: Sandy W.

description: I love Out the Door, so much so that I am craving it right now.  I've been here once before and ordered the chicken claypot, the claypot was really good. BUT, I went again with a larger appetite and my mom to share with, we ordered the crispy spring rolls and lemongrass pork with rice. Those hit the spot. The spring rolls have a great flavor and the perfect crunch. It comes with fish sauce, those white noodle things, and lettuce, we wrapped it in the lettuce and put some noodles and fish sauce with it and it feels like you're eating something healthy and delicious. (Minus the fried part). The lemongrass pork with rice is so yummy, I can't even describe it. You'll have to just try it out for yourself. (And I highly recommend trying it out!)
author: Analisa S.

description: Single pork bun on a drippy dreary Sunday afternoon is the perfect on-the-go snack for walking and poking around in all those cute stores
author: Teju A.

description:
YES! Porridge in downtown.... So yummy. Three star place but they get the extra star for having my favorite Asian breakfast from my travels in an easily accessible area and charging a somewhat reasonable price.

   I came here 30 minutes before they closed on a cold night that screamed "eat soup for dinner!!" Having noticed the porridge menu option during the summer I swung by to give it a try. I was completely taken aback when I saw the size of the serving. It was huge! So huge in fact that I only finished 1/3 of it.  The soup is a broth thickened with rice. I chose the chicken as my protein so there was shredded chicken mixed in with garlic and onions on top. It could have used some siracha or soy sauce to liven it up, but I was tasty. Now, while I must admit that it didn't taste like it fell out of Asia, it was a nice reminder of my savory breakfasts in the far east and I will order it again. But next time, I won't put the to-go container in my giant purse. Spilled porridge in purse=not happiness!
author: chelsea b.

description:
Steamed vegetarian buns!   yummmmmmy =)

Crispy Imperial vegetarian rolls!   delicious!
author: Jennifer S.

description: Service was pretty good, food was very good. Was difficult to hear people you were sitting with.
author: Michael W.

description: The food was ok.  The service was great.  I think they charge too much for sides and rice (8.50 for a side of chinese broccoli and 3 for a side of rice).  Definitely overpriced and I probably wouldn't go back but the waitress was really nice.
author: Set S.

description:
Slanted Door is rather pricey for vietnamese, but well worth the experience.  Out the Door offers to-go options that are uniformly tasty, but also rather expensive.  I had two good meals from there, so was looking forward to trying something new on the menu.  Turns out the chicken curry should be called "chicken knuckle and gristle curry".  The curry was tasty, but there was almost no meat, just bones and knuckles.  Rather a disappointing thing to discover about my 12 dollar meal back at the office.  

So the noodles rock, but stay far away from the curry.  It is not worth the high price tag at all.
author: Liz R.

description:
For being a restaurant in a mall it was pretty good. Its a casual atmosphere and the prices are average. Service was good. We started with a bottle of Reisling that was pretty good. 

I would have liked to have seen more of a variety, the selection was decent but not too big.We ordered Spring rolls, really good. Spare ribs, also tasty. For our main dishes we got some noodle with crab , steak and lamb....all 3 dishes really good. We were stuffed so didn't order desert.  Over all it was really good, I am looking forward to trying their sister restaurant ( i think it's the swinging door).
author: Leza B.

description:
Positives:
Good food, great for the financial district, walking distance from where I work.

Claypot
Oh man, nothing beats the claypot for lunch. I'd have it every single day if I could, except for the small little fact that I'm afraid of getting sick of it. Chicken, cilantro, over rice... mmmmmmm starting to get hungry again... 

Imperial Fried Rolls
One of the best fried rolls I've ever had. Crispy, yet fresh on the inside, they give you romaine lettuce and some rice noodles to kinda make it like a Fried Roll Burrito (wrap the roll in the romaine lettuce, add the rice noodles, and wallah!). Dip it in the sauce and watch it disappear so quick that if you blink, you'll think I teleported that bad boy into my mouth.

Lemongrass pork
Pretty good, but I like the claypot better. I mean, why mess with perfection?

Negative
Pricey. But if you're eating lunch, and you work in the financial district... I don't think that price is a limiting factor for you.
Oh and they don't give you enough rice. But hey, I'm Asian, and you know how us Asians love our rice.

Disclaimer: Yes I know i'm stereotyping, and yes i understand that not all Asians like rice, and yes I get that... you know what... F* it. All Asians love rice. They don't give you enough. Booyah.

Ambiance
Er... it's take out. I got your ambiance right here foo...

Service
Cmon now! It's take out! You order, you pay,  you git da hell outta dere!

Seating
Ok I gotta say, seating sucks. This is a Ferry Building in general complaint. If it's sunny, people seem to materialize out of the woodworks (I think we're kinda allergic to falling water... drinking it we do ok, but if it falls from the sky? allergic.) and the place is packed. Not a fault of Out the Door, but of the Ferry Building in general. Get there by 11:30 and you should be ok. Theoretically. Sometimes... 

Summary:
Nice place for lunch, expect to pay $15. But cmon, its the Financial District and pho costs $8! Whaddya expect?!
author: Seiji N.

description:
Out the Door has great one-dish Vietnamese meals for a reasonable price.  Considering you are getting Slanted Door organic, local  ingredients, it is a really great deal.

I love to grab a vermicelli bowl and sit out on the Pier watching the sailboats and seagulls on the bay.

Definitely grab a bite here when you are craving Vietnamese at the Embarcadero, or when the Slanted Door has a wait so long that you just can't hang.
author: Jessica P.

description: I ordered a Saturday special a week ago.  It was lemongrass chicken with jasmine rice.  The small bits of chicken meat on my plate were dry and hard to chew.  The flavor was not distinctively Vietnamese.  It had no lemongrass taste.  For a $13 plate of to go food, it was a disappointment to say the least.
author: Elizabeth Y.

description: True to its name, the line is always out the door and for good reason:  the food is tasty and fast, though priced for the Ferry Building crowd.  Diners expecting authentic Vietnamese food must remember that Charles Phan is known for targeting his cuisine to a broader audience, which means variations from traditional Vietnamese and/other Asian cuisine.  One example is the steamed buns, a fresh and tasty treat.  I think these are a variation of Chinese steamed buns, but Out the Door's are distinct from traditional Chinese chicken, vegetable, or pork buns.  I'm a fan of the traditional buns, but here, each variety is more refined, less mass produced, and more catered to foodies (and those who don't mind paying $3 per bun).  For example, these pork buns don't have the red-dyed, oven-baked BBQ pork; Out the Door's pork bun has a softer, caramel colored braised pork filing that is a bit sweet with hints of pickled vegetables.
author: Chris T.

description:
I thought I reviewed this place before but since it didn't prompt me for an update.......

Won ton noodle soup.  I've had this twice.  Quality product but light on the won ton.  Also the won ton could be heartier looking.  They look puny.  Now won ton is a Chinese thing but I guess they do it with a Vietnamese slant to it, right?  Give me more won ton per serving and I'll boost the star rating.
author: Robert C.

description: Had Lemongrass pork with rice vermicelli.  It was average at best, portion was half of what I have ever gotten in other cities.  Meh!
author: Adriana G.

description: Got lucky while Christmas shopping at Ferry Market and no line here. Enjoyed delicious, fresh Pho, ginger cookies and a trio playing Nutcracker music.  Out the Door is a good option if you crave the Slanted Door for a casual meal, but are in a rush and want to skip the line.
author: michael p.

description: So many great dishes, and done so well. Do get the green papaya salad, which is fresh, and perfectly dressed with a tangy savory dressing. The crispy imperial rolls are expertly fried and pairs the rice noodles, lettuce wraps and sweet/sour sauce so well. Then there is the clay pot chicken, with notes of soy, fish sauce, and cilantro, both savory, sweet and fragrant. Don't bother with the shaking beef -- it's rather unremarkable.
author: Horace L.

description:
Out the Door Rocks. It takes care of my slanted door cravings when i don't have the time to sit down, and allows me to have it several times a week.   When i've gone, it's always been fast and flawless. oh god...thank you for putting the hue dumplings on the menu....my super favorite.
Update 9/13: No more hue dumplings :(
author: sarah C.

description:
Yawn,
this is just over priced over glorified, white washed Vietnamese food meant for general consumption.  

Go to the Tenderloin if you want better food with less frills and a smaller bill.
author: Matt V.

description:
What is it about being handed one of those flashing, vibrating, coaster-esque pagers that makes me stand there for a moment and think, "Seriously?" I suppose they are handier than yelling out a name or number, especially when you may slowly wander over to ogle some mushrooms at Far West Fungi. Still, there is just something, I don't know... something very impersonal and robotic about them. Plus, what do you do with the damn thing? Someone should rent out hockey sticks so you can start a pick-up game while you wait. But enough about my disdain for having something that looks like my PDA and bike taillight's love child tell me when my food is ready.

I had the lemongrass rice w/ crispy tofu and my wife had the green papaya salad. According to the one of us not writing this review, Out the Door had recently upped their prices, but, according to the same source, her salad was also a bit more generous in size. Both were very good. I think I am actually brainwashed to the point where I like tofu an may even go so far as to consider myself able to discriminate between tasty tofu and nasty tofu (but the ability to discern anything between edible and crap still escapes me). My rice could have been just a tad stickier. Though my skills are unimpressive, I prefer chopsticks with such dishes and good sticky rice makes me look better at using them. The green papaya salad, which I was forced to try, was also very tasty and, I might add, quite chopstickable.

Other reviewers point out there is no place to sit and eat, which confuses me since this place is so obviously geared to take-out customers. I suspect they also complain about the lack of waiters at McDonald's. The prices are, sadly, a bit steep in my book, not crass, just that the food, experience, and price don't really balance each other. Still, it makes for a nice, quick lunch stop and if you want to grab something slightly different  than your standard fare of soups and sandwiches and cop a squat in the Plaza, along the Embarcadero, or just shuffle back to your cubicle, you could do worse.
author: Don B.

description:
I heard about the restaurant "Slanted Door" from a friend of mine ... then I heard about the take out "Out the door" from my co worker. Apparently its the new "Hot Spot" so my boyfriend and I decided to try it out.

I went to Slanted Door Restaurant on a Friday afternoon during lunch. When we got there they said that only the bar was open for seating. But since that was packed too ... we decided to check out the take out window ... "Out the Door".

The line was fairly long and when you order, they give you one of those pagers. But seriously, our food took less than 5 minutes to be ready. We ordered the Crispy Imperial Rolls, a Meatball sandwich and tea. Oh wow the food was so yummy!!! The rolls came in 2 and were cut up into 4 pieces. The sandwich was a good size too. A little bit messy to eat but it was still very good!! 

The only reason why I gave this place 4 stars instead of 5 was cause of the price. You can probably get the same quality of food for a lower price somewhere in Chinatown! Oh and ... though I drink tea regularly, I wasn't a fan of their Iced tea.
author: Hiyasmin D.

description: I mean food was decent, flavors was there. Had the lemongrass tofu and veg, brown rice - $12! And it wasn't anything special. Was a little disappointed considering I head so much about this place. Maybe I should try the actual restaurant, they need to keep up the quality.
author: Pink G.

description:
Thank you out the door, your chicken porridge was yummy (it will taste better if you add soy sauce) and I felt alot better after eating it :) 

The pork bun was also good, though pricey (everything here is pricey)
author: Sendy K.

description: My visit to Out the Door is only representative of the soups me and my friend got there, which were filling and satisfying enough, but felt it a bit overpriced for what we got. Knowing that it is in a prime location, I expected higher prices - but the chicken noodle soup I got consisted of ho fun (thick rice noodles), a few pieces of chicken and a blandish soup base. My friends rice porridge was just as it sounds - nothing more and nothing less. Both items were very average and things that I could easily be made at home at 1/10 of the cost.  If it weren't for the line, the Slanted Door is a safer bet at getting a satisfying, worthy meal.
author: john l.

description:
