Finally, a place to have a business lunch downtown! Don't let the fact that it is in the basement of a shopping centre throw you off: there are tons of great eats in the Westfield. There's nothing wrong with having good food near to lots of shopping. If you've ever been to Japan, you know where I'm coming from.

I've been to Out the Door twice, both times for lunch meetings. Have never had to wait for a table. Today they seated me and let me wait for the rest of my party with no hassle. 

We ordered two appetizers: the Crispy imperial rolls with meat, and the Crispy vegetarian imperial rolls. Thankfully they arrived before we ordered our entrees, because they were so could have been a meal unto themselves. I liked the veggie rolls better, the meat ones were just too heavy & spicy for me.

I had the Niman Ranch beef salad for a main course. Very peppery, lots of tastes playing off of each other. The orange slices were a great compliment. A very solid lunch spot. 

Vietnamese coffee, iced, is dangerous. You must have some. I must have some more. Right after I walk home and back a few times. Bzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzt
author: Greg Q.

description: Omg. I love papaya salad and this place had it. Great place to do takeout and eat in the food court to take a break from shopping.
author: Jennifer D.

description: For the price, I think this place should be serving much better food. Or provide entertainment with their food. Or something. For the price of their (admittedly fine) Vietnamese sandwich, you can buy 2-3 sandwiches from Lee's or Saigon. Ok, so this isn't the place to buy Vietnamese sandwiches, but surely their other stuff is good right? 7x7 says you should try their spring rolls. I tried them. Nothing special. And still expensive. This place is probably just riding the hype of Slanted Door (which I've yet to try).
author: Tim C.

description: I came here for the Chicken Porridge as recommended by 7x7's 100 Things to Try Before You Die in San Francisco. I might be grading Out the Door a bit harsh here because I am Chinese and I know how to make porridge, but I only found their's to be average. To be fair, it is far superior to that of say, Quickly's, which is more like watered down rice with a generous serving of corn starch for thickening. However, the main problem with OTD's porridge is that it's completely possible to make it at home at a fraction of the cost. Just make sure you throw in those chicken bones and simmer with the rice to extract all the natural chicken flavors. If you're not someone who knows how to make porridge, then this is a good alternative. It's as close to homemade porridge as you can find anywhere. Just be prepared to pay a premium for it. It's also a good idea to get it before noon, especially during Farmer's Market, because I've seen it sold out on multiple occasions during the late afternoon.
author: Jenny C.

description: The Lychee and Chrysanthemum iced tea was good, but they filled the cup with 3/4 ice....ugh...i want some iced tea, not ICE.
author: Moko R.

description:
If all you eat is imperial rolls this place would get a 5. This is the "fast food" arm of the slanted door. The quality of food is what you'd expect from the main restaurant. Ive not gotten a chance to try the sauteed shrimp vermicelli. They sell out of very quickly, so somethings gotta be right about it.

The lemongrass grilled pork vermicelli bowl has wonderful flavors but the meat is too thick. This leaves an incredibly chewy product that tastes more boiled than grilled.

If you enjoy your imperial rolls with the lettuce, ask for an extra piece or two. They provide you with 3, sometimes 4, and i tend to go through one per piece (6 total). Ive only had this dish better in one other place across the 50 states (to chao in Oahu).

Yum yum!
author: H B.

description:
Ok, I'm Yelping when I should be writing a paper.  It's still "writing" right?  

Anyway, I had lunch with my b/f at this place.  I was a bit reluctant to go to a place that serves Vietnamese food with every meal like $8 and up.  I've had hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese places with good ass food.  Anyway, this place was voted #1 by some SF magazine for best spring rolls...Whatever!  It didn't even taste as good as the cheap ones.  Two spring rolls were like $8!!!

The Lemongrass Pork Vermicelli bowl was flavorful and the Vietnamese Pork Sandwich was good (a bit dry...Irving's Cafe kicks its butt) and had a lot of meat.  The Chinese "donut" tasted cold and greasy.  The Vietnamese Coffee was yummy...and in an eco-friendly cup too!

Anyway, this place is decent - it serves fresh food at least.  Too expensive for Vietnamese food though.  But if you have the dough, hang out at the Ferry Building.  I usually go there just to sample foods and walk around.
author: Dylan's Aunt E.

description:
I went there 4 years ago. I ordered some chinse porridge with no sugar coated donuts. The donuts were big at that time. I like scattering these donuts in the porriage. Slightly ginger taste with chicken. It was good.

I went there a couple of months ago. I ordered the same dish. Donuts were like M&M size. Dissapointed. i don't know if I go there again. 

This kind of food are supposed to be cheap. They are originally cheap foods for general public. But like any other stores in the ferry building, it was quite expensive. I guess that we pay for more style?
author: Dove P.

description: Had the pork bun and spring rolls and both were delish!  I had been eating all day at the farmers market so I just wanted a little taste since I've heard so much about The Slanted Door.  So glad that I stopped by!
author: Tiff L.

description:
I have tried the sandwich's for lunch and they are very good.  A little pricey but everything else is in the financial district for lunch.  The pork sando is my usual fav.  Order some steamed buns while your at it.  I once tried the lemongrass chicken dish, thumbs down.

Update:  They raised the price of the sandwich to $7.50.   Everything else cost way more.  They are getting too greedy.
author: Nagoo N.

description:
Out the Door is pricey but I always find myself going back for the fresh spring rolls. They're not too filling, just the right amount, and very tasty. 

Make sure that if you do get any of their foods packaged in their plastic to put it in the compost bin to the left of the counter.
author: Ashley E.

description:
Are you kidding me.  This place is horrible.  Bland, overpriced food with so so service.  (ditto for Slanted Door)

My girlfriend and I ate lunch there and were utterly disappointed.  Save your money and go down 2 blocks to Tu Lan on 6th street between Mssion and Market.  The ambience is kinda hoody but the food is very good.
author: Rene M.

description:
The food here is good and moderately priced. I recommend the duck+watercress or duck porridge... 

Don't expect any seating though. Minus the small bar and a couple tables there really isn't anywhere to eat. You could try the dock outside, but it's usually full during lunch hours. It's a good place to pick up something to go.
author: Terence T.

description:
$9 for a main item a two salads.  I had the tofu chicken patty which is like a tofu dumpling with shredded chicken and rice and veggies for the stuffing.  It was excellent!  I also had the mushroom salad and some other salad, both of which were pretty good.

My gf had the friend shrimp cake which she said was good.   However, she did not like the black colored salad.
author: Brad S.

description:
The vegetarian spring rolls are FABULOUS!  Portabello mushrooms, noodles, tofu, small amount of carrots and mint leaves all wrapped up, chilled and served with a delicious peanut based spicy sauce.  Good stuff!  

Sometimes there is a long line if you catch it around noon on a Friday - but isn't everywhere at the Ferry Bldg like that?!  They try to get you through the line as quick as they can.
author: Kristin C.

description:
i make an effort to come here on fridays and/or saturdays.  it's the only 2 days they serve their current scones.  FREGGIN DELISH!  if you have a chance, go get some.

the crisps outer layer and the soft inside.  it's not too sweet nor bland.  you can see the lemon zest and taste what it is you're actually eating.  

my personal perfect pairing to the scone is their iced coffee.  it's like crack served in a 16oz solo plastic cup.  my goodness!!  haven't had cracked out coffee like that since i was in vietnam!!!

their shrimp spring rolls, good.  tofu veggie rice bowl, good.. everything good.  every time we order food there i feel as if we coulda gotten the same tasty foods in chinatown for a lower price.  guess we're paying for the view.  rather enjoy my food by the water (or gandhi) than in a loud crowded cramped restaurant.
author: ann.ie k.

description: You must get the Spring Roles! The shrimp, rice, lettuce, and pork wrapped goodness is to die for. Dipped in their delicious peanut sauce! Now you're in heaven! On a sunny day take your spring roles outside to enjoy. It's the perfect lunch break that will cost you about $7. I can't wait to try more at this tasty spot.
author: Casi C.

description:
Their duck porridge is my new favorite dish. Its the Asian clam chowder of San Francisco. Fragrant with a fabulous herbal perfume from special Vietnamese herbs, warming, rich and delicious on a cold damp foggy day. And thats not even including the duck! And I dont even like duck especially!
And to think this was  to go - WE LIVE HERE!
author: Nan L.

description: If you want a version of Slanted Door at a discounted price try Out the Door.  Its not as good as Slanted Door but its very good. The noodle dishes... are all very tasty.  The soups here are good but the flavors are not as complex as you would find at Slanted Door.  The food is very good here, especially considering that it is really offered up in a food court at the mall.
author: David C.

description: My first day in SF. My first food experience in SF. My first, "wow, this is really good" in SF. And my first thank you to my friend who suggested lunch here. For a tiny, to-go spot like Out the Door, I was seriously impressed. Everything on the menu sounded delicious, but with the recommendation from my friend to try the Grilled Lemongrass Pork, I was sold. It was fantastic -- very flavorful with just the right amount of spice. And, to boot, we ate it outside by the bay. What's better than good food, a nice bay breeze and great company? A fantastic first day in SF!
author: Tracy T.

description: So, I discovered this in the corner during my last trip to SF..it's almost hidden that you would overlook it. I had try slanted door the last time around and i was aghast to see $7 vietnamese sandwich! what?!?! Compared to my $3 sandwich in westminster? But I gotta admit the sandwich was delicious...toasted with charbroiled chicken and it was huge...and their chrysanthemum/lychee tea was yummy...pricey but yummy! There's like 6 seats right outside the area but it's more of a take it and go type of food.
author: Jenny L.

description: I've tried 3 things from here and they were all amazing! The 5 spice chicken sandwich, pork sandwich, and the pork noodles are all seasoned perfectly. While the meats are super flavorful, the crispness of the veggies (cucumbers, basil, carrots, etc) really add a nice touch. Perfect place for lunch and is much more affordable than the expensive side of this restaurant. Recommend picking up sandwiches and sitting outside facing the water.
author: Catherine K.

description: Had heard a lot about The Slanted Door and noticed this outpost offered some similar dishes. Since I was on my own for lunch, I went to Out the Door and got the fresh vegetable spring rolls and the Chicken Vermicelli Salad. Both were very good; fresh; loaded with vegetables and flavorful. I think I would have liked a little more chicken in the salad, but that's just me -the balance was really perfect the way it was. I couldn't finish both dishes so my husband got the leftovers and was quite happy with both dishes.
author: Martha R.

description: Looking for a quick bite, we stopped at Out the Door on Saturday afternoon after a stroll through the Ferry Building. Three words: heavenly spring rolls. The veggie spring rolls (and peanut sauce) were superb, if a bit pricey. My boyfriend got the jicama and grapefruit salad; he was a fan, though the salad was a bit light on the jicama, heavy on the cabbage. I'll definitely be back for the veggie spring rolls, though I don't know whether I'd make a special trip for them...
author: Kate G.

description: the crispy imperial rolls are excellent (see my photo) - they are totally different from egg rolls, or spring rolls, or fresh salad rolls; they are an invention onto themselves.
author: Scott F.

description: I get lunch take-out from this spot at least once a week. They have been putting less beef into the beef noodle soup and it's starting to bug me. I don't like it when quality places start to scrimp on ingredients. At $11.50 for soup, I think they should think about adding the value back
author: roger m.

description: On our escape from LA visits to San Francisco our family turns into crazed food hopping visitors. One stop that is always on our hop hit list is the Out The Door take out.   We actually prefer the simple food at the Out The Door take out over the fancy stuff at Slanted Door.   We hit this place in the morning for their wonton noodle soup, chicken bun or porridge which are all really good and split the food (tourist food hop eating).  We then move on over to the Saturday morning farm market and sample other interesting foods.
author: Robert M.

description: What a rip off for 12$.  Hardly any noodles in my vermicelli bowl. You would think a reputable place would be more generous. I will never go there again.
author: CR L.

description: I'm not a big fan of the Slanted Door, I think that place is overrated, and I am now a lesser fan of Out The Door. I think this place is way overpriced for something that is so standard and could easily be made straight out of a box purchased at Trader Joes.
author: NirvAnna M.

description:
I had a terrible day at work and decided to treat myself to take out from slanted door. i really wanted the bbq pork ribs but they do not do them . very disappointing and i could not order them in slanted to go either. i did order my usual imperial rolls , slanted door spring rolls and the jicama salad with red grapefruit and pecans and since i couldn't get the ribs i ordered the lemongrass pork and vermicelli . spent 37.00 
the imperial rolls were fine and that's were it ended. the spring rolls were old they had been sitting around , the pork was greasy and full of Grissel and fat , and the jicama salad was 99 % red cabbage 4 small segments of white sour grapefruit and 3 pecan pieces . the red cabbage salad i fed to my garbage disposal it was horrible tasting . i can honestly say i will not buy from them again .
author: mark y.

description:
$8.50 for a sandwich?  Was it worth it? Yes, it was.  I left half a sandwich in my fridge for 2 days and it still tasted great.  That means they use fresh ingredients so the sandwich last longer.  It wasn't soggy.  I  have left too many sandwiches and forgotten all about them in the fridge so I'm an expert at this.  
I like the pork better than the chicken.  The pork was more flavorful.  The shrimp spring rolls were delicious. The only thing I didn't like so far is the Hanoi beef noodle.  It was tasteless.
author: S. K.

description: Boba rocks my world! It's a treat I allow myself to have every month or so. Total sugar bomb, but I can't say no to a mango flavored Boba!! The Vegetarian Spring Rolls are incredible. Accompanied with their rockin peanut sauce you really can't go wrong. I also enjoy their veggie bun. You can pick up these great eats and head outside to park yourself on a bench with the view of the bay. Life is good and so it lunch at Out the Door!
author: Jen B.

description: My co-worker and I go here for lunch once every 2 weeks...The food is delicious, line is always so long during lunch hour, but the service is quick so it's worth it.  It's pretty pricey for the dishes - it's in the Ferry Building so that's expected!  All dishes - soups, sandwiches, vermicilli, and even their boba drinks are yummy!  The food is pretty fresh and full of flavor.
author: Regina N.

description: This is the place i come to when I am near the ferry building at lunch time - there are a few really tasty vegan options and have never been disappointed.  The only negative is the fairly high prices and sometimes the lines are pretty long.
author: Wendy K.

description: Tasty and quick, but way overpriced - $7 for a spring roll?  Give me a break!
author: .Hon H.

description:
looking for a lunch time quickie?

....this is where i come for my weekday vietnamese fix.

the fun part of going for lunch at the ferry building with co-workers is that we can go our separate ways and meet up again at a table with all of our different foods.  

it was on the pricey side but i guess they have to pay the overhead and rent.
the bad part of the location is sometimes there are no available seats.  you can also head over to the benches outside on a nice day or if it gets too crowded indoors.

i usually go for the duck rice porridge and order a bubble tea.  my co-workers also like the summer rolls - when it gets busy get ready for a long wait.
author: Anh V.

description: Overrated and overpriced! There are far too many great Vietnamese restaurants in the Bay Area to be wasting money and calories on this place!
author: Anastasia B.

description: The chicken bun was amazing!! Sooooo good...it's pretty steep for $2 a bun but it was filled with chicken breast, no fatty meat and the right amount of dough. It was a right temperature and otherwise, I would have burnt my tongue as I gobbled it down. Will return to try other items on the menu.
author: Yan M.

description:
TOURIST TRAP WARNING

I took an out-of-town guest to the Market location-a food court, for which I apologized-for a "business" lunch.  There were plenty of empty tables throughout the entire time we spent there.  Their dishes were no better than the great dishes I have had in the "Avenues" for 1/3 the price.

 After we paid our outrageous bill (about $50), we were approached by an employee stating that they had "reservations" for 20 min later & we needed to leave.  I pointed out that there were many, many empty tables in the restaurant & we would be willing to move to them should anyone wish to occupy our specific space.

The guy started stuttering & mumbling & looking very guilty, then said it was up to the management.

I did not wish to make a scene in front of my guest, but called them later to complain.  The manager's statement was that "Well, we did have some reservations for that time".  My response was that there were many empty tables at the time & there was absolutely no need to embarrass me or my client by asking us to leave.  I have eaten at this establishment (a food court) several times, but will not return.

Don't bother.  If you are hungry for really wonderful Vietnamese food, go to the "Avenues".  Just about any hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese place will top this place for 1/3 the price or less & much more professional waiters/waitresses.  Try "Mai's" on Clement for example.

This place is a TOURIST TRAP
author: sally g.

description: While running along the Embarcadero with a friend recently, in the shadow the Bay bridge, on a sunny November day, we couldn't help but thrill in the fact that we live ~here~; that this gorgeous run is our midday workout.  Those same sentiments are what I apply to Out the Door.  I can't believe that food this flavorful, balanced and exciting is available for a workday, grab-and-go lunch.  Leaps and bound better than a tired deli sandwich and well worth the extra dollar or two.  I've far from exhausted the menu but I have yet to encounter any outright disappointments.
author: Emily D.

description: This place is a great treat for lunch!  The line went quickly and the lemongrass tofu rice bowl was a fantastic conglomeration of spices and sauces.  My friends had meatier dishes and everyone was pleased.  We took our lunches out back, sat on the ground with our legs dangling over the bay and enjoyed the sun.
author: ellyk E.

description: The 3 stars are for the food. I love their egg noodle soup thingy and the fresh imperial rolls. Minus 1 star for the price (come on, Ferry Bldg! Don't you feel the economy?) and another for the sneering, mean, token white guy at the register who has in the past mixed up my order without an apology, never cracks a smile, and generally has no sense of customer service. I always have to subdue the urge to say Who put you in charge? I started to go on days when he's not serving the register. I mean, those prices have to include some hospitality or service, even if it's just for take out, esp since you have a tip jar on the counter.
author: Ms. Q.

description: Went there with my SO on a 10 day SF visit.  We got jicama salad w/ grapefruit, imperial rolls, fresh spring rolls, lemongrass pork vermicelli.  Jicama salad was the only good dish---excellent combination of flavors. A mix of textures from crunchy candied nuts to juicy grapefruit to cripsy vegetables.  Imperial rolls were okay---crispy but not juicy, sauce was one-dimensional.  Spring rolls were dry, skin was tough, no herbs inside (just lettuce, noodles, pork, shrimp), lacking flavor and peanut dipping sauce was bland (worst I've ever tasted).  Vermicelli was okay---pork was cooked through w/o browning (no crisp exterior), noodles were okay, but not particularly flavorful.  Our past experience w/ vietnamese is that you get interesting textures and flavor combinations.  Here it seemed like they didn't have much of either.
author: Jason R.

description: I loved the duck porridge.  It was great on a cold day after walking around the farmer's market.  There were no seats at the small counter (is there ever?) so we just ate standing up which was no big deal.  Definitely would get the duck porridge again.
author: Lila J.

description: The spring rolls are the best I've had in the area and I look forward to eating them any time I'm within walking distance. I also enjoyed the beef noodle soup, but holy moly is that ever a lot of soup!! I really wish I could find a place with soup and fresh (not fried, ew) spring rolls I liked this much in the East Bay.
author: Jen S.

description: I had a absolutely stunning bbq pork meatball sandwich here, to quote that crazy horse from the food network, "YUMMM-OH!". Juicy, fatty, no complaints. Abby and I have also shared the spring rolls numerous times which are always great as are the steamed buns and dumplings (both vegetarian and meat). Their pretty fast too so don't let the wait stop you.
author: Alex D.

description: Good, fresh, delicious Viatnemese food without the waiting line of the Slanted door. Great fresh rolls, soups, bunns, etc. Highly recommended!
author: Kedu A.

description: The food here is good but it is a bit pricey.  It's hard to justify the price of this meal when I can go elsewhere in the financial district/soma and get better food for half the price.  The wait is typically long during the regular lunch hour and it is hard to wade through the crowds of tourists in the Ferry Building.  I would rather spend more money and eat in the Slanted Door restaurant.
author: Dominique K.

description: If it wasn't so expensive and the wait wasn't so long, I would come here more often. It's definitely the best chicken pho in the FiDi, although it's hard to eat out of the tall take-out container.
author: Laura B.

description: Pretty darn good for mall food.  We chose to eat in, so it was a little more relaxing than roaming around with trays of food, trying to find a seat on a very busy Sunday afternoon.  Service was decent.  Prices were reasonable.  Food was good.  We would definitely eat here again.
author: Maryanne R.

description: Quick killer food without needing reservations six weeks in advance. Try the sandwiches for a picnic.
author: Eric K.

description:
Got the lemongras pork and vermicelli noodles.  I remember this place being a great take-out lunch spot, but it didn't blow me away.  Pork was a bit overcooked and jerky-like.  Overall, the meal was rock solid, and I'd go back and try something else.

Friend got the pork sandwich and raved about it.  Will have to try that next time...

Short wait, decent location if you work in one of the Embarcaderos, and not crazy expensive (~$9 for an entree).
author: w l.

description: Finally, a lunch spot that serves porridge a la chicken or duck, albeit a little too glutinous for my taste.  Afterwards, I felt like a bowl of glue had settled into my tummy.
author: Irene S.

description: Too expensive.  Vietnamese sandwich was admittedly very well stuffed with pork, cilantro, etc. so it wasn't skimpy, but still, overpriced at $9.  BBQ pork bun was great, but again, one bun for $3.  Nice food, need to adjust the prices down a bit.
author: Peter G.

description: Four stars mostly for the vegetarian bun--- delicately stuffed with asian buddhist veggies and mushrooms. I also had the lemongrass tofu dish- I thought it was perhaps a bit dry(needs more sauce) but the flavoring was nice. My friend had the shredded green papaya salad- I had a taste of it and liked the tangy(fish sauce-based) dressing. Though a bit pricey, the portions are generous.
author: Vicky P.

description: It gets points for having a shorter line than Taylor's Refresher, but thats about it.  My grilled lemongrass pork over rice noodles with imperial rolls, cucumber and mint  was that weird in-between temperature which, to me, makes food really unpleasant.  Its not warm, its not cold, some pieces are.  Things are warm that shouldnt be, pieces that aren't warm should be.  The pork was not great, the portion wasnt overwhelming.  The prices were ok, but i think you can find better vietnamese nearby (sai's on washington/battery) and you can find better, if not vietnamese in the ferry building.  I guess the 'fools' waiting for taylors were me 2 weeks prior.  Sometimes the popular choice is better.  This review in no way implicates the experience at The Slanted Door.
author: Christian W.

description: I went here this past summer for a trip to SFMOMA and they had really good Vietnamese baguette sandwiches and jasmine iced tea. My food was good but expensive since both items together rounded up a total of $11.50! That's too much for a sandwich but it was good so that's important. It's even in the Ferry Building which I found very cool!
author: Rodolfo S V.

description: Quite tasty, but not mind blowing, and soured by the fact that $7.50 is way too expensive for two little imperial rolls, a tiny pile of noodles, and some lettuce leaves - a mere snack really - and $3 is too too much for iced tea (they give tea away for free at Chinese restaurants... and its HOT). I know this place has the ritzy rep of the Slanted Door behind it, but that's no excuse to be stingy. I hate paying over $10 for lunch and still having to find something to eat on the way back to the office.
author: Caitlin H.

description: OK so they have this great kit where you can make their Shaking Beef at home. It's so good and everyone will think you're a top chef. You can also snag a Vietnamese Coffee on your way out, the caffeine will keep you going til next Wednesday.
author: Carson H.

description: The tall boy who works at this kiosk brings home the goods to my hungry tummy when I'm too lazy to look elsewhere. He's got me craving my jicama salads and veggie buns, though. The tofu is pretty bitchin', as well! If i didn't love him, I might use him for all the cheap food. It bugs me that they don't have more veggie options, though.
author: haley d.

description: I was beyond unimpressed with Out the Door.  I have been to the slanted door, which is overpriced, and this spin-off is no better.  I spent $10.50 + tax on their petrale sole vermicelli.  What I got was a box of vermicelli, a bunch of lettuce covered in fish sauce, and a piece of fish the size of 1/2 of a filet-o-fish from Mickey D's.  It tasted great, but it satisfied me about as much as gulping air would.  The only reason they get a second star is because they serve lavender soda (so refreshing) and the fish did taste good, despite the fact that there wasn't much of it.  So disappointing.
author: Kandi K.

description: I picked up 2 packages of shaking beef to take home and try and recreate Charles Phan's dish. Was it good? Yeah, pretty tasty. Was it worth it? It was kind of expensive!! I think I'll try my own version of shaking beef next time at less than half the price.
author: K H.

description: This is The Slanted Door's take-out window. FINALLY! With a menu that plays like the greatest hits list from the main restaurant's menu, this is exactly what we needed! The Lemongrass Tofu, Imperial Rolls, Papaya & Lime Boba, and 5 Spice Chicken are all to die for, and they usually a few have daily specials. Be prepared to drop $15 to $20 a head for this amazing lunch. And then head out to the seating that is on the bayside of the main restaurant. Soon they are going to have take home meals - everything measured all you have to do is cook it! I can't wait.
author: Rachel L M.

description:
yum, yum, yum, yum....

i love their papaya salad, their beef pho, the spring rolls, the rice noodle bowls are incredible, ooh and the rice pudding, damn its all so good.  its a little on the pricey side, but what isn't in the ferry building? i could eat their food every day for the rest of my life.....

they also have do-it yourself kits for food you can make at home, like their killer shaking beef, but i prefer to sit in their restaurant next door...
author: Kate G.

description: They offer basically the same menu as Slanted Door but without the need for a reservation or an expense account.  An additional bonus is you get to gulp down Belgium beers while you wait the fifteen to twenty minutes for a table.  The service is pretty decent as well.
author: Amber L.

description: I had a super lunch here today. It was a special - crispy noodles with stir fried seafood - delicious! Not expensive for the quality (my meal was $10) and you get to eat outside enjoying the waterfront view!
author: Sarah R.

description:
i really love this place, even tho i feel like they practically rape me for the cost of my lunch, i have to remind myself that this restaurant is doing great things with recyclable food packaging and composting, and supporting local farmers. i really care about that crap--so i can't get too annoyed at the price. 

i love the fresh spring rolls with chicken and shrimp. the portion size is ample and they come with this amazing peanut sauce for dipping. they don't skimp on the sauce either, i always have enough to finish. i'm also a fan of the rice noodle bowl with pork or chicken. you get this sweet and tangy fish sauce to dump over it and it's incredible. the lemongrass chicken and rice is very good too. 

the drinks are another way to drop too much cash on lunch, i try to steer clear, but i've become addicted to a few of them. they carry ginger beer here, coconut water, and i'm crazy about their taro root bubble teas. that sucker will fill you up tho, so skip it if you want a real meal for lunch. 

there's nowhere to sit tho so be prepared to search out a bench out back if it's warm, or to truck it back to the office if it's freezing.
author: rachel p.

description: I find this place pretty good; as others have said, it's pretty expensive for what it is.  I really enjoy the vietnamese sandwich, but that, in particular, is massively overpriced.  When I have visitors in town, I'll often take them here just as a way of going to the Ferry Building.
author: Danielle G.

description:
i ate here, inside, for the first time last night.  i think i prefer it as a to go place.  it just was a little weird eating at a nice place like this in the food court of a shopping center. of course, when you are shopping and you want something a little nicer, it's perfect.

the two of us did enjoy our meal. we had the fried veggie imperial rolls, the lemongrass tofu, and the eggplant/avocado sandwich. all of the food was really good.  the portions were just right, although, without the appetizer wouldn't have been enough. our total was about 32.00 with tip. i thought the price was reasonable for the quality of food but a little high for a food court restaurant. they had many other wonderful sounding veggie appetizers, just like the slanted door. and, i liked the carpeted, fuzzy, ceiling.  

one thing really annoyed me. when i needed to use the bathroom mid-meal, i had to leave the restaurant. it wasn't too far, but i just don't think this was good planning on their part.
author: Kristie P.

description:
a great lunch option!! the line seemd long at first, but it went pretty fast. i had the lemongrass pork vermicelli - so good! it was fresh, light, and the perfect amount of food for lunchtime. no afternoon food coma for me! 

my only gripe is it is a tad expensive for lunch, but hey its sf, what can you say!
author: Jessica B.

description: Considering it's the side project of the slanted door you can't expect it to be a cheap lunch spot. They are pretty fast considering they are PACKED during lunch especially on Friday afternoon's. If you don't fee like hanging out for 45 mins in line for a burger at Taylor's this is a fine alternative. They run out of some of their more popular dishes towards the end of lunch keep in mind. They are way less crowded for dinner which is nice if you are in a pinch and you don't feel like cooking or going out.
author: Stephen K.

description: Steamed veggie bun, green papaya salad, sunny day on the water, and I'm a happy girl.
author: Jenn M.

description: I am ADDICTED to their 5 spice chicken sandwich.  I have been walking 20 minutes from work as often as possible to get this delectable lunch.   I have also had their vegetarian steam buns - literally they melt in your mouth, people.   I get there usually on the early side for lunch (11-11:30) and I usually have to wait 5-10 minutes for my food.  Seems a long time to wait before the lunch rush.  I should try to call in advance to see if I can place the order by phone and pick up.  I get the feeling that the wait might be much longer during the heart of lunch hour.  They don't seem to have too much staff to support what I'd imagine to be a popular crowd for lunch.  In any case, the food is awesome.   Worth the wait -- and the 20 minute walk time!!  I recommend it.  Plus the ferry building and views of the water are spectacular!
author: Sheila D.

description: This place is the cafe version of slanted door. Although not the same quality as the restaurant, I would come here when I am craving high quality Vietnamese food. I've had the sandwiches, noodles and spring rolls. All are very good and high in quality. The only issue is the high price. But the restaurant is even more expensive.
author: Ginny M.

description: Had the lemon grass and five-spice tofu, which was to die for. But those must try spring rolls? Sorry Charlie, I've had better.  The pork overwhelmed the shrimp and the sauce was too sweet.
author: Amelia J.

description: I have lunch here once or twice a week and usually get the same thing -scrumptious spring rolls and a chicken bun or the delicious pork sandwich, accompanied by Vietnamese iced coffee.  I would branch out and try something else, but the gigantic beam blocks my view of the menu and my back hurts too much for me to bend down in an effort to read the other menu selections.
author: Marcus C.

description: Pretty expensive for lunch but well worth it.  The sandwiches are freaking fantastic.  The chicken buns and rolls are spectacular.  Usually a relatively long line, but it's quick.  Go on a nice day and hit up the outside seating, meet new people and sit on a bench.
author: Chris S.

description: I paid $10.50 for a dish called Crispy egg noodles with rock shrimp, squid, yellow chives and mung bean sprouts....only to find ONE pathetic shrimp in my meal. Though the dish was tasty, it ain't worth the price.
author: D'Andy C.

description: It is expensive compared to other places but it's expected when it's in the Ferry Building.  I had the chicken, potato and carrot curry which was really really good.  The portion was just right, but if you went any where else you would have definitely had left overs.  I paid some where around $8.50.  Definitely a good place for a change, but I'd head to C-town or the loin for some really good and cheap V food.
author: Po L.

description: I had my benchmark comparison dish for Vietnamese food: Bun Thit Nuong (aka rice noodles with BBQ'd pork and vegetables).  The defining aspect of the dish is the pork, and in this case, it was bad.   It had none of the delicious details of what I've come to love: thinly sliced, marinated pork grilled just until the ends are slightly charred.  No.  This was pork chunks laced with an uninspired brown glaze.  Ugh.
author: M A N I K.

description: love the ferry building. limited to-go menu here...but i always get the beef soup noodles. VERY long lines at lunch. Go around 11.30-11.45a to ensure 'faster service. somewhat sulky and rude service there
author: Jocelyn L.

description: (I agree with the hard-to-read menu comment.)  Overall, it was worth the long line.  I wish they had more veggie entrees and that the tofu/veggie dish didn't have fish sauce on it.  The special mung bean/sesame dumplings were super yummy.  I want to go back and try the desserts!
author: Andi T.

description: When you read the words "Lemon Grass Pork & Vegetables," your mouth starts watering, right?  Turns out it's an 8-dollar order of fatty meat and broccoli.  Whaaat?  I'm willing to give them another chance, but until then, it's just glorified Chinese take-out to me.
author: Andrea U.

description: The sticky buns are where it's at. I love the Ferry Building, but my wallet does not. The dumplings are the perfect cheap and tasty bit sized lunch (which I found filling, but my 6' boyfriend found just satisfying enough to hold over to dinner). That way I can spend my money where it really counts...cheese.
author: Leslie C.

description: I recommend this place when you get tired of pre-processed lunchtime options, as they make your order right then and there with lots of Vietnamese flair to basic, fresh ingredients. Dishes of note: grapefruit jicama salad, green papaya salad, vermicelli and shrimp and their spring rolls (keep in mind that the non-veggie version includes both shrimp and pork). I am also quick to mention that their chrysanthemum and lychee-infused iced tea is also worth the battle against line-clogging yuppies, I often order one then go get food from somewhere else- it's that good.
author: Megan W.

description: A bit overpriced...but considering this is the offspring of The Slanted Door, there's really no surprise. Asian food in general is one of the great bargains of the world, so it was a tad difficult to pay $8 for a small portion of five spice chicken and vermicelli. It was good, but a bigger portion would've been nice.
author: Maximillian M.

description: Wow! The 5 Taste Chicken and rice noodles is out of this world. I usually get the spring rolls or imperial rolls, but was so happy I got something different for a change. DELISH!
author: Jewel N.

description: I don't get anything here except the pork sandwich and have no need for anything else.  Unless you're Jewish, Muslim or vegetarian, you don't either.
author: Stef A.

description: I had the meatball sandwich on my latest visit for lunch.  Yum, it was a bit messy from the juices running out of the meat, which is more like a ground pork mixture than a meatball, but it was delicious.  I'd have it again, but there's always other stuff to try too.
author: Edgar C.

description: One of the perks in working in downtown SF is all the great eats in the area and Out the Door is one of my favs. Although it's on the pricey side, I would end up here at least once a week. My signature orders are: the fresh spring rolls, chicken porridge and sometimes their sandwiches. The rest of the choices are ok to me but for the price, I could wait til the weekend to go down in south SJ. My fav about this place are their cooking kits. Simple dishes that you can dish up in 15 mins or less. I LOVE their chicken claypot. I just wished that there were more options so that I could "cook" more frequently during the week.  =)
author: Kaitlyn H.

description:
overpriced.  some things are so so so good  the wings. yum  pork noodles.. rich and yum yum   their spring rolls wrapped in lettuce yum

but it has been very hit or miss.  VERY
author: Nicholas C.

description: surprisingly bad boba tea. my fault for ordering boba tea here and expecting it to be good though...
author: linda t.

description: It's pretty descent vietnamese food. But its really americanized vietnamese food. Their lemongrass chicken is what I ordered. I had plently of a portion but was expecting it to be a bit more spicy than intended. Chicken was quite tender. But in other words I rather stick to the real vietnamese stuff.
author: Nathalie N.

description: I'm usually only in the Ferry Building on Sundays, which is unfortunate since Out the Door is closed on Sundays. However, I have made it to the FB on days OtD was open and had the pleasure of eating their veggie buns and chicken buns. The veggie buns seem a bit heavy on straw mushrooms, but the chicken buns are really good and pretty inexpensive. A couple of those, a piece of fruit from Farm Fresh to You, and a salad from Delica rf-1 would be a perfect weekday Ferry Building meal.
author: Katie I.

description: A chance to eat at The Slanted Door without a 3 week advance reservation! The food is tasty and fresh and made my day. I had the vermicelli/shrimp and it was the perfect serving size. I took the food outside to watch the ferries coming and going and sip a bubble tea (OMG they serve BOBA HERE!! I was in heaven, until I tasted it, terrible, but drank it anyways...) Plus I cant wait to try the take away meals, genius.
author: Alyssa C.

description: Went for the first time today... miraculously, the huge crowd was waiting for Taylor's, despite the primetime of 12:15.  Got the special -- Niman ranch beef bavette -- basically super tender beef in a yummy sauce with asparagus, green onions, and lemongrass, and some other yummy things I couldn't identify.  My wallet was significantly lighter, but it was totally worth it.  Yum.
author: Nat K.

description:
my vietnamese girlfriend was visiting from denver and wanted to get her ferry building fix. she is quite the food critic as she is an excellent cook herself. when she suggested, i said okie dokie!

we had the chicken and pork bun (vermicelli in a bowl). her son had the bbq chicken sandwich (which was served as a whole grilled chicken breast on roll vs. chopped up chicken). her hubby had the vegetable and tofu rice plate. everyone was happy with their meals. i'd say they were good and less expensive than eating in slanted door. however, $9.50 for a bowl of bun is a bit overpriced!! i suppose it's reasonable compared to the rest of the options at the ferry building
author: joyce l.

description:
it's hard when you work at the embarcadero and you're craving vietnamese food. you're time is usually limited to one hour and at whatever pace your feet can carry you. out the door is usually a good choice because of it's convienence definitely not the price. and chinatown is just a bit too far. and who wants to take the bus down to the tl for lunch anyway?

the spring rolls are yummy and fresh. but peanut sauce is a little runny. the bbq pork vermicelli, well, i do wish the portion was bigger. 

the staff there is quite stingy about their condiments. we ordered take out for the office one afternoon for about 12 people so we had all sorts of things. we had the daikon cakes (very yummy), sandwiches, salads, well, basically everything on the damn take out menu. i asked one of the staff for some extra fish sauce and he asked me what i needed it for! when i politely explain that i wanted extra because we had 4 huge bags of food and lots of people, many with different taste buds would like to have more sauce. and the hot sauce was for the daikon cakes and sandwiches. ANYWAY after i explained why i wanted these extra condiments he asked me how many! dude, i need enough for EVERYONE. i ended up with 4 little plastic thingies of hot sauce and 4 extra fish sauce. it was NOT enough.
author: Mei N.

description: I'm actually pleasantly surprised their chicken porridge is so good (and such a huge portion if you get it to go).  With a few squeezes of lime juice, it tastes just like arrozcaldo, a Filipino version of rice porridge. I'd give it 4 stars but they sure skimp on the protein portions for the porridge!  I'm glad they serve pearl drinks here - it's nice to have something other than coffee in the Ferry Building.
author: Vera D.

description: Back in the Door are we.  Ordered 4 papaya salads to see if the changes had been made since our last crunch.  Happily they're back on the block with that.
author: Paula H.

description: My weekly ritual.  The great food of the Slanted Door at much more reasonable prices and you are "out the door" in less than 10 minutes.  My personal fave is the chicken salad but they have a pretty wide-ranging menu and daily specials.
author: Lindsay P.

description: Great take out without a long wait. Try the spring rolls with peanut sauce or the pork tenderloin sandwich with pate, and then head outside the ferry building and enjoy the sunshine and the bums talking to themselves.
author: Rob H.

description: Good food, decently priced, but take out takes a LONG time sometimes, even when it's not rush hour. Good selection of sodas and beer. The chicken buns are a must (and cheap, for SF).
author: Kevin L.

description: Their vietnamese sandwiches are clearly overpriced and not that great.  BUT, i am pretty into their chicken buns, which are only $2.  Two please!  And then I get a Dr. Pepper at Taylors to go window.  Muahahaha!
author: Katie M.

description: I got the chicken vermicelli to go and wasn't impressed. I hear great things about the actual restaurant Slanted Door, but was disappointed at Out the Door. I'll probably give it another shot, but it's way overpriced for mediocre vietnamese food when I can go up a couple of blocks and get a  big bowl of pho for $6. There's always a line here during lunch time though.
author: Linda C.

description: The best possible takeout.  I love everything here.  My favs are the lemongrass pork vermicelli and the claypot chicken.  This is my "good job on rocking that meeting" lunch spot because it can be a little on the pricey side.  Or I go there when i'm having a bad day because it just makes me happy.  Don't be afraid of the line though; it moves really quickly.
author: Alyssa W.

description: The food quality and service here is a smidge better than the Westfield one I think.  I've already voiced my displeasure about the repriced $3 chicken buns in my review there.  Still, a reliable standby for a clean, good lunch.  The boba were perfect today too.
author: Leo C.

description: I wandered in Out the Door while checking out the Ferry Building and could not resist ordering something! They were hustling and bustling, and everything looked and smelled delicious!  Also, there was such a smattering of choice that it took my breath away!  (I am a BIG fan of as many choices as possible when dining out, which often proves to be difficult when one is a vegetarian..) Lucky for me, there were choices abound, AND it was nearly lunchtime.  Phew!  I ordered the two salads+rice plate and decided upon the special green-bean salad with the most amazingly delicious sauce as well as a noodle dish that was out of this world!!!!!!!!  I could not get enough of this scrumptious food, and wish I could eat it as much as humanly possible, especially because it would be awesome for my non-allergy inducing diet, which restricts cheese, dairy, wheat, etc.  If you have a chance to go to Out the Door or the Slanted Door, do it!!! You will NOT be disappointed.
author: Joolz M.

description: This is a great addition to the embarcadero area lunch selection!  the shrimp rice noodle bowl, the lemongrass tofu, and the spring rolls are my favorites...but I've tried a few of their specials, particularly the braised short ribs, which are amazing as well!  There is a bit of a wait, and it's not the cheapest lunch option...but a little Vietnamese on a sunny day sitting outside staring at the bay...it's tough, let me tell you!
author: Sarah D.

description: Saigon Roasted Pork sandwich, wow. Some Iced Tea to wash it down and I was good to go. Obviously more expensive than the normal Pork Sandwich you can find in Chinatown, but they make up for it with the great bread, twice as much pork, and a tasty sauce...
author: Nicolas H.

description:
I'm a FAN!  I dream about the papaya salad from Slanted Door--so fresh + yummy.  Instead of waiting for my next super spendy night there--the lunch portion (and price) is perfect.  I think it was $7!
I also had the special of the day which was bite-sized pork ribs w/ broccoli+mushrooms+rice.  So good--and a huge portion.  I also had Blue Bottle Coffee (dripped to order) which I was really excited about--I don't think it's served anywhere else downtown?  After coffee/bottled water and salad/ribs my bill was under $20.   That's a great kind of cheating Slanted Door experience.  I'll definitely be back to try the lunch specials again.  
Desserts looked yummy too.
author: Amy C.

description: Not too exciting. Pretty simple. Good but missing something.  I ate here for lunch yesterday and was pleasantly surprised at how fast they are for being in the peak lunching hour of 12:15pm.  Of course, it IS To Go so they should be on it.  by "it" I mean their jack you up junk known as Vietnamese coffee so they can kick out food to the herd of cattle in line to chew cud.  I got one b/c my morning coffee shakes had worn off and I was starting to slow down.  We can't be havin' me running at anything less than full on tweak all day and this sure did the trick.  I was back stuttering and bouncing my knees in no time.  Any who, back to the food.  It was ok.  I still prefer Out The Door's daddy to this one any day.
author: Chard M.

description:
everything's overpriced downtown, so prices are pretty standard

great food with good-sized portions in a very convenient box

walk over to an adjacent pier and take in the view while you wonder how many days of your life each bite of dragon rolls will take away

it's a welcome change from the usual sandwich or burrito or salad and always worth a return trip

come early, though, as some of the better dishes tend to sell out
author: Charles C.

description: One of the more satisfying lunches I have had in awhile.  I tend to avoid malls but was brought to Out the Door because it was something I HAD to try.  I could not be happier and am even considering going back tomorrow, mall surroundings and all.  The green papaya salad is one of the more perfect fusion of tastes with pickled carrots and tofu; I highly recommend.  The lemongrass chicken was equally good.   The service was impeccable. Our waiter was really informative and nice.  I'll be back.
author: Catrinel A.

description: I'm personally disappointed with Out the Door. When they first started, I thought the food was excellent and just as good as Slanted Door, but with little wait time and reasonably priced for the quality of food. But recently, I feel that the food is uneven. For example, take their lemon grass tofu dish. Sometimes it's quite saucy and nice (or shall I say naughty?  ;-)). Other times, it tastes like they ran out of time to throw some sauce on it. Same with their lemon grass pork. Sometimes it's saucy and sometimes it's dry. I also checked out the Westfield Mall one. The restaurant itself is beautifully decorated, but the food was mediocre.
author: unhei k.

description: Not nearly enough vegetarian options. Fairly expensive for takeout... but less expensive than the actual restaurant. Good springrolls (which is basically the only thing you can order if you're vegetarian)
author: n s.

description: Many days have a big crowd at work and need a quick quality alternative near down town....  Out the door delivers.  Oh yeah.. can be healthy too!   Definitely worth the walk.
author: Tom C.

description: I ordered the spicy grilled pork with vermicelli noodles and was not impressed. It was a bit overpriced compared to what you would typically pay for Vietnamese food but in its credit, the restaurant is very clean and you don't have to deal with bad service that is normal with Vietnamese restaurant. Ha, I can bad mouth my own people. I usually expect Vietnamese food to be fresh and lite but the pork was cut in big chunks and there was hardly in fresh vegetables (lettuce, cucumber, pickled carrots, etc.). I paid $13 for the grill pork with vermicelli and well was expecting a bit more value for my money.
author: Ailien P.

description: Out the Door is about as solid as over the counter take out comes. Along with Slanted Door favorites like chicken claypot and crispy imperial rolls, Out the Door offers what is arguably my favorite sandwich in the city, the 5 spice chicken sandwich. This sandwich is especially good when the chicken is a bit fatty and peppery. Although the barbecued Niman Ranch pork spareribs isn't offered at this Out the Door location, I can't complain. The efficiency of the staff and the green tea boba also keep me coming back. For these reasons, Out the Door is one of my standby favorites.
author: Adam L.

description: Well, I seem to be the first to give Out the Door 5 stars, and it's for my personal one-time experience, which was perfect - especially because it's take-out and fast.  The food was excellent and ready very quickly.  They use high quality meats (niman ranch, etc.) and organic (?) veggies, and the lunch entree portions were huge.  We had the lemongrass pork and 5-spice chicken/vermicelli, both of which were very good and they had fresh brown rice available for the rice dish.  They also use biodegradable and recyclable take out materials, although it would be nice if it was all compostable instead of recyclable plastic.  Because it's the ferry building, there are also receptacles for this stuff  if you eat there.
author: Sarah B.

description: Can a sista get an order of Spring Rolls & some Peanut Sauce, PLEASE?!  Super fresh & delish...good vermacelli & grilled meats...I'm happy!!!
author: Amoura B.

description: Two words Pork Sandwich. Delicious, try it and you'll love it. I commute to SF to work each day, and at least once a week I'll drive hungry for an hour just to get to the city to enjoy this meal.
author: austin g.

description: Best  worktime lunch in the City with the lunchtime line to prove it! The fresh spring rolls are my absolute fave. The peanut sauce served alongside is spicy and crunchy. The steamed buns are another great choice.  Make it a long lunch and sit along the waterfront and enjoy!
author: Joslyn D.

description: I tried the chicken congee..yumm it was HUGE and HOT so make sure you take your time before taking the first bite. It was good. I wish it came with some chinese donut..;)
author: Alissa T.

description: At the urging of Meryl, I tried this place last Saturday. I had just finished walking about a million blocks in the Saint Patrick's Day parade and I was a hungry hungry hippo! Luckily, the lemongrass tofu with broccoli and rice really hit the spot! It was a little pricey for me (Oooo, seven dollars!) but the chunks of tofu were huge and accompanied by strips of seitan (I think) and large mushrooms (amazing). Like I said, I was starving and this definitely quieted the demon inside me for at least a couple of hours.
author: Larisa S.

description: The food looks and smells good and people look like they are really enjoying it, but my review is for two things - the Vietnamese coffee and Hong Kong (hot) milk tea.  I love them both.  When i want sweet smooth warm coffee/tea that is not as strong tasting as Peet's or Blue Bottle during a farmers' market pillage on a sunny Saturday, this is it.
author: Today Y.

description: i TRY not to eat here every day. But their vegetarian steamed buns keep pulling me in. Mushrooms!  Glass noodles! Delish!  The chicken bun is good as well, since it doesn't have all that funky cartilage surprise meat that you usually find in steamed buns.  The duck rice porridge is very tasty, the duck is broken into pieces and also not all cartilage-y.  The spring rolls make my tummy happy on a warm-ish day (or as warm as we get here anyway).
author: Lisa Marie G.

description: I really love coming to the ferry building during lunch.  I love eating outside on a sunny day and perusing the cute little stores, and I love Out the Door for a fresh & tasty lunch.  I don't care how touristy it can get or how crowded, it just makes me happy :)  The salads are great, particularly the chicken salad.  Chicken buns are pretty yummy too, and cheap.  Although it is a little pricey for a full lunch (unless you just get chicken buns), you'll end up paying just as much going to any other popular FiDi lunch spot.
author: Jenna H.

description: At out the door you can get very similar dishes to the slanted door, with the same quality and  lower prices, without the wait and the attitude.  What's not to love?  I've tried their vermicelli dishes, their salads, sandwiches and imperial rolls, and loved them all.  The wait and the lack of seating is not ideal, but that doesn't stop me from going there every chance I get.
author: cecilia g.

description: went here for dinner on a thurdsday night with a friend.  got a table and it was fast and convinient.  The food wasnt overwhelmingly good but its great for the area and the service is just excellent.  Not super cheap but definitely reasonable.  at the time i got there around 530pm there was no wait at all
author: Diego C.

description:
I feel so damn lucky to watch the Phan family rock the modern ethnic restaurant category.  I mean--my amazing $5 glass of riesling, in a crystal reider stemless wineglass, and the super warm, chillax vibe from the lovely, fiercely independent service staff (like laura cunningham kissed the sport with her grace and best wishes, and some on the ball people at the slanted door caught it, and have been running with it ever since, only to finesse it into perfection at out the door.  The angelic being who brought me my water works in the kitchen at hawthorne lane.  The warm & fuzzy hombre who brought me the delectable 5spice chicken vermicelli with divine roasted peanut dust was from espana, and had a very cool vintage 3/4 length adidas down jacket on as he was leaving.  These people were like super lovable sweethearts.  And the food, as always, was pristine, organic, uber-top quality, modern cal-vietnamese deliciousness.  My wine, well, I'm still savoring its memory.  How often can most of us say that?  Unless you work for the highly-respected sommelier of the slanted door.
The whole experience was delightful, happy-making and memorable.  But, go ahead and hate it.  Stay away.  I love how spacious it is, and the ultra-green build-out of this subterranean food court space is, kinda ethereal, but in a really grounded way.  It feels good to sit in there.  I hope they bring in a dj on a regular basis.  That would rock it.  The wall of honey pressed between plexiglass panels is intriguing and fun to stare it, like stoner tv.  
I drove across the bridge at 7:30, paid $$ to park in a garage, all to get my fix of an inspired meal, in a uber-chillax, yet stimulating environment, served by very special beings.  
I like this version of Charle's genius the best.  Although Valencia st. was way cool back then.  (pre dot).
But, hey--stay away.  You'll hate it.
author: Kenzie D.

description: Yummy!! The weekday lunch hour lines get a bit long, but once you get the pager its just a few minutes.
author: viv k.

description: The chicken buns are excellent.  So excellent that I've never ordered anything else there.  Chicken buns forever!
author: Risa S.

description: Chicken dumplings for $2.00; the only reason why I would come here, well, also because I work upstairs, but I'd rather go to Chinatown.  I will admit, these dumplings are so good that they just might put M.S.G. in them because I feel like crap after downing three of these suckers!  I here  Slanted Door is the real thing.  That is only, if you're the real thing (it's costly)!
author: Justin C.

description: My owna brought home some yummy rice noodles from this place.  The 5 spice chicken and beef combo vermicelli noodle plate with fresh ass spring roll side rocks for a quick dinner fix.  A little pricey but tastes good.  I highly recommend this place for a quick take out dinner on the way home.  Panda says yummy!
author: Steven L.

description: I ordered a pork meatball bahn mi here and was pleasantly surprised at how good it was.  I would have liked some pickled daikon on it, but otherwise it was solid.  At $9 it's kind of hard to justify when I can get a better bahn mi for $2.75 at Saigon Sandwich, but if you're stuck in the Embarcadero area and really need a bahn mi, this will do.
author: Michelle A.

description:
to quote the child loving "Wheezie" from Dragon Tails..."LOOOOVE IT"
I eat here at least twice a week and get the Lemon Grass tofu with brown rice.  It is excellent, 11.66 total and worth it.  I usually go around 11:30 as lunch time is swamped.
author: d S.

description: the spring rolls are really tasty here. i actually don't like spring rolls. i took a bite and i had to have all of them. the peanut sauce is REALLY tasty.
author: Helen C.

description: Food was actually decent - but about 30-40% too expensive for what you're getting. Their chicken claypot is great - but it's not $10 good, you can the same thing in inner richmond for a lot less. Food was three stars - but freaking HATED the atmosphere. The metal tables made me feel like I was in prison or something - felt like I was eating at Ikea (to clarify - I don't like eating at Ikea).
author: Sung P.

description: I wish the sandwiches were a bit cheaper, since I'm used to paying 1/3 the price.  The staff is rude too.  So, I just settle for the chicken bun for $2.50 and go on my frugal way.
author: Val U.

description: This place has impeccable Vietnamese sandwiches, albeit at double the price of the standard ones found all over the FiDi.  I've had them all, and I have to say the Five Spice Chicken is my favorite.  Sometimes they can take a while (tops 15 min), but you are in the Ferry Building, so take the time to browse all the beautiful foodstuffs and get ideas for meals.  Also a plus, they use Blue Bottle for their Vietnamese coffee.  All in all, a great place to grab a delicious lunch and sit by the water or amuse yourself with tourists' antics.
author: Gianpaolo P.

description: Fresh veggie spring rolls are about the only thing I get here.  They are always good when I'm short on time.  Filled with mint, rice noodles, mushrooms, mung bean shoots, and carrot (other ingredients indiscernible), these little rolls are fresh, easy to scarf down, and will keep you satiated for a few hours at least.  But, they would be nothing without the spicy peanut sauce...it really completes the flavor medley.
author: Celeste A.

description: I wonder if proximity is the main driver of why I go here.  It certainly isn't the best value but it's the Ferry Building so I expect that.  I work right next door.  I've eaten at the Slanted Door restaurant and enjoyed it mightily.  What I've had at OTD is certainly not bad or else I wouldn't keep going back; it's tasty but it doesn't seem to linger in my mind.  Maybe part of the draw is that it seems to be of higher quality than my other lunch options so I'm more willing to fork over the cash.  Got it-it doesn't translate as well as take out as it does while eating in house.  That must be why I'm feeling so 3 star-ish about it.
author: Nicole B.

description: ...lunch today with a friend...we both loved everything...service was perfect, wait persons friendly and helpful...the sauteed daikon and rice cake was wonderful...i'd go again in a second...
author: Bob L.

description: I felt compelled to update this review, lest I send someone here only to be disappointed. In recent months they have increased prices not once but twice. Could be understandable in today's economy, but they also lowered the quality of the food at the same time and that just doesn't seem right. The rice is of a much lower quality and they got rid of their fresh Sriracha sauce in favor of little "Ketchup packets" of sauce that tastes lousy. Sorry OTD, I won't be going back any time soon.
author: Craig V.

description: The worst iced vietnamese coffee EVER! It was watery, barely tasted like coffee even though I waited 10 minutes for it to drip. I've had better coffee from 7-11. Be sure to keep your receipt because they'll let other people who ordered the same thing as you run off with your food. I go back because I like their spring rolls but I've waited 20 minutes another day for a Hong Kong Milk Tea because they kept giving mine to someone else. What the hell are those buzzer things for if you don't use them? Twice now they've messed up my order and wasted my time. The horrible HORRIBLE vietnamese iced coffee took the cake though. It was watered down milk... HORRIBLE!!!!
author: Art L.

description: I met a friend there for lunch a couple of weeks ago and ordered the curry.  Not the most flavorful food I've had, but they delivered really good food in little time at all on my lunch hour (i.e. it's not as good as the Slanted Door, but that is to be expected).  So, consider me a fan.  It can take a little time to get through the line at times, but it didn't take me too long to get food after that.  Also, the price was fairly reasonable for the quality of the food.  I can't wait to eat there again!
author: Ryan M.

description: So the banh mi is literally 3x the price it is in the 'loin, but the fresh tangy papaya salad and the ability to walk outside and gorge on lunch in the sun overlooking the bay almost makes up for the price. As for the imperial rolls, see banh mi comment above. The duck jook was a little too bland and had little duck in it and the 5-spice chicken sandwich didn't taste like it had any spice at all. But I will still go back and try the soups and recs from other yelpers; the food was fresh, seemed carefully prepared, and I was much more pleasant than the main restaurant.
author: Liboo K.

description: If you're looking for a vietnamese sandwich and you are far from the tenderloin, then i guess this is acceptable. its a lot of just OK...but today i tried the pork on vermicelli noodles and it was AWFUL. the meat was tough, dry, and poorly flavored. it tasted like it was cooked by someone who did not dare to taste it, and who has teath of sharp steel.
author: Z C.

description: Above average take-out lunch destination for lunch.   I wish there were more places like this in the Ferry Building.  Their salads are noodles are solid.
author: Frenchy B.

description: Definitely the place to lunch while shopping or for a bite before a movie.  Very nice Vietnamese food without all the hassle of Slanted Door.  Service can be slow, but it's a pleasant place to be.
author: Eric H.

description: I've ended up at Out the Door on quite a few occasions, usually the result of farmer's market madness and long lines at all the other eateries on a typical Saturday afternoon at the Ferry Plaza. This fast food version of The Slanted Door offers French-Vietnamese (although mainly Vietnamese) food from a permanent stall outside the mother restaurant. There is usually no line, you can easily go up to the counter and order to your hearts content- they give you a buzzer so you can go off exploring until your food is ready. Everything I've ordered from here has been fresh and flavorful. The chicken buns never cease to amaze me. These moist rice flour buns are stuffed with a very gingery chicken and bits of mushroom. The vegetarian spring rolls are a refreshing snack- rice paper encasing layers of lettuce, cabbage, carrots, tofu, and mushrooms, and served with a chili peanut dipping sauce.I've also had the green papaya salad, which was delicious. I had to ask for a fish free dressing, but that was not a problem. My only complaint is the prices, which are on the high side- this is however, the Ferry Building, so what do you expect?
author: Kate A.

description: Why am I the only one not enchanted with the Door Trio? I already know I don't like Slanted Door or Out the Door Westfield, but my wife (who also didn't like Slanted Door) eats regularly here. I ordered the Pork Vemicelli and was rewarded with lots of shiny pork that unfortunately was tough to the point of being difficult to eat and has lots of stuff that looked like thick hairs sticking out of it. It wasn't hair, but it wasn't very appealing either. I get more delicous pork from a $2.50 pork sandwich at most Vietnamese delis. I also tried often praised vegetable bun, which was good but no better than the one in my freezer I picked up at Kukje Korean market in DC, and certainly not worth going there just for that alone. The $5 rice pudding was fantastic, with hints of ginger and cubes of fresh mango, maybe the best rice pudding I've had. I couldn't eat any more pork so I traded with my wife half way through for her chicken curry. Delicous sauce, rice like couscous, and lots of chicken. I would have enjoyed it more had they removed the bones and skin from the chicken though. I went back to work with an upset stomach from the greasy factor I guess. I vow to never again eat from Slanted Door or any of its offshoots. I just can't ride this wave.
author: Johnny O.

description: Decent stop for Vietnamese sandwiches, but it wasn't amazing.  I had the chicken sandwich.  It was pretty good, and the bread was excellent (which is the norm in SF), but it wasn't all that filling for how much you pay.  Definitely some other spots in the area to go to for a decent lunch.  But that doesn't mean I won't go back to try more things.
author: Amit M.

description: I'm so disappointed in this place and frankly at the whole Out the Door chain. So much potential, but its over priced and average tasting food in the smallest portions possible. The grilled chicken is almost inedible because they give you fatty pieces. $8.50 for very little vermicelli and even smaller portions of veggies and fatty misc. pieces of chicken? No thanks.
author: Mama L.

description: try the roast pork sandwich $8.50. expect a somewhat long wait. there can be very long lines. take it to go and eat by the water or find a seat/table inside where available. very limited.
author: Oanh N.

description: One of the best deals in SF Steamed Buns $3.00!!! Great deal and delicious .Really good deserts Mango tapoica pudding to die for.One of my favorite quick stops.
author: Kathy B.

description: Definitely look at this place as a lunch treat....good size portions (nice meat to noodle ratio) to take and sit outside on a sunny day. I love the pork vermicelli, and the utensils they have are oddly fascinating. Trust me on that one.
author: Kaveh A.

description: This review is only about Justine's scones.  My friend works at the Slanted Door and told me that I had to try Justine's scones sold at Out the Door. Justine was apparently hired by Mr. Phan when the Slanted Door was still on Valencia. Mr. Phan and his wife tried Justine's scones and hired her.  The scones are huge, and look like the the tops of huge muffins. They are slightly crunchy on the outside with raisins and orange zest on the inside. Perfect amount of sweetness and really very moist. These babies are only available on Fridays and Saturdays. I guess she only makes a dozen or so a day, so when they're out, they're gone. They cost $2.50 a scone, which is not bad since they are HUGE and considering we are in the financial district/ferry building, it is not bad at all. I was there this morning right when Out the Door opened, and bought 2 scones (even though they ended up giving me 3). They had just finished baking not too long ago because the scone was still warm. It was perfect with my iced frappe drink from Peet's.  I will definitely come back for more!
author: Annie Y.

description: We had our work party here (when I recommended it based on other reviews) and on another occasion I managed to get a table for 8 last minute for out-of-town colleagues (luck!!) and everyone was impressed with the food, the service, and the wine selections.  Yes it can get pricey but the jicama salad, the rolls, dishes and desert + the austrian riesling make it all worth it.
author: jess l.

description: J says: More like 3.5 stars.  I've been craving vietnamese lately so I went to slanted door's little take-out station in the ferry buildling today and got myself the pork spare ribs (one of today's specials) and imperial rolls.  The spare ribs were so-so, I felt they weren't marinated or cooked long enough so was lacking a bit in flavor.  The sweet corn that came with the dish was really fresh and extra sweet though.  The imperial rolls were probably the best I've had among many vietnamese restaurants, there were chunks of tasty shrimp in them.    I also got an iced vietnamese coffee which was oh so good, but got me on a huge sugar high because of all the sweetened condensed milk they put in it.  On another occasion I tried their curry chicken and was sorely disappointed, there wasn't much flavor, really below average.  I got there before the lunch crowd today (before noon) and the line was very short and service was quick.
author: Jen Ken H.

description: mmm, beef noodle soup, fresh spring rolls, lemongrass noodles. yep, this confirms slanted door - in and out the door - is one of my favorites.
author: Liz R.

description: i love this little lunchtime spot - just like going to the slanted door but during the day, waiting in line instead of sitting at a table, and a slightly smaller menu.  the quality of the food is still great - i love their spring rolls and imperial rolls, and the soups.  most recently i also tried the chicken bun - yes please!
author: Carolyn B.

description: The 5-spice chicken sandwich was really good, and the Vietnamese coffee was nice and strong.  A friend, who is a regular, took me there, and she got the spring rolls and chicken bun.  If I lived in the city, I think Out the Door is too expensive to become a HABIT, but I'd definitely go every now and then.  I really enjoyed watching the water from the benches outside.
author: Samantha L.

description: this place is so good and innovative(have you seen their take home claypot kit thingies?). everything is rad. if you are a veggie...theyve got your jam. if you like carcass theyve got your jam. my only qualm is that since seating during lunchtime at the ferry building is cray to the cray, they need to make the food i dont know.... easier to eat when you are benching it up. Its spilly central. LIKE TOTES
author: Lauren V.

description: mmmm...this place has the BEST chicken buns. i used to look forward to getting cupcakes at miette when i went to the ferry building, but out the door is my new obsession. the food has been so yummy to date. i just got the wonton noodle soup and it hit the spot!
author: eve l.

description: Recently I ordered a Chicken Clay Pot here. It was  $13!!!!!!!!! It also took them twenty minutes to make it and when I had it ,there was way too much sauce!!!!! Worst chicken clay pot ever!
author: Jacob A.

description: I had the chicken and it was mediocre. For the price, I'd suggest Taylor's instead.
author: suz q.

description: great place to get take out food especially on a sunny saturday in the ferry building. i had pork with lemograss with veggies..which was without surprise very good.  im glad to see that the quality doesnt suffer just because it is a "take out window".
author: Christian S.

description: Delicious!  Try the jook - duck or chicken yummy! or the saute shrimp vermicelli - just right!
author: Hope O.

description: I've passed this place a lot and it always seems to be closing down so I've never stopped.  Today I first asked for a meatball bahn mi but, at 10:30 am, they were already sold out!  So I got the pork and it was kind of bland for a bahn mi.  There are less then a dozen "seats" here so it's not good for a crowd (inside at the Slanted Door they have room but I'm only reviewing Out the Door here) and I doubt the help could handle a crowd all wanting food at the same time.  Took them about 10 mins to fix my little sandwich (and nothing had to be cooked in it), and then it cost $9.  I gave them a $20 and only got a $10 back; I brought this up to the guy running the register but he insisted that was the correct change--so I didn't leave a tip.  This place is priced for the tourist trade and their food isn't anything to write home about--you can get better and cheaper elsewhere (and close by too).  I'll skip the Slanted Door and it's back Door from now on.
author: Kai T.

description: This is not really mall food.  It's a great restaurant in its own right.  Here's my tip: you can order steamed chicken buns anytime of day.  They'll say it's only on the menu for lunch.  But, they always have them if you ask.
author: Sharif E.

description: i had a craving for pho and i didn't want to go to pho hoa cuz of my previous post so i decided to check this place out.  a bowl of beef pho...$8.  it is quite expensive but it was good.  plus they're fast cuz its slanted doors to go...see previous post too.  anyways, it comes packaged in a cute plastic container, all the fixing in a separate bag, and cute plastic soup spoon.  pretty good size, noodles are thicker here, meat was good, but it was clumped together so it was kinda hard to eat it.  all in all very good pho but again, it's pricey.  not a whole lot of selection but seems that the rolls are pretty popular with the tourists!  they also have chicken congee, lemon grass something...
author: D W.

description: the orange beef salad here is TO DIE FOR!  i'm told the jicama grapefruit is their specialty (and i do love me some jicama...), but the orange beef is really where it's at.  every time i bring a friend here they go buck wild for it, and i'm left staring wistfully while i settle for the jicama.  no more  - in the future, i'll order two orange beef salads, because no one should have to share.  portions are quite good, you'll want your own nonethless.  it comes with friend taro strips on top.  BOOYA!
author: nicole l.

description: The food is good for lunch... but it is the service that makes it so bad.  I had a big order for 4 people.  I called ahead but they wouldn't take my order over the phone because it was for 4 and did not reach their minimum of 10 people.  They promised I would have my food in no more than 15 minutes.  Now mind you, the ferry building is a weird place to find parking- so I took the risk to park up front and ran inside to place my order and get the food.  Hey 15 minutes, why not? They took my order quickly...but it was 50 minutes later before I actually got my food.
